PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHAPMAN; COULTER; FOREMAN; HAINES; JONES; SCHACHT; VANSTONE
PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chapman (from 225 citizens), Coulter (from 230 citizens), Foreman (from 156 citizens), Haines (from 202 citizens), Jones (from 527 citizens), Schacht (from 245 citizens) and Vanstone (from 304 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987-88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound, your petitioners, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting as suggested in the Bill ``The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989''.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by businesses who sell/supply goods and/or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate Standing Committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam War from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Watson, at the request of Senator Walters (from 1,624 citizens).,

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
that increasing numbers of Australians with modest incomes are becoming subject to the Capital Gains Tax upon the sale of assets never acquired for speculative intent;

that the continuation of this tax in its present form threatens to deprive Australians engaged in small business of adequate returns for the sale of enterprises developed through effort and risk-taking;
that this increasingly unjust and burdensome tax be replaced by measures of taxation upon short term and speculative capital gains only.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and 11) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 46 citizens), Michael Baume (from 35 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 23 citizens) and Faulkner (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should support both the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of electors, and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older;
if open not-for-profit health funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably;
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled urge the Government to take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: New Schools Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that the Government's New Schools Policy unnecessarily restricts the non-Government school sector.
Your petitioners therefore request the members of the Senate to:
recognise the right of every child to a reasonable level of Commonwealth support for their education;
recognise that parents should be provided with real choice in the schooling they choose for their children;
call upon the Government to abolish the New Schools Policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conservation of Resources
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

on 1 September 1989 the Australian Tax Office sought to discourage the recycling of glass bottles by imposing sales tax on the cost of re-acquiring such bottles and on crating, classifying, storing, sorting, washing and cleaning them;

this will result in major beverage manufacturers abandoning the use of bottles in favour of plastic containers, which are made from valuable non-renewable and imported resources, and which are then thrown away to become waste;
furthermore, the Income Tax Assessment Act encourages businesses to throw away valuable equipment by allowing full write-offs only if the equipment is scrapped.
Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should take steps to amend tax laws:
(a) to encourage the conservation of resources rather than the throwing-away of resources;
(b) so that no sales tax is payable on any recycled or re-used components;
(c) so that a penal sales tax in the form of a waste tax is imposed on all throw-away products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conservation of Resources
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully shows:

that on 1 September 1989 the Australian Tax Office sought to discourage the recycling of glass bottles by imposing sales tax on the cost of re-acquiring such bottles and on crating, classifying, storing, sorting, washing and cleaning them;

that this will result in major beverage manufacturers abandoning the use of bottles in favour of plastic containers, which are made from valuable non-renewable and imported resources, and which are then thrown away to become waste;
that the Income Tax Assessment Act encourages businesses to throw away valuable equipment by allowing full write-offs only if the equipment is scrapped.
that we call upon the Parliament to amend all tax laws to encourage the conservation of resources rather than the throwing-away of resources;
that no sales tax should be payable on any recycled or re-used components;
that a penal sales tax in the form of a waste tax should be imposed on all throw-away products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COONEY

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 100 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, object to the proposed amendments to the Social Security Act which will restrict the rights of the unemployed to freedom of movement. The reasons for our objections are as follows:
1. The amendments would force unemployed people who need to move to find out what changes of residence would be acceptable to the Department of Social Security. This is an unacceptable intrusion.
2. The amendments do not appear to add anything to the existing work test. If they do, then it is at the administrative level where widely different approaches may be taken.
3. The cost of administering such an unclear test would be considerable.

4. The only exception to cancellation-moving to live with or near relatives-is too narrow. There are many other valid reasons for moving home. Not least of these is the pressure of increasing rents, which affect people on benefits particularly strongly. Rents are higher in areas of higher employment. People forced to move for this or other strong reasons should not be penalized by termination or suspension of benefit.
We, the petitioners, request that you reject the proposed amendments.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that all honourable senators have agreed to be extraordinarily brief on this matter, given the constraints that are upon us. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 330 and made under the National Health Act 1953, be disallowed.

In speaking very briefly to the motion, I make three points. Firstly, this regulation was introduced in what I regard as a somewhat dishonourable fashion in the way in which it was processed in the Senate. We became aware, through the good offices of my colleague Senator Kay Patterson, of the particular problems which were inherent in this regulation. On 14 December Senator Patterson purchased a copy of this regulation from the Australian Government Publishing Service and tabled it in the Senate on that day. It is perhaps instructive to look at the fact that there is a paper which sets out those papers to be tabled by the Clerk on that day. The paper indicates that statutory rules Nos. 317 to 359 were tabled on that day, with the exception of statutory rule No. 330. I put it to the Senate that it is our belief that there was a deliberate attempt on the part of the health authorities to ensure the latest possible tabling of that regulation in a way which simply did not allow it to come within the scrutiny of our normal procedures. It is shameful that that sort of activity should be undertaken. It is, however, not the first time that delayed tabling of sensitive regulations which governments or departments hope to sneak through without notice has occurred.

The second point that I want to make is that this regulation was made without proper consultation with the pharmacy profession which it affects directly. Indeed, the first contact between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia on this subject occurred on 14 December, the day on which Senator Patterson tabled the regulation. Pharmacists were unaware that they had not been properly notified that they were in breach of the regulations at the time these regulations were put down because the Department had not adequately informed them of the change that was being made to dispensing rules. It is quite unacceptable that a profession should be treated in this fashion, particularly when the meat in the sandwich of any such dispute is the patients and consumers of Australia-those who need their prescriptions filled and are dependent upon pharmacists to provide them with those prescriptions. I will not delay the Senate by reciting the details of correspondence between the Health Insurance Commission or the Department of Community Services and Health and various pharmacists around the place. I simply refer honourable senators to the speech of my colleague Senator Patterson on 20 December which sets out those matters in detail.

The third and final issue to which I refer is the question of what is contained in the regulations and what is fundamentally defective about them. Part 8 of the regulation provides that a pharmacist is not to dispense a repeat prescription within three days of having dispensed the original or previous prescription. I simply ask honourable senators to address their minds to these examples: the person whose prescription item is lost or an item in a particular form which has been spilt, broken or destroyed; the person who needs a daily supply of a legally injectable substance; or the example which I gave the other day of people such as myself who use small asthma sprays for the control of a particular disease and who often have two or three of those sprays around the place-one carried on the person, one perhaps somewhere at home, one in the car, one in the office-and who, as a result, go to a pharmacist and seek to have five repeats filled on sequential days so that they have an adequate supply of that particular item around. The regulations do not provide adequately for emergency situations which would allow patients the maximum degree of flexibility in the management of their own health care concerns.

We also object to some of the requirements for the sex and age of applicants to be notified in a particular fashion in relation to the filling of prescriptions which are provided for in part 5 (c) of these regulations. The Opposition parties are not opposed to the introduction of appropriate technology within the pharmacy system, the proper recording of these matters and the appropriate use of modern technology. We do, however, have considerable concerns about the personal detail which needs to be given.

In conclusion, I simply repeat my three points. Firstly, we believe that the Government and the Department have not acted properly in terms of the way in which they have dealt with the Senate over the tabling of this particular regulation. Secondly, we believe that the Government has not acted properly in terms of the lack of consultation between the Government, the Department and the profession. Thirdly, we believe that the regulations themselves are fundamentally defective. For those three reasons I have moved that this regulation be disallowed and that the Government come back in February and re-present its case properly after it has had consultation with the pharmacy profession and after it has given additional thought to the significant change which it is going to make in the operations of pharmacies and the way in which people will manage their own health care status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support the Opposition in the disallowance of these regulations as contained in statutory rules No. 330 for the following reasons. As Senator Puplick has mentioned, one part of these regulations relates to the redispensing of a prescription within three days of the initial or some subsequent dispensing of the prescription if there are a number of repeats. I do not want to enter into an argument as to whether the new regulation is completely justified on the grounds which the Government has stated, namely, that it is designed to prevent hoarding of pharmaceutical agents towards the end of a prescription year. Equally I accept the sorts of hypothetical situations which have been posed by Senator Puplick. Without entering into that, I simply make the point that it seems to me that there are grounds for deciding either way with respect to this regulation, but the way in which the regulation has been presented has not allowed a proper debate of that matter. That is the central reason why the Democrats will support the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulation was introduced, evidently, on 1 December but the pharmacists themselves were not told of that introduction, nor were they consulted before this regulation was introduced. As I understand it, it was not until 13 or 14 December that anybody became aware of it. A letter was sent to pharmacists explaining that that fact notwithstanding, had they refilled a prescription within three days during the first two weeks of December they would not be liable to a fine or penalty.

But the question as to whether they would be eligible for payment under those circumstances is still very much an open legal question because the regulation as it stands says that a prescription shall not be filled within that three-day period. If that prescription had been filled it would be quite conceivable that the Government could simply refuse payment for that second prescription.

So the way in which this matter has been introduced has been quite unsatisfactory. The regulation was tabled in this place only yesterday, and that was the first opportunity we had, the day before the Senate was due to rise, to formally and properly look at it. The whole way in which this matter has been dealt with seems to be yet another example of the Minister concerned, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), dealing with pharmacists in a very arrogant manner. Surely this is a matter on which, as I indicated initially, one could argue either way on a three-day rule. For that reason and because it is likely to be contentious, it would have been appropriate to enter into some sort of consultation with both pharmacists and doctors, to decide what appropriate rule should be introduced, and then to introduce it in a manner whereby both Houses of the Parliament and those affected would know about it at the time of its introduction and not several weeks later.

It is for those reasons that we are supporting the Opposition's disallowance, bearing in mind that disallowing it at this time, when the Parliament is rising, gives the Government an adequate opportunity to go away, consult with those people affected and come back with a regulation in a form which is acceptable and at a time when it can be properly debated before that regulation starts to have effect. If we were to allow this regulation now, it would run right through until some time in April or May in a very unsatisfactory form with a number of legal matters unresolved. That situation is absolutely unsatisfactory and should be unacceptable to the Senate. It is principally the manner of the introduction and the handling of this whole issue which cause the Democrats to support the Opposition in its disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick said that, by agreement, we will be brief on this, but brevity does not in any way indicate a lack of passion or force of conviction on the Government's behalf as to the reasons why this regulation should proceed. In the beginning, let me out of hand reject the stunt by Senator Kay Patterson last week in trying to dramatise puny concerns about this matter. The Opposition's tactics in the matter of the disallowance of the amended regulations of the operation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) are a further example of its cynical and opportunistic approach to a whole range of issues in the health area. The Opposition's motion to disallow these regulations will stop the Government from protecting patients from overcharging by chemists.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is the Government proposing to change the regulations? The answer is simple. By getting pharmacists to place a price on the patient's record form, we can protect the patient from being overcharged. This is a responsible approach by the Government to respond to the fact that a recent Australia-wide survey of pharmacists revealed overcharging on 83.7 per cent of general patient prescriptions which were priced under $11. Worse than that, 56.5 per cent of those were recorded on the prescription record form, and this is a breach of the National Health Act. The survey was undertaken to discover how substantial and how widespread the overcharging was, following extensive coverage of the issue in the press and complaints from consumer groups and some pharmacist organisations concerned about the practice.

We are well aware of arguments that, because there is no direct government subsidy for items priced at less than $11 for general patients, there is no place for government controls on prices. Some pharmacist organisations have argued strongly that these prescriptions are not part of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and that therefore there should be no controls on what pharmacists charge. The Opposition, in an attempt to appeal to pharmacists for support, has said, `Yes, we agree. We will free up the price of these drugs and let you charge what you like'. This represents about the only promise of substance that has come from the Opposition in the health area.

I think we should look at the reality of the pricing of these items. The Commonwealth uses the pricing power of the universal pharmaceutical benefits scheme to get the best prices for taxpayers. The price negotiated with the manufacturer covers the supply to the chemist, regardless of who the patient will be. That is, the chemist pays the manufacturer the PBS price to chemists regardless of whether he or she dispenses the item to a pensioner or to a general patient. All Australians are meant to get the benefit of the price to manufacturer negotiated by the Commonwealth. It is ludicrous therefore to suggest that manufacturers should have their prices fixed to let pharmacists charge what they like. If the market were truly freed up, pharmacists would lose. For the first time the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association has made a submission to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. In their submission, the manufacturers say:
The Tribunal should be aware that by international standards PBS prices are very low with Australian manufacturers only receiving some 55% of world average prices.
They go on to say:

Manufacturers are concerned that the retail pharmacy share for dispensing a PBS product (47%) is virtually identical with the manufacturers share (48%) from which all research and development costs, medical and scientific support services, quality assurance and manufacturing costs, and product liability insurance costs among others, must be recovered. Recent initiatives by some pharmacists to surcharge patients receiving prescriptions costing less than the current $11.00 general user contribution are also of great concern to APMA as such actions not only distort the relative shares between pharmacists and manufacturer but can also be a further disincentive to a patient already making a disproportionate percentage of consumer contributions to PBS costs.

These comments are not comments from the Government or patients concerned about pharmacists overcharging, but from the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a key body representing the major pharmaceutical manufacturers in Australia. It is clear that the Opposition and apparently the Australian Democrats do not understand how the pharmaceutical benefits scheme works.

The second change to the regulations which the Opposition objects to is the amendment which prevents repeat prescriptions being filled within three days of the original prescription. Previously the regulations provided for only a one-day period between the filling of an original prescription and a repeat. The Opposition's approach to this issue is again cynical and, I have to say, opportunistic. Only a few months ago the Opposition's health spokesman, Mr Shack, said that he was concerned about people in Mercedes Benzes and Rolls Royces stopping outside chemist shops and stocking up with free prescriptions under the safety net scheme. The three-day provision in the regulation is intended to reduce a dangerous and costly stockpiling of medicine at the end of the year by extending the period between the filling of original and repeat prescriptions. This measure was announced in the Budget to tackle stockpiling of medicines for both safety and economic reasons. By disallowing this amendment the Opposition is again showing that it is prepared to support particular interest groups for short term political purposes to the detriment of sensible and rational health policy.

The Government is not prepared to let patients continue to fill original and repeat prescriptions at the same time and build up stocks of potentially dangerous drugs. To continue to allow this to happen is bad health policy and bad program management. I am surprised that Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats would support people being able to fill repeats excessively and to hold dangerously high levels of drugs in their homes.

The Department of Community Services and Health has received many calls from pharmacists on this change. I understand that virtually all support the three-day rule in principle. Some have raised potential problems, such as have been mentioned in this debate-for example, a patient losing or breaking a bottle-but this is no different from the situation under the existing 24-hour rule. The Government recognises that this potential problem should be addressed, and it is discussing special exemption provisions with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. It is pointless to suggest that the new regulations should be withdrawn until the exemption provisions are sorted out, as the potential problem would still exist under the old 24-hour rule.

The other change to the regulation relates to information about the age and sex of applicants for entitlement cards. This information is required to verify the entitlement for eligible persons. The Government is disappointed, therefore, that the Opposition has taken the line of disallowing these regulations and has been enjoined in that folly by the Australian Democrats, but we do not wish to prolong the debate and take up the time of the Senate on this matter.

Finally, the only helpful thing that will come from this sordid little episode is that next year the Australian electors will express, for the third time, their disappointment with the Opposition and the Democrats for interfering with attempts by this Government to save costs, and be fiscally restrained and thus impose a lesser burden on Australian taxpayers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 December, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Hill had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert ``the Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading as the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill:
(a) imposes excessive and unjustified prohibitions and restrictions on the collection and use of personal financial information;

(b) fails to provide that credit reference agencies be able to give commercial organisations reasonable access to appropriate financial information they have collected provided that the information is reasonably required by a commercial organisation to assist it in making commercial decisions;

(c) will place obstacles in the way of the detection of fraud, add to the cost of insurance, goods and services, increase interest rates and impose additional costs and inefficiencies on business, its customers and the community;

(d) falls short of the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988, particularly those Principles designed to ensure that individuals are made aware that information concerning them has been disclosed;
(e) will have many unintended consequences to the detriment of consumers, credit providers, credit reference agencies and the community as a whole; and
(f) has been introduced without adequate consultation''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes in which I spoke last night I was expressing concern about the Privacy Amendment Bill. I wish now to explain the reasons for my concern. The only winners from this legislation will be the practised delinquent debtors for whom life will be made that much easier, despite some minor modifications now proposed by the Government. We were debating a little while ago the disallowance of a pharmacy regulation. That, in itself, is amazing because the Government, after installing that regulation, decided that it would consult with pharmacy. The same thing happened with this Bill. As I was saying last night, this Bill was introduced in the dying hours of the autumn session and this debate is now being crammed into the dying hours of this session. Prior to the introduction of this legislation no consultation took place with those who were going to be affected. Limited consultation has taken place since, but the losers will be the mass of honest consumers who will be paying extra to meet the costs generated by this irresponsible minority, who will be denied credit or services because of the climate of business uncertainty that this Bill will create, or who will be encouraged into overcommitment simply because credit monitoring, in effect, will be prohibited.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a measure of the unreality of the Government's position that a senior ministerial adviser should be reported as having stated in May that the Australian community would accept increased credit costs of an extra 1 1/2 per cent in return for the supposed benefit of increased privacy. One may well ask, `Just how would he know?'. His only defence would be that in May interest rates had not hit their current massive levels, destroying earlier assumptions. All honourable senators, especially the Australian Democrats, who profess to have a special concern as to the impact of interest rates on Australians, should reflect long and hard before they assent to a Bill which, in effect, will lead to more expensive consumer credit.

It is the firm belief of the Federal coalition that legislation of this kind must strike a balance between commercial reality and the safeguarding of privacy. We are certainly not opposed to privacy amendments as such, but they have to be workable; they have to protect the consumer; and they have to protect those who are providing credit. This Bill fails the test and should be rejected. At the very least, the Senate must be prepared to amend it carefully, rather than railroad it through in the dying hours of this session. I believe that sound legislation must enable commercial organisations to have access to information showing financial problems that would enable them to make accurate commercial decisions. At the same time, consumers must have the right to be given reasonable notice that such access has occurred and to obtain redress for any improper use of personal information.

It should be made perfectly clear that for all the mischief that this Bill does to business it does not provide any more real privacy protection for the citizen than is already given. This Hawke Labor Government cannot claim the excuse that the current practice of credit reference reporting involves actual violations of privacy; rather, the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA), through which 98 per cent of credit reference reporting occurs, maintains a careful discipline over its 4,800 members. These include not only credit providers but also retailers, insurance companies, public utilities-in fact, Telecom Australia accounts for over 6 per cent of CRAA business-trading companies and real estate agents. The use of CRAA files is governed by proper security, with records kept only on financial matters and not on personal information, with prohibitions on their use for private investigation, mailing lists or pre-employment checks. I would agree that the concept of so-called positive reporting raises the undesirable possibility of greatly enlarged personal data compilation, and the coalition would support sensible proposals to remove this possibility.

In this Bill, however, we have an effective prohibition of the negative reporting that is essential to credit providers and users. This Government may move 41 amendments that here and there lessen the severity of its initial proposals, but the fact remains that this Bill stands as a massive spoke in the wheels of credit provision and business activity, because it strikes at the viability of the Credit Reference Association of Australia. That Association has been set an all but impossible task in separating commercial credit from consumer credit in its existing files, perhaps involving millions of manual extractions. Again we see the arrogance and ignorance of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and his advisers, when they tell the CRAA that its computers will be able to achieve this. Trust the outsiders to know better than the actual business!

The viability of the CRAA will be threatened by the $150,000 fines that will be levied upon breaches of the new, restrictive reporting conditions. It will be equally undermined by the removal of significant categories of current CRAA members. For no good reason of privacy protection, in effect, only the providers of personal loans will be permitted to remain with the CRAA. Utilities, real estate agents, insurance companies, collection agents and providers of trade credit will all be excluded from the CRAA, devaluing the database for its remaining users. Exclusion of utilities will make life easier for that many more delinquent debtors but ultimately, when Telecom's bad debts rise, low income Australians may find themselves paying substantial bonds that they can ill afford. Again and again, this is the end result of supposedly pro-consumer legislation that ignores commercial reality.

This bundle of face-saving amendments that has been brought in much after the event, supposedly to deal with delinquent debtors, does not alter the fact that this legislation makes life for such people that much easier and, accordingly, adds to the costs of business. Prevention of reporting a bad debt until it is 60 days overdue means, in effect, that the debtor has missed eight weekly payments before any action can be taken. That is just not satisfactory. Why are we going on and on with something like this? The Government and the Australian Democrats profess to look after those in need, yet when it comes to the crunch we know how they vote. Clearly, the Minister and his advisers are not interested in the testimony of one small business in the motor trade which, prior to joining the CRAA, employed 14 people, with bad debts running at 9 per cent of sales. Access to credit reporting through the Credit Reference Association of Australia has cut the bad debt rate to 2 per cent and enabled employment of seven additional employees, and that is what the Government and the Democrats want to wipe out. By removing and restricting access to the Credit Reference Association and by threatening the viability of the Association itself, this Labor Government is putting the jobs of employees in peril. One must recognise and consider that the Government has to live up to what it says is its concern for people in this country. Unless it looks at that aspect, the Government is just completely neglecting its responsibility to provide jobs and security for people.

Perhaps the worst example of the mischievous unreality of this Bill is the arbitrary separation of personal loans from commercial loans that in future can only be matched through a most restrictive process, which is unsatisfactory, and the drafters of this Bill can have no idea that thousands of small business enterprises are at least partially funded through personal loans. That is just a further example of how the Government has simply not understood what it is doing with this Bill. The Government does not understand how it impacts on the business sector; it does not understand obviously how it impacts on individuals; and it does not understand how the mischievous person can in fact benefit from this type of legislation. Indeed, one Australian family in seven operates some kind of a small business that may be funded by personal loans, and this Bill will prevent the easy verification of the personal guarantees of a company director-again only assisting the reckless and the dishonest.

Two industries in particular will be adversely affected by this Bill-real estate and credit unions. Neither can be described as big business, and in each case the end loser will be ordinary Australians. The Hawke-Keating Labor Government has not consulted with the real estate industry where, in the first 10 months of 1988-89, over 100,000 inquiries were made by real estate agents of the Credit Reference Association of Australia. Most real estate property in the residential area is owned by ordinary Australians, who require their assets to be safeguarded. But here we have a Bill that just throws that out the door. The Government does not care; the Australian Democrats do not care.

Quite frankly, I think people have a right to have their property safeguarded and, accordingly, real estate agents may need to check the creditworthiness of prospective tenants before a lease is signed. Again, we must ask whether this Government believes that no tenant ever commits fraud or misuses what is the property of another. From my own point of view, I would certainly want to know that an agent was adequately checking any tenants if they were going into my property to make sure that my property was being safeguarded. But no, the Government says that that is unimportant to this Bill.

Once the real estate industry is arbitrarily excluded from credit reporting, there will be some inevitable discrimination against potential tenants who are poor. The song of the Democrats and the Government is, `We've got to protect the poor, we must protect the poor', yet this Bill actively discriminates against the poor. Tenancies may not be available when there is no means of checking previous credit commitments, and queues for public housing will get longer. If the Government is prepared to allow the queues for public housing to get longer, then that in itself is very tragic. But once again the Government does not seem to care, because taxpayers' money is just to be thrown around. We get $36m thrown to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, we get money just thrown around to plug up the gaps before an election, and yet here we have a Bill that will actively discriminate against the poorer people in our society and the Government says, `That's okay'. I do not think it is okay.

When other cumbersome and possibly more intrusive checking methods must be used there will be longer delays in applications for tenancy, but once again the Government does not mind that. If we have more people thrown out into the streets, it will be because of this Bill. The greater uncertainty that will be injected into the rental market will result, of course, in higher bonds. Who does that discriminate against? People will have to request higher bonds if they cannot check the credit viability of tenants and, therefore, the poor are again going to be discriminated against.

If this Labor Government succeeds through this Bill in destroying the effectiveness of the Credit Reference Association of Australia, it will deal a massive blow to Australian credit unions, even though they are not excluded from the existing databank. The 406 members of the Australian Federation of Credit Unions, with 2.7 million members and $7.5 billion worth of assets, made 631,000 inquiries to the Credit Reference Association of Australia. All the consultation it got from this Government prior to the introduction of the Bill was a 40-minute meeting on 18 April. We know now that the Government has seen the light of day, but the problem is that it did not do so until after the Bill had been introduced. The Government does not bother consulting beforehand. The Government does it after it introduces the Bill-in the say way as the Government is now going to consult the pharmacists, after it has put in punitive regulations. This Government fails to appreciate that credit unions lend money at the high risk end of the market. With only the capital of their depositors, and no actual shareholders, increased bad debts and other costs can result only in lower returns to depositors and higher loan interest.

I cannot hear-and thank heavens, I might add-the interjections that are going on, although I anticipate that they would be as lunatic as this Bill, as lacking in care as this Bill and a further demonstration of exactly where the Democrats and the Government stand on these issues. This Bill will hamper people in being able to get access to credit and will discriminate against those who need it. If this Bill denies the suppliers of consumer credit necessary information in regard to the credit history of an applicant, it will prevent the directors of Western Australian credit unions from carrying out their obligations under the Western Australian Credit Union Act-to ensure that members can repay a loan before approval is given.

It is a bad joke for this Labor Government to claim that the Bill will have minimal cost impact on the credit industry, when the national cost to credit unions has been estimated at $62m. This includes $20m caused through new bad debts and the opportunity cost when loans are refused because creditworthiness cannot be checked. It includes $16m in bad debts that would today be detected at the monitoring stage, $14m through inability to collect existing, accumulated debts, and $12m in administrative costs. It has been estimated that an additional loans officer would be needed for every 250 credit union members, that 5 per cent of approved loan applications would be rejected, and that the recovery rate of bad debts will decline from 40 per cent to a mere 5 per cent.

This further demonstrates what the Government thinks of small business. The Government is prepared to dish out, as I said before, $36m to a company like Kodak and yet when it comes to the small business people who have a right to collect money, who have a responsibility to themselves and their staff to collect the money, the Government wants to throw a handful of ballbearings under their feet to prevent them from doing so. Senator Zakharov sits on the other side of the chamber this morning and shakes her head. I have not seen her get up in this place and explain how this Bill will prevent any of the things happening that I have been talking about here today. Senator Zakharov does not understand how the Bill will impact. Of course, Senator Powell has gone on at length about her so-called concerns-although they are intangible when they relate to this Bill-and yet the Democrats nail their flag to the mast. We know where they stand.

The estimates of the decline and the collection of bad debts predict a lot of heartache for a lot of Australians. With these extra costs pushing up the interest rates for honest consumers, there is even a suggestion that credit unions will have to abandon consumer loans altogether, which will be a disaster for thousands of individuals. It is interesting that Senator Zakharov and Senator Powell have been burbling on in this place today with huge doses of verbal diarrhoea. I do not know why, on the last day of this sitting, they have suddenly come to life with rot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Minister?

—That is a very good question. Where is Senator Bolkus? He has ducked for cover. The Government does not think that people are concerned, yet full page advertisements prove people's concern. An advertisement in the Canberra Times on Wednesday, 20 December 1989 lists a number of groups expressing concern: the Advertising Federation of Australia Ltd, the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia, the Business Council of Australia, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry South Australia Ltd, the Confederation of Australian Industry, and the Employers Federation of New South Wales. Yet Government senators in this place huff and puff and do not care about this expression of concern. The list also includes the retail traders associations, the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (Inc.) Western Australia, and the Trustee Companies Association of Australia. The Government does not care. The Democrats, of course, could not care less about anything other than making promises to try to win seats: promises that they will never have to keep because, let us remember-and thank heavens for Australia-they will never be in government to deliver them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another full page advertisement in the following day's newspaper, on 21 December. That particular advertisement is very interesting because it asks seven questions. I will read those seven questions because they sum up the concerns of the coalition about this Bill. The advertisement states:

Debate on this Bill has been accelerated to the last week before Christmas. As you approach the issues involved, the Credit Reporting Forum would ask you to take into account your own answers to the following 7 questions.
Senator Zakharov interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov can save her breath because, fortunately, I cannot hear her, and that is a blessing. The advertisement continues as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Why have several Labor and Coalition State Governments plus over 50 national and State industry and professional bodies, as well as responsible government departments, urged that this Bill be withdrawn?

2. Why in June did Senator Bolkus advise the Senate that the cost to the community of this legislation would be `minimal', when in May his own proponents of the Bill told him consumers would pay higher charges and higher interest rates because of it?

3. Why does Senator Bolkus continue to disparage the only economic impact study of the Bill, when even after his many changes, the independent consultants have confirmed that a conservative estimate of its cost to the community is in the order of $1.3 billion to $2.4 billion per year?

4. Why was the original Bill rushed into the Senate in the last days of the Autumn Session and why is debate on the latest version, with its already 40 plus amendments, being rushed in the last days of the Budget Session?
5. What is wrong with the industry sponsored alternatives?
6. Exactly how will this Bill protect privacy?
7. Why is the Parliament being rushed into protecting frauds and cheats at the expense of the less well-off?

Those seven questions have not been answered, and it will be interesting to see whether Senator Bolkus-whenever he turns up-answers those questions. I guarantee he will not. This is not a pro-privacy Bill; it is an anti-business and anti-consumer Bill. It should be returned for a thorough redrafting in accordance with commercial reality and the real world generally. I hope that the Government will have a better look at this Bill because it will be putting the noose around many necks in the provision of credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add some remarks to the second reading debate on the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989. In doing so, I support Senator Hill's amendment to the motion for the second reading. In particular, I support his statement that the Opposition will oppose the second reading of this Bill, and what it stands for, tooth and nail.

SPEECH.PARA: One or two speakers-particularly the Australian Democrats, in their usual light-fingered way-have had the impertinence to question the Opposition's bona fides in opposing this Bill by asserting that the Opposition has no regard for privacy. I remind the chamber-and I would remind the Democrats, if I saw any point in doing so, that their forgettery, as my grandmother would have said, is working overtime as it always does-that it was the Opposition which, during the debate on the tax file number legislation last year, forcibly reminded the Government that despite repeated promises from the Government, including the Minister now in the chamber, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, to introduce privacy legislation, no such legislation had been forthcoming. We made it clear that we would not pass the tax file number legislation without accompanying privacy legislation and finally forced the Privacy Act out of a reluctant government. I have to say-because we, at least, tell the truth in this place, unlike some others-that we received the support of the Australian Democrats in pursuing the enactment of privacy legislation at that time. It is disgraceful that last night Senator Powell attempted to suggest that the coalition parties have had no regard for privacy. Without the coalition parties there would be no principal Act to be amended by this Bill.

I pick up a comment made by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, yesterday in a somewhat different context, when the Democrats were off on one of their usual rampages over the political landscape. Senator Ray rather sapiently observed that conservation is becoming the last refuge of the scoundrel in political debate in this country. That was a very apt comment on Senator Ray's part, and one with which I totally agree. All I say is that if this Bill is carried, with the support of the Australian Democrats, privacy will have become the last refuge of the scoundrel because the chief beneficiaries of this Bill will be scoundrels. I suppose it is not surprising that the Bill's chief proponents in this place are also scoundrels.

The history of the Bill is that it was introduced during the dying days of the last session of the Senate, on 16 June this year, by the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus. It had been the subject of no prior consultation with any industry-least of all the credit reference reporting industry, or any of the other industries likely to be affected by the Bill-yet it is a major piece of legislation which will undoubtedly seriously damage the livelihoods of all those industries. There was a suggestion at the time that the Bill had been drafted in the Minister's private office, firstly, because it was so badly drafted and, secondly because it was such an obviously ideologically motivated Bill that it was hard to believe that it could have been exposed to the legislative processes of the Cabinet committees.

I leave that suggestion aside and go on to consider the further history of the Bill. The objections began to emerge and Senator Bolkus had, or was forced to have, some second thoughts. Senator Bolkus's second thoughts are rarely any better than his first thoughts; nevertheless he was forced to have some. Now we have a Bill which contains 41 amendments to the original piece of legislation. What could more eloquently testify the shoddiness of the administrative and ministerial processes leading to the introduction of this legislation in the first place? Senator Bolkus, as a Minister of the Crown, ought to be ashamed of himself for bringing forward a piece of legislation so fundamentally flawed in the first place which required 41 amendments within a month or so of it having been presented.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what happens when you are election driven.

—I will come back to that point. The fact is that if we reach the committee stage of this Bill the Opposition will have no fewer than 35 amendments to the Bill as it now stands. I have to say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this Bill is one element in a mosaic or pattern of behaviour from this Government to which we have appallingly become only too used. We have had a pattern of behaviour from this Government of being anti-small business and also, I should say, totally prepared to introduce the most repressive legislation. The Government talks all the time about civil liberties, human rights, freedom of the individual and privacy. Yet everything it does, whether designed to do so or not, has the effect of reducing and harming all those highly desirable principles or objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking first of all a general matter, before I come to more particular ones, we have the Government's unidirectional economic policy, based wholly increasingly, and indeed now crushingly, on high interest rates. That, of course, is affecting all business, not merely small business. It is not hard to understand that small business is much more adversely affected by this than the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltds of this world or the other major companies with whose chief executives the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was wont to spend so much time before they became a bit sick of the sight of him in recent months. Our economic environment is crushing small business. We will hear a lot more about that as we enter 1990 and as people start to go belly up around this economy and bankruptcies start to soar.

Turning to some particulars, we have the Government's absolutely unpardonable attack on the pharmacists led, I should say, by a factional colleague of Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, who is from the same stable. That Minister has put out the most offensive material to Australian Labor Party electorate officers, advising them how to talk to their constituents about the pharmacists. They are advised-we know this because we have had papers tabled both in the Senate and in the other place-to describe pharmacists as greedy and stupid, and other epithets of that kind. We know what Minister Staples and this Government think of pharmacists-a fairly significant element in the small business community. There is not the slightest shadow of doubt about it; it is on the record.

I do not have time to go through the totality of the pharmacists dispute, but that is a saga in itself as far as small business in this country is concerned. I might add that it is a saga in itself as to the manner in which this Government goes about its shoddy dealings with the business community. Most recently we had the Prime Minister's rather more venal attempt than usual to buy off the pharmacists by having the Remuneration Tribunal back off its original position and offer to bring down a new award if only the pharmacists would stop politically campaigning against the Government. That is a subject in itself. If we had more time to debate these matters in this place it would be worthy of significant investigation by the Senate. I am referring to the behaviour of this so-called independent tribunal, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, but again I will not pause long on that point.

Next we have the tourism industry. It is a quintessential small business industry if ever there was one which has been hit to leg all over the country, but particularly in States such as Tasmania and Queensland, and to a lesser extent perhaps Western Australia, by the effects of the pilots dispute. This is a dispute which has been prolonged, and is being prolonged to this day, as a result of the initially inflammatory actions and statements by that once great conciliator, the Prime Minister, Mr Robert James Lee Hawke. Again, we have had that same man attempting to back off the consequences of his own actions a week or two ago by saying that the last thing he as an ex-trade unionist would have wanted to do would be to set out to crush a trade union. I am afraid that, as is so often the case with the Prime Minister, actions speak, and will continue to speak, much louder than words. The point of relevance is that here again some parts of the tourism industry have been crushed and otherwise financially damaged by effects directly induced by this Government.

Recently in this place we saw the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 5) which, as you will recall Mr Acting Deputy President, originally, when it was announced on 15 August in the Budget, set out to bring forward the payment of all company taxes payable by companies with tax liabilities of more than $1,000-that is even tiny shelf companies basically; in other words no real company. Every what I call `real' company was being forced to bring forward its tax payment to not more than 15 days after the end of its financial year, or at least as to 85 per cent of its tax liability within that time. The Government had a succession of back-offs from that under the pressure brought to bear upon it by a combination of the business community and the Opposition. We now have a situation where for the forthcoming transitional year the Government has significantly amended that.

Nevertheless, I make the point in passing that once again the chief elements adversely affected by that Bill in the community would have been-and indeed in the year beyond the transitional year-and will continue to be the small business community. As you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am pursuing the theme that this Government's actions consistently and persistently are directed to smashing small business. Of course, that is not surprising because small business is made of individuals. If there is one thing the Labor Party hates, it is individuals. Notwithstanding all the tripe it goes on talking about-civil liberties and respect for human rights and freedoms and individuals-by its actions it continues to repress individualism. That is a theme again in itself which one has not time for this morning.

Now we have this piece of legislation. Honourable senators should look at the effect on the real estate industry particularly, if I may say so, those involved in lettings and management of residential property. I happen to reside in an area on the Sunshine Coast of Queensland which is a significant tourism and holiday area. A lot of properties are let in that area to people, not merely at this time of year, although particularly now, who are itinerants. They come there for a few weeks and they go away again. Sometimes they go there for more than a few weeks. I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that certainly real estate agents who have that kind of business in my area regard themselves as being potentially very much affected by this legislation. They are bitterly hostile towards it.

What we have had from this Minister in relation to this Bill is a pattern of arrogance on the one hand and ignorance on the other-arrogance in the sense of total lack of prior consultation before the Bill was introduced, which I have already referred to. Now it has some amendments, amendments which leave the Bill still fundamentally unsatisfactory. We have had reasoned arguments so far as I can judge them being presented to the Minister by bodies such as the Credit Reporting Forum and its constituents. Last night Senator Powell had the impertinence, the absolute gall, to claim that the Credit Reporting Forum had provided no alternatives. She actually quoted from a full-page advertisement in yesterday's newspapers in which the Credit Reporting Forum had asked, as one of the questions which I think were referred to earlier by Senator Knowles, what is wrong with the industry-sponsored alternatives to the Bill. I should make it clear in passing, in case it is not clear to some members of the Senate, that the Credit Reporting Forum and its affiliated bodies are not in the least objecting to due consideration being paid to people's privacy. On the contrary, they would support that, as the coalition and I certainly would. They are saying that this Bill, as drawn, is totally inappropriate to achieve its purpose while maintaining a balance with the proper commercial interests of those whose businesses it will affect. But, as I say, Senator Powell got up here in the Senate last night, quoted that passage from the advertisement and had the impertinence to claim `We've had discussions with these people, and at no time have we ever seen an alternative. There are no alternatives. We had no alternative put to us'.

I happen to know something about the facts of that matter. I have in front of me a Credit Reporting Forum document on the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989. It concerns policy appraisal and alternative legislative models and is dated August 1989. I am assured-and I have no reason whatsoever to doubt the assurance-that this document was presented to Senator Powell and the Democrats in either late August or early September of this year. Senator Powell came in here last night and said there are no alternatives. This document sets out two quite specific alternatives. She may not think the alternatives are worthwhile or that they are good as the Government's Bill. If so, then she is perfectly entitled to that view and entitled to express it. But she has come in here and misled the Senate, I presume inadvertently, by in effect questioning the integrity and the bona fides of the Credit Reporting Forum by saying that the question is not based upon any fact-in other words, that there are no alternatives and therefore the Credit Reporting Forum is effectively acting as a dishonest body by including that question in its advertisement. That action on the part of Senator Powell itself verges upon a lack of integrity. I hope that Senator Powell will have the personal integrity to come back into the Senate later-if she has an opportunity-and withdraw or at least seek leave of the Senate to withdraw that comment. I would be very interested to see whether she has the backbone to do so. I would not like to bet on it, but I hope she will.

The document I have just referred to from the Credit Reporting Forum is a very interesting and very balanced document. For example, the second paragraph of the document starts with a statement about the rationale for what are basically credit reference facilities. It says:
The community in general benefits when certain commercial decisions are able to be based in whole or in part on objective-
note that word `objective'-
personal financial information that is relevant-
again, that is an important word-
to those decisions. Reasonable access by commercial organisations to personal financial information is important in the following areas . . .

Those areas included financial and insurance fraud; the control of overcommitment and bad debts; reducing costs to the community that would flow from inappropriate and preventable commercial decisions; ensuring that commercial decisions affecting individuals are as far as possible fair and objective; and so on. At a later point the document moves on to the question of an alternative approach and sets out what I think is an admirable statement of aim or of principle. Paragraph 5.2 of the document states:
Drawing on the information privacy principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988-
that is the Act I referred to in my earlier remarks when I was rebutting or rejecting the infamous allegation by Senator Powell here last night that the Opposition has no regard for privacy-
and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the foundation for legislation in this area should be directed to dealing with `arbitrary or unlawful interference'-
because those are the terms of the International Covenant-
with an individual's privacy.
But it goes on to say:
The privacy rights in the Covenant are not absolute.

Of course they are not absolute because privacy cannot be an absolute requirement; if it were we would not be able to investigate the murder of somebody because we would be violating the murderer's privacy. There has to be a balance in these things, as always. The Forum goes on to say in this document:
The very terms and expressions used in the Covenant themselves point to the necessity for a given context and for measured and reasonable control by the individual.
In paragraph 5.3 the Forum says:

Therefore we believe that the principles upon which legislation should be drawn are (1) to prevent arbitrary and unlawful interference with individuals' privacy by enhancing the opportunity for greater control and awareness by them of both personal information held in their name and access to that information-
I would have thought that was a totally undeniable principle, but here is the balancing point-
and (2) to balance this imperative-
I think `imperative' is a very good word in that context-

with commercial interests consistent with fair trading and trade practices principles by ensuring that credit referencing is not misleading or inaccurate and that legislation does not have unintended anti-competitive consequences.

I think it might almost have said unintended anti-competitive and other consequences but I leave that point aside. What really are the gripes in this area? What is supposed to have led to the appearance of this Bill in the first place? I found it very difficult indeed to ascertain what the gripes are or are supposed to have been. I have had some discussion on the matter particularly with real estate agents in my own area and they tell me that there is a very close correlation between past non-payment for items purchased on credit and non-payment of rent. They have drawn my attention to a survey of five real estate agencies which was presented to the New South Wales Privacy Committee in 1986 and which showed that 56 per cent of defaulting tenants with those agencies had a prior history of credit default.

The Real Estate Institute of Australia-again people have drawn my attention to this-has estimated that since the late 1960s over 1 1/2 million inquiries have been made to credit referencing agencies by estate agents on behalf of property owners. Senator Bolkus has found it difficult to point to one single example of abuse of this information by a real estate agent. I do not say he cannot point to one or two-he probably can; there will always be some. But the idea that we should therefore go and shoot every fish in the barrel is nonsense. It is a typical example of this Government's approach to the world.

But as I said in quoting from that document a moment ago, there will undoubtedly be a number of unintended consequences-at least I take them to be unintended-from this legislation should it come into law. Senator Michael Baume, in his remarks here last night, drew attention to some representations he had received from the Illawarra Credit Union Ltd, which, as he said, is not a gilt-edged, high-flying, financial, money market dealing body but a credit union-the poor man's bank, as he quite rightly referred to it-from an area which is not notable as being at the top end of town. The clear view of the credit union was that this legislation, if passed into law, would have serious adverse effects on what it called the lower socioeconomic groups.

Of course, the Democrats do not care about that but they have never had any concern for lower socioeconomic groups. They are always chasing after their middle class trendy vote-people who have no contact with what the sociologists call the lower socioeconomic groups-and their new class supporters. I have to say that the Labor Party does not care about those people. We have seen that demonstrated again and again in by-elections in this country during this year, with a revolt against the Labor Party in electorates like Oxley, Adelaide, Port Adelaide and so on-a demonstration that the Labor Party is out of touch with its own roots and that it, too, has been to a large degree captured by the new class of supporters: the Public Service trade union organisers, the lawyers for Labor and other such luminaries.

We are going to find as one of the unintended consequences of the passage of this Bill that the incidence of fraud will certainly increase-which other honourable senators from this side have spoken about-when dishonest tenants learn that they can move from one property to another without details of their non-payment of rent and/or damage to property being recorded and accessible to new and unsuspecting people renting property to them. Of course, one consequence of that will inevitably be that persons renting property will be much less willing to do so to tenants who cannot produce impeccable references. Again, what the Illawarra Credit Union calls the lower socioeconomic groups, because they will not be able to produce those impeccable references, will simply find themselves either unable or much less able to get tenancies than they can today. No doubt more people will go on to the public housing rolls. This will be an unintended consequence on the part of this Government and will add to the list of the new poor which the Labor Party has created. Alternatively, persons renting property will simply load rentals generally as a form of insurance against default.

The fact is that like most such politically motivated do-gooding exercises-if they can even be called by that dignified phrase-this legislation, if passed, will have major unintended consequences. Small business-real estate agents in particular-will be disrupted and disadvantaged in the access to and extension of credit on which its operations are based. Consumers, especially in the lower income group, will be significantly disadvantaged while costs to the services provided will be increased because of the extra risks involved in providing them. Senator Bolkus and his colleagues believe they are the only ones in step. I am glad to see the Minister has finally come in to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been here all morning.

—The Minister has not been here. He scurried into the chamber late last night in the hope that we could have some more discussion about his terrible Bill, but apart from that I have hardly seen him, and I have been in the chamber for a good deal more of the second reading debate than Senator Bolkus. A Minister who does not even have the decency to sit in the chamber and monitor the second reading debate on his own Bill, I think, leaves something to be desired as a Minister.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I have put up with a fair degree of abuse from this little man. In terms of being here last night, I was in or just outside this chamber during most of the debate last night and this morning. I have put up with this rubbish for about half an hour.
—Order! Senator Bolkus will resume his seat. There is no point of order, and it is not appropriate for senators to speak out of order in such a way.

—Senator Bolkus and the Australian Democrats-as one would expect for the reasons I have already given-are in step on this Bill, yet there is a list of organisations opposing this Bill. A full-page advertisement on 20 December lists 45 bodies. They have already been referred to at some length by other honourable senators and I do not have time in any case to list them. But let me look at some of them: the Insurance Agents Association of Australia, the Media Council of Australia, the Small Business People's Movement and the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies. These are respectable bodies and are not to be held in contempt by the Government, but the fact is that Senator Bolkus believes he is the only one in step. I suspect that even his Cabinet colleagues do not understand what he is doing and if they did they would not let him. In conclusion, nothing will do the Labor Party more damage than this Bill being passed. In that case, perhaps I should not be opposing the Bill. Nevertheless, I do oppose the Bill, and I conclude my remarks on that note.

—I hope that the Government will recognise a number of the points that have been raised during the second reading debate and a number of the further representations that have been made to it. My view is that the Privacy Amendment Bill does require amendment, and my hope is that the Government will see its way clear to further amend the Bill to take account of those points that have been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In raising my point of order earlier I made some comments about Senator Stone. Suffice it to say that, when the big decisions were made in Australia over the last seven years when Senator Stone was in a position of responsibility-when the dollar was floated, for instance-he slept through them. Australia has had to progress despite the attitudes and vitriol of people like Senator Stone, and I for one am glad that he is in the Senate because it keeps him out of the Department of Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry to say that this has been one of the most disappointing second reading debates that this Parliament has seen. It has been disappointing because of the degree of misinformation that has been relayed to the Senate by the Opposition. It is disappointing that all the Opposition has chosen to do is repeat unfounded misinformation fielded by one sector of the credit industry, and I say one sector because major parts of industry have had direct, continuing and fruitful discussions with government which the Opposition has chosen to ignore.
