I think that is a symptom of the problem that Australia faces today. The Opposition will forever be the sideshow if it continues to play with the sideshow operators.

As I say, it has been a campaign of misinformation, harassment and, in some cases, direct political blackmail. It has been a hypocritical campaign based, on the one hand, on mouthing platitudes in support of privacy and, on the other hand, on running very hard on a secret agenda. These angels of privacy, the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA), as Senator Stone in his new-found wisdom in the area refers to them, for instance, have said:

Privacy is a genuine concern for the community. Government and Opposition parties will not be easily persuaded to reject privacy oriented legislation. Accordingly, they will only respond to a massive and insistent demonstration from all elements of industry affected that, in the community interests, the Bolkus legislation is totally unacceptable.
That is a stark demonstration of the mouthing of platitudes but with a distinctly secret agenda. Angels they are not, I point out to Senator Stone; evil angels they may very well be.

I mentioned blackmail-and I do not mention that word all that lightly, either. For instance, there was the move by CRAA, the Opposition's sponsors in this debate, on 22 November 1989 to switch off access to its database to motor vehicle dealers because, as it claimed, of the effect of the Privacy Bill-a Bill that at that stage had not even been debated here. The CRAA conceded to the Motor Traders Association of Australia (MTAA) that the CRAA had deliberately taken such precipitate action in order to influence the outcome of a meeting between the CRAA and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The CRAA found the MTAA's satisfaction with the Government's assurances as to its members' interests unacceptable to its political cause. It turned off access, which consequently had a financial impact on its members. Is it any wonder that the Motor Traders Association has called this `the most outrageously blatant piece of political blackmail by a self-interested group against Government policy of which we have heard'? Is it any wonder that MTAA members are contemplating legal proceedings? Yet the Opposition has taken the position, the side, of this organisation hook, line and sinker.

I mentioned misinformation, and we have seen some great examples over the last three days. Two days ago we found this often quoted advertisement-one that has been presented by the Opposition which, once again, has been sucked in-claiming that a member of the Australian Privacy Foundation had stated that the Bill would force interest rates up. He said no such thing. The statement was a statement of principle, made as a member of another organisation before the Bill was even introduced or considered. The statement has no relevance to the Bill and does not reflect on the Bill at all, but it is quoted consistently by those suckers on the other side of the chambers as a judgment on the Bill.

The misinformation continued yesterday on the issue of the cost of the legislation. I was asked in a full page advertisement why I continued to disparage the only economic impact study of the Bill when, even after many changes, the independent consultants have confirmed that a conservative estimate of its cost to the community is in the order of $1.36 billion to $2.4 billion per year. The answer is very simple. The study has no relevance, nor does it have any credibility. For instance, the Chairman of the Credit Reporting Forum, Mr Graham Laughlin, said on 22 August:
The existing criticisms of the Bill had become purely hypothetical in view of the proposed amendments.

Yesterday we had a continuation of the big lie. We were told that, in essence, there has been another study since the amendments. What is the truth about this economic assessment, this other study? What is the truth about the first study as well? The author, the consultant, has told us the following about the study: firstly, he had not reconsidered his economic assessment after the amendments, nor had he studied the amendments. Secondly, originally he had been given 2 1/2 weeks to prepare his report but it took just a little longer. Thirdly, he said that his figures `came together on the last day'. So that is why I disparage a report like that and that is why I would expect other people in this Parliament to do the same. There has not been, as claimed, a reassessment. The initial assessment is hypothetical crap. It is irrelevant; it is shoddy; and even the initial figures in it are superficial. That is why I will continue to disparage it and that is why economic progress in this country would be better off if Opposition senators made a closer analysis of documents such as that.

As I have said, members of the Opposition have fallen behind this irresponsible campaign of misinformation to the extent that all the amendments that they had circulated up to yesterday, word for word and line for line, but for two minor exceptions, were the amendments of the CRAA. In the interests of honest information in this place I will table those amendments so that honourable senators opposite can match them word for word with their amendments. The pretence of defenders of privacy on the other side is well and truly just a pretence. They come in here with--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I know that it is a stressful time as we approach Christmas; nevertheless, surely some decorum should be maintained in this chamber. A moment or two ago the Minister was referring to certain matters as `crap'. We now see him tabling a document but, instead of doing that, he has thrown it across the chamber. Is there some way in which you could bring him to order and ask him to behave in a way that is more in accord with the standards that some of us try to maintain in this place?

—Speaking to the point of order: if we are to establish standards in this place they ought to be to do as we do ourselves and not as we would like others to do. If the standards the honourable senator is seeking to apply are to apply to those on this side of the chamber, I ask him to institute those standards first on his side of the chamber-and for honourable senators opposite to exercise some self-control themselves.

—What Senator McKiernan has said is certainly correct; there are the same requirements for all honourable senators. On the point that Senator Hill raised, the unparliamentary language that honourable senators use is a reflection upon those honourable senators, but the throwing of papers in this chamber is disorderly. I thank Senator Hill for bringing that point to my attention and I ask Senator Bolkus to apologise to the chamber.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise unreservedly. However, I make the comment that, in the interests of fair and open public debate, one should go through those amendments and see where they come from. We have been told for weeks now that the Opposition has been in a closed room working out its amendments to this Bill. Mr N. A. Brown, the Opposition spokesman, is supposed to be closed up somewhere in his private room working out the amendments. We went through them the other night and we discovered that, word for word, they were amendments that had been presented to the Government before. So let us put an end to the pretence that the Opposition has any interest in a fair and balanced approach to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told that there has been a lack of consultation; I think Senator Hill made that point at the start of his speech. On the day the first Bill was issued-in fact even before that-I met with Mr Brown and on the day amendments were issued I met and consulted with him. There has been continuing consultation with Mr Brown on this issue as he is the relevant person in this area. For instance, I do not think Senator Hill even looked at the amendments until some time yesterday. Mr Brown, as the appropriate spokesperson, had been consulted.

We have been told there have not been consultations with industry. Consultations have been going on in this area for about seven months before and after the introduction of the Bill, about the principles of the Bill and the sorts of things that we are going to do. But I must say that we have been misled. Take, for instance, one of the important issues that has been raised by the Opposition concerning who should have access to credit files. There is some claim that anyone in the commercial sector should have access to credit files. On 19 April in a public meeting I asked Mr Bargon of the CRAA what we should do with insurance companies, government departments, real estate agents and rental companies. He said, `I am happy to see legislation stamp them out, even in circumstances where a finance company is related to the real estate function'. We have had consultations in this area, but sometimes it is like dancing on quicksand and that is why the consultations have gone on for quite some time. In fact, we have consulted widely. We have consulted with the Australian Bankers Association, credit unions, mortgage insurers, the Australian Finance Conference Ltd, and the list goes on. In fact I can quote from one of quite a number of letters that we have received. Mr Richard Thomas, Director of Corporate Affairs, Coles Myer Ltd, in a letter dated 5 September states:

. . . on behalf of Coles Myer Ltd and its associate company, Australian Retail Financial Network Ltd, I wish to thank you for the obvious efforts you have made to accommodate industry concerns with the legislation. It is evident in the amendments you have put forward that you have genuinely sought to overcome some of the major problems identified by the credit industry . . . and to satisfy the interest of both credit providers and their customers.
Let us not have this continual claptrap that we get from the other side. I keep saying that, if Opposition senators keep playing on the sideshow, they will stay there.

We have come forward with 41 amendments which relate to six major areas. Let us just go to two of those areas since we are talking about consultations. At the start of this debate we were presented with a proposed code of operation from the CRAA. Under that code it was suggested that there be a 90-day period before defaults could be logged. I accepted that and adopted it in good faith. In the normal way in which this game has been played by the Opposition's sponsors they then came out and criticised us. A lot of the amendments go very much to that point. Amendments have been put up and accepted by the Government, but the quicksand has changed. Not only did we reduce the 90-day period to 60 days but also we have accommodated earlier registration of serious credit infringements.

The commercial consumer distinction was made very clear to us. In fact, when I put it to Opposition senators that Neil Brown, the shadow Attorney-General, was thinking of bringing commercial files under the ambit of the Act, they said, `No'. What do we get from the other side now? The amendments cover four other major areas. We should not be blinded by the number of amendments; we should just look at the number of pivotal areas that have been mentioned.

The Government has adopted a serious consultative process in this area which I think has led to some quite productive outcomes. Not only have we had to dance on quicksand with industry in this area but also the history of politics and privacy in this country indicates that we have had the same sort of problem when dealing with members of the Opposition. Nowhere has this become more difficult in recent years than in negotiating with the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown.

Two major underlying themes have been raised by the Opposition. The first is who has access and the second is what information should be made available. In the normal way that the Opposition handles business these days we had to contend with different spokespeople. Mr Brown had charge of the shadow portfolio and lost it, Mr Moore took it over and lost it and Mr Brown then got in back. So there has been difficulty in getting a coherent line from the Opposition in this area, not only between spokespeople but also from each one. Mr Brown, in his first press statement to do with this area, said that there need to be clear rules about who should have access to this information. He then said:
Many Australians are . . . doubly worried about who will have access to it and what guarantees there will be that it remains confidential.
That is not the only thing he said. He continued:
There must be clear rules laid down on-what may be recorded; by whom; who will have access to it; and the individual's right to have access to his or her own records and to correct mistakes.
He said that the information should be available only to those who are involved in granting credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what date was that?

—I have his press release here. It is dated 17 May 1989. However, it did not stop there because by 29 August someone had sat on him. From sensible decisions about granting credit the criterion changed to `sensible commercial decisions'. Blow it out; no decisions necessary about who was appropriate to have access to these files and who was not. Blow it right out: Mr Brown had been sat on. There have been many speeches on the other side about information on file. In fact, the debate has been so incoherent that if I were sponsoring the Opposition I would be embarrassed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sheil said yesterday evening that what was going on was terrible because he had received amendments circulated that afternoon which were highly unintelligible. They were the Opposition's amendments. They were the only amendments circulated yesterday afternoon. That is the degree of support that the Opposition's sponsors are getting. Mr Moore also put out a press statement in respect of the information that should go on file. One cannot stop John Moore issuing press statements. In his press statement he said; `Only credit information'. What do we have now? Open slather and dancing on quicksand by the Opposition.

The Government's position is quite clear. It has been adopted in the main Act and in the Bill. Information will be used for the purpose for which it is collected. In this case we talking about the credit industry. There has been a litany of evidence over the years of the necessity both domestically and internationally within Australia to ensure that that principle is maintained. That is not where the errors end. Senator Hill told us that insurance companies will no longer have access to insurance claim files. I can understand why he would believe that; the insurance sector was told that. Anyone who reads the Bill would know that that is not true. Insurance companies can continue to have access to the separate insurance claims file which is pivotal in seeking out fraud. They continue to have access to that. We will debate the matter of the credit files later on.

In regard to what Senator Hill has said, there is evidence from a major company in Australia that when it does its fraud assessment in its bigger than Costigan computer system and gets its tally sheets up, credit reference records do not rate a mention. The most important part of its operation is claims files. Yet the efficacy of the current system has been mouthed by the Opposition. Let us see what other people say about the evil angels, the Opposition's sponsors. I will not mention every commentator in the country, particularly over the last five months, who has praised the Government for taking this position. In 1983 the senior research officer for the New South Wales Privacy Committee stated:

From the standpoint of providing adequate protection to consumers without undue hindrance to the process of credit reporting, the Voluntary Agreement must be judged a failure. The kinds of credit reporting problems encountered by consumers are serious and persistent. The protection afforded by the Agreement is piecemeal and unreliable. Most notably the Agreement has failed as an example of self-regulation. Whether through ignorance, conscious determination, or lack of awareness of the Agreement's importance, credit grantors in large numbers are failing to comply with its terms.

Let us acknowledge that the people sponsoring those opposite may not be playing the game properly. I mentioned earlier the instance of default and the business and commercial distinction. Many on the other side have made the point that we will not be allowed to use personal files for assessing business cheques and vice versa. The amendments accommodate that. A better reading of the Bill might have brought that to the attention of members of the Opposition. We have also been told that the penalties are too high. Once again, in an earlier press statement, Mr Moore did not think so; he thought they were appropriate. Those on the other side are inconsistent and that is why we have consulted more widely than just talking to them and their sponsors.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about real estate?

—Someone asked me last night whether I had owned a house or rented one. I have done both. This legislation goes very much to the heart of fixing a problem. We have been given misinformation by the other side. As I say, there has been a campaign of lies and, as quoted by industry sources, political blackmail. Quite a number of groups have been misled. For a number of months we have had letters from credit unions and building societies telling us that they would be denied access to credit files. In reality, even the initial Bill made specific reference to those two organisations maintaining a reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already instanced quite a number of areas on which we have had misinformation. I will briefly refer to real estate agents. In reality, the Government's position is that it is talking about rental information, not credit information. There have been major disadvantages when rental information has been used on credit files, and credit information has been used for assessing rental. As I keep saying-I think Senator Powell made this point the other night-if the information is so good, why are only 655 out of 9,000 registered real estate agents in Australia using it? I have consulted very widely with a number of them, and I do not agree with the organisation.

In closing this second reading debate, let me say I have had disappointed. I think the public should be disappointed. Very early in the piece I found that in order to get good legislation we would have to consult very widely, and that is what we have done. We have been quite accommodating. Some people have had an ideological fixation against legislation and regulation in this area. A hell of a lot of people want this area cleaned up once and for all. They realise that the only way it can be done is by enacting effective national legislation. They recognise the importance of this Bill.

To go back to the point on which I started, the way in which members of the Opposition have been sucked in in this area has been disappointing. They should go out and consult widely. As I have demonstrated this afternoon, one benchmark of the campaign against us in this area is the so-called consultant's report. By his own words, the consultant has blown that out of the water, and he has exposed some of the players in this campaign of lies, misinformation and blackmail as the real culprits. The Government recognises that the way things are going we will not get this legislation through today. We also acknowledge that the getting of this legislation so far, against the wishes of members of the Opposition, in this last week of filibustering, has been vitally important. They can be sure that we will see them in February.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.
Referral to Standing Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 196a I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

It seems to us that this is now the only sensible way to deal with this Bill and the many amendments concerning it that are before the chamber. I remind the Senate that the history of the matter is that the Government introduced the Bill, without consultation with the industry, and then found it to be unworkable. It then came back to this chamber with 41 amendments which substantially altered the Bill so that on any reasonable consideration of it one would have to say that it was a new Bill. Instead of taking our advice and withdrawing its first Bill, consolidating it with its afterthoughts and presenting to this chamber a workable document, the Government determined to go ahead with its 41 extra amendments.

The matter is complex-there is no doubt about that-and so much so that in order to do our job properly it will be necessary for us to move another 42 amendments in the committee stage. That puts the number of amendments up over 80. In addition, we learn that the Government itself will bring before us another batch of amendments. When the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) refers to amendments circulated yesterday, the chances are that he is referring to his latest amendments. When one adds to that the amendments of the Australian Democrats one finds a shambles, and an inappropriate way in which to deal with a complex Bill of this nature.

We have seen the alternatives adopted in this chamber: firstly, the occasions when Bills of this nature have gone to a committee, been dealt with properly and have come back here in an orderly way and, secondly, the occasions when the Government-through stubbornness or for some other reason-has determined not to do that and has made the process in this place a long and difficult debate, the ultimate result of which is legislation of not the same quality as if the Government had used the committee process. We have just had a debate in this chamber about the importance of using the Senate standing committee process to improve the quality of legislation where Bills are complex and where there are a considerable number of amendments. I doubt whether in the history of this place there have been many Bills before this chamber to which there have been nearly 100 amendments to be debated. I remind the chamber-I probably do not need to-that this is the last working day, at least for civilised people, before Christmas.

It is not as though there is a great difference in principle. In this instance the industry concerned, which was denigrated by the Minister this morning, supports legislation in relation to credit reports because it has had to carry on its business in areas of uncertainty. It wants its position and obligations with regard to privacy clarified. That is fair enough. The Government has said that it wants legislation to govern privacy in relation to credit reports; the Australian Democrats have said that they want similar legislation; and the Opposition has said that it supports legislation to govern credit reports. The differences are in the detail, and there are enormous differences in the detail. That is the debate that the Minister would have us go into now.

There is no critical urgency in relation to this matter. Obviously it is in everyone's best interests that it be dealt with expeditiously, but there is no critical urgency. The Government sold the furphy-the Minister sold the furphy in the beginning-that there was an urgency because the industry was about to introduce positive reporting. That was simply not the case. That is not the question that we have before us. All the parties agree that positive reporting is not in the best interests of sound legislative practice in this area, so what we are talking about is a negative reporting regime. Therefore, there is no urgency. The industry has been in operation for a long time. The day-to-day operations of an enormous number of Australian businesses are involved. The records are there. As much as a regulatory regime is necessary, it needs to be imposed in an orderly and sensible way, with adequate consultation with industry and commerce that are so vitally dependent upon it.

There is no critical urgency. What better process could be adopted by this chamber than in the first part of next year its Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs being given the task-I do not know whether it will embrace it with great enthusiasm-of working through the 100 amendments that are about to be debated in this chamber, putting them in order, finding ways in which they might be consolidated, settling the differences of argument, listening to business and commerce which wish to put points of view and ensuring that their views are, in fact, properly brought to the chamber, because there is great disparity of view as to what business is saying.

I will refer to two matters that the Minister raised this morning. He said that the costs of his regulatory regime have been estimated at between $1.5 billion and $2.3 billion which, I remind honourable senators, will ultimately be borne by the consumer although in the first instance it will be borne by business. The Minister says that should not be taken into account and, in fact, those who prepared the estimates have withdrawn from their position. I quote from a letter dated 24 November 1989 from the Business Planning Group which says:

I produce the newsletter `Business Insight' and report on progress of this legislation in issues of the 8th September and the 19th October, copies of which are attached. It is clear and on the public record that I was monitoring this legislation and that I had not changed my overall assessment of the effects on industry which it would have.

So there has been no withdrawal from those who estimated the cost. The only figures that we have in this debate, that are on the record, are estimates of somewhere between $1.5 and $2.3 billion in terms of extra financial burden to business.

The Minister, in his quite ungracious second reading closing speech, sought largely to use the occasion to bucket the Opposition to justify his legislation. He said that there was no doubt that insurers do not rely upon credit reports in helping to avoid fraud. I bring to the attention of honourable senators a letter from the Insurance Council of Australia dated 6 November 1989-in actual fact, it is addressed to Senator Janine Haines, so presumably the Democrats will not dispute this-which states:

One of Australia's largest general insurers sampled several hundred claims suspected of being fraudulent and determined that the CRAA had provided relevant information enabling the appropriate defensive strategies to be developed in an alarming 17 per cent of cases.

In another test of the worth of CRAA the insurance companies examined 600 successfully denied fraud claims over a one-year period. The insurer calculated the CRAA contributed relevant information to the extent of about 40 per cent in these cases which overall prevented some $3.5m being paid on fraud claims.

So in actual fact if the true advice of the industry is put before the chamber-which, of course, would be the case if there was a proper committee examination of this matter-much of what the Minister said in his second reading speech today would be found to be untrue.

It is important that those views are put on the record. I also draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that nearly 4,000 individual Australians-this might be of some relevance to the Democrats although they bucketed the individual Australians who had been lobbying them in recent days-have petitioned that this matter be referred to a Senate committee for consideration and report because of the state of the Bill which the Minister intends to progress and because of the cost to the Australian community of that Bill. We suggest to the chamber that the views of the 4,000-odd petitioners be respected and that the Bill be referred to the Committee as they have duly petitioned.

As has been said in the second reading debate, many outstanding issues can be progressed at the committee stage. In presenting this argument for reference of the Bill to the Committee, it is not my intention to go through the major debate again, but I remind honourable senators very briefly of some of the technical and operational difficulties that have come out of the debate; some of the inconsistencies, contradictions and omissions that could be overcome through proper committee consideration; and also some of the legitimate businesses which have been excluded.

Let me start with that last category. I remind honourable senators that the Bill effectively excludes debt collection agencies which have used the credit reference system effectively in the past; and effectively excludes property management agents and general insurance companies from accessing credit information. All that collection agents will be able to get under this Bill is a name and address. This limited disclosure is, of course, inadequate as the collection agent also needs access to the credit information contained in the report to establish what course of collection action would be appropriate. Collection agents, of course, act for small businesses, and so ultimately the small businesses who use the collection agent resources will suffer. As I have said, the cost to small business will no doubt be passed to the consumer.

Then there is the concern of real estate agents who deal with property management. As Senator Panizza interjected during the Minister's speech, the important thing is that approximately 90 per cent, perhaps more, of those who deal in the area of property management utilise this service. It is not relevant to look simply at the percentage of all real estate agents who use the service because not all real estate agents conduct the business of property management. Those who do have for some 20 years used the facilities of the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA) to check the financial backgrounds of prospective tenants, and will not be able to do so if the legislation is passed in this form. Why should they not have the opportunity to bring their views to the Parliament through the committee system?

In relation to general insurance companies, general insurers have had access to credit information for nearly six years. As I said, they use that information to pre-screen an insurance claim, and it is of great advantage in reducing the extent to which fraudulent claims are successful. I would have thought that that would be something that even the Government would applaud and that would respect and properly take into account the views of these general insurance companies. If the matter is referred to a committee the general insurance industry will have the opportunity to present its case to this Parliament and will not have to rely upon the Minister's assertions to the chamber which, as I said, in the form that they were put today, were quite misleading.

One can touch upon some of the technical and operational difficulties. CRAA will be required under the terms of this Bill to delete commercial credit information from the records of individuals. It will be impossible in many cases for it to do so, yet the Minister and the Government have not been prepared to address that question. Apart from that, and apart from the possible fines and prosecutions that could follow as a result of a breach of the provisions, no logical or sound reason has been put as to why commercial credit and consumer credit should be separated. In the case of small businesses, as those on this side of the chamber who have been experienced in small business will know, it is often very difficult to distinguish, in areas of revolving credit, whether the borrowings are used for purposes of the business or the individual who runs the business. The Minister and the Government have not been prepared properly to address these technical difficulties and a committee of the Parliament should therefore be given the responsibility of doing so. I, for one, have confidence that it would do a better job.

Apart from this commercial information which has to be exercised there is also other non-permitted information that CRAA will have to remove-for example, information that has been provided by those who are no longer permitted access, such as government departments. Again, regrettably, it will not be possible in all circumstances properly to identify that information. Another example is in relation to splitting the files of married couples. We do not object to that but the machinery of doing so, the computer power to do so, is simply not currently within the system; yet this Government is prepared to impose something that is currently unworkable.

In relation to inconsistencies, contradictions and omissions, the Bill does not permit a credit provider to inquire about an individual who has offered to guarantee the account of another person. The Government brought that amendment, one of its latest, to our notice yesterday, but we think there are still difficulties in its terminology. We have just received that amendment. Would not the best course of action be that it go to the Committee for consideration? The Bill exempts from any regulation publicly available information, writs, debts, summonses and judgments. Our concern about that is that in the future there will not be regulation to deal with that information. If people are not given credit because of an error on a summons that they had received in the past, they do not have a right of recourse under this legislation. They cannot require it to be corrected and cannot acquire copies of the information that is being distributed. We do not understand the reason for excluding the protection that would be offered. Perhaps the Government can justify it to a bipartisan committee of this Parliament. The Committee's advice would be of great use in the committee stage of the Bill.

The Bill bans a credit provider from monitoring its customers. It seems to us common sense that in some circumstances monitoring of a doubtful credit case is only common sense. Senator Boswell has had a great deal of small business experience and I am sure that he would endorse what I say because I am sure he has lost money through bad debts and appreciated the opportunity to monitor those who are in doubt. The Bill does not permit a trader to inquire about an individual for the purpose of assisting in the collection of dishonoured cheques. We cannot understand that. Why should not the Government justify that to a committee which would have the opportunity to examine the arguments on both sides of that issue?

We have moved this motion because we sincerely believe that it is the best way in which to further process this Bill so that a credit reference protection regime can be in a form that is commercially workable, which this one is not at the moment; can be effective; can protect those whom it is designed to protect; and so there can be an orderly debate on the subject in this chamber and, in the end, the whole chamber can be happy that what has come out of it is a satisfactory and effective piece of legislation. All parties in this chamber now say that there should be protection; there should be credit reference legislation. We are talking about the detail of that legislation. There are now some 100-odd amendments to be debated. The best and sensible way of dealing with that is through a Senate standing committee, and I commend that course of action to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly, not on the particular merits of the case as put by Senator Hill, but on a more general point. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember that a committee, of which you were chairman, recommended-and the recommendation was unanimously accepted by the Senate-that more Bills should be referred to legislative and general purposes committees and that the machinery was set up, including putting aside next year special sitting days, for consideration of legislation by those committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The Privacy Amendment Bill seems to be a Bill-and I do not want to repeat the arguments of Senator Hill-on which there is genuine divergence of views. Many people in the community feel worried about the Bill and wish to make an input into it. For that reason, it seems to me highly proper that the Bill should go to a legislative and general purposes committee-and the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee is the obvious one because of the Bill's complexity-and, since the view of the Senate is that we should send more Bills to committees, it could be properly examined in public with the community being able to make an input into its content. The Committee of which you were chairman, Mr Acting Deputy President, comprised honourable senators from the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats. It was the unanimous view of the Committee that we should send more Bills to committees. It seems to me that if the Senate means what it says we should send this Bill off to a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. This matter of referring Bills to a committee again highlights the difficulties that references such as this make for committees. The Senate will be well aware of the extreme problems the Select Committee on Migration Regulations has experienced in the recent few weeks when the Committee was formed and given the task of examining in great detail the regulations attached to the new migration Act. We had a reporting date which meant a very tight schedule. In order to meet that schedule, we had to meet whilst the Senate was sitting, but the Senate itself, despite setting the Committee deadlines, was unwilling to allow the Committee to meet while the Senate was in session. I am not arguing the merits against that decision but I argue that, if we are to use the committee system, we have somehow to accommodate how a committee can follow through with its work, meet its obligations to the chamber and to the Parliament, while at the same time taking account of the workload of the members of the various committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Today is the fifth day of the fifth consecutive week of sitting, and the Migration Regulations Committee-the one that I particularly referred to, although it is not the only committee that I am a member of-had to meet at extreme hours of the day in order to fulfil the obligations imposed upon us in the Senate. Next year we are moving into a new committee system, with which I recognise the previous speaker, Senator Hamer, had a great deal to do. I hope the experiment will work, because I think there are many advantages, with different Bills that come before us, in requiring the detailed scrutiny that a committee can give to a Bill. I think it is something that we all can look forward to, but at the end of a session, as we are at the moment, we all too often get matters referred to a committee as a way of hiving things off.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose Senator Hill's proposition. In doing so I do not want to go through my speech again, as Senator Hill went partly through his, but there have been consultations which have been constructive. I think that has been a very healthy process, particularly with those organisations that have wanted to play it constructively. I think Senator McKiernan makes quite a valid point. On the one hand, we have been having consultations and, on the other hand, I remind Senator Hill that he may not have been having consultations with the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, to which he wants to send this matter. But having spoken to three members of that Committee in the last 15 minutes, they do not share his enthusiasm to take this process on. In other words, the Committee does not want it. The Government gives highest priority to the Privacy Amendment Bill and it will be the first Bill on the agenda when we return in February. As a consequence, having given it that priority and asserting that we have had wide and constructive consultations, we oppose the referral of this Bill to a committee.

—I rise to say that the Australian Democrats will also not be supporting this reference to a committee. I just make a point about Senator Hill's argument that the number of amendments is relevant to any decision on whether or not a Bill should go to a committee. In my short time in this place I have dealt with many pieces of legislation with voluminous amendments. One such piece of legislation was debated at the beginning of this week. If there is goodwill on all sides it is quite within the capacity of people responsible for legislation, and the people with whom they are consulting outside this chamber, to address that practical issue of numbers of amendments and to come to resolution. It is not always necessary to send legislation to a committee. I endorse the remarks of the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) about the level of consultation in this process. The Democrats believe that the legislation has reached the stage where it is workable and ought to be able to be handled by this chamber and, indeed, would have been able to have been handled by this chamber. Therefore, I do not believe there are any arguments on that basis for the Bill to be referred to a committee.

—I supported the second reading of the Privacy Amendment Bill, because I believed that the Bill dealt with an area which needs to be dealt with. I also indicated that it required amendment. I listened to Opposition speeches in the second reading debate, many of which included a declaration that legislation in this area was desirable. Having an agreement in principle from members of the Opposition, and obviously an agreement in principle by the Government, that legislation in this area is desirable, we are faced with innumerable amendments. One benefit of the Bill going to a committee that I can see is that a committee would be unanimous in the view that, in principle, legislation in this area should be adopted; therefore, the committee would be able to narrow down the differences and, in a report back to the Senate, indicate where the essential differences are. It appears to me that only three or four areas of absolute difference exist, and under those circumstances in this case-and I will not argue about the general issue-it seems desirable to have the Bill referred to a committee. I support the motion that the matter be referred to a committee, but I do so only on the understanding that the committee would get on to its business quickly, advertise in January and get the report prepared preferably by early February, so that it would be available for us in time for the first sitting day next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill, the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, for the amendments to the Bill to be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As Senator Harradine pointed out, some members of the Opposition, including myself, supported the Privacy Amendment Bill because of some of the measures contained within it. I am one of the most outspoken ones against the vexatious clauses of the Bill. Last evening I supported the idea that some of this Bill is required to protect the honest user of credit. But 90 per cent of it has been made in haste by this Government and will be supported by the Australian Democrats because of the oncoming election. After all, this Bill was brought into this House at least seven weeks ago. Immediately, the Government had 42-odd amendments. If it is so pressing and if there are so many problems with credit reporting the Government has had plenty of time in the last seven weeks to bring it on and deal with it.
—Rubbish!

—Senator McKiernan should know that we have had all the time on earth but Government members have wasted time on other things. They have been helped by the Democrats to waste time. They should have got their priorities right; they have had the time to do so. We can argue about that all day, but we have had the time. I am not one who believes we should rush it through or do anything just because it is nearly Christmas. I believe that we should work until the last minute that we are here. Just because Christmas is on Monday we should not hurry through things that we may regret later. I will work until tomorrow morning or whenever to get everything done so long as it is done properly.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the point of this Bill. As I said, although this Bill is needed to protect a certain amount of genuine people who use credit, it is a slug on small business and the real estate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The motion before the Chair is for the referral of the Bill to a committee. That is what we must concentrate on. The merits of the Bill itself are not relevant.

—I understand fully, Mr Deputy President. That is why I am explaining that we should not be in a hurry to rush through this legislation because it is far too vexatious. There are far too many heated ideas on the matter. That is why I believe it should be referred to a committee that will be able to deal with it in more of a temperate climate. We are so far apart in ideals on the matter that we will not settle it here even if we sit on it for a week. As has happened in other cases, a matter is referred to a bipartisan committee and submissions can be received from people and organisations to justify the action. We have had plenty of ammunition from the Minister this morning. I was told that we have had unsubstantiated allegations from the Press Gallery. If we put this case to a committee we can make the Government back up its arguments. At this stage of the game that is the only way to go. I strongly endorse what our shadow Minister has had to say on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate I want to reiterate the point that I am disappointed that the Australian Democrats and the Government are not prepared to adopt this process which will not only result in improved legislation but also improve debate at the committee stage in this chamber. I remind the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) that he was involved in the debate on the Corporations Bill. As a result of a committee of the Parliament having the opportunity to deal with that Bill, the debate in this chamber was reduced to a sensible number of hours, literally a few hours, whereas otherwise it would have taken up days, if not weeks. That is what we are putting to both the Democrats and the Government in this instance. Why not reduce the complexity by making the committee system work?

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament does not sit again, if it is to sit again before the election, until 20 February. That would mean that advertisements and other matters that need to be attended to in the meantime could take place early in January. The Committee could have three weeks to consider this Bill and to put it in shape before, as Senator Bolkus says, it is treated as the first item on the agenda when we return here on 20 February. If the Government and the Democrats were prepared to adopt that procedure we would all be better off. What is more important, we would end up producing a better piece of legislation. So in no way can this mechanism be said to be a delaying mechanism; rather it is a mechanism to improve the processes of the Parliament and the consideration of this Bill, and ultimately result in a better piece of legislation. I plead with both the Democrats and the Government to take that into account. There can be no argument with the logic of what I have just put. There can be no argument that it will not facilitate or improve debate in this place. I therefore ask them to reconsider their objection and support the motion which is now to be voted upon.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989SALES TAX LAWS (COMPUTER PROGRAMS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 21 December 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering messages from the House of Representatives relating to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and the motion relating thereto moved by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh.

—Last night Senator Haines moved that we adjourn this matter until today because there was some confusion as to exactly what had happened in the House of Representatives. I point out that there has been a change in the order and the numbering in the Bill. The Bill now refers to subsection 1, and there was no subsection 1 in the original Bill, which is what rather confused me at the time. Effectively, the House of Representatives has accepted the principle which we wish to see incorporated into this legislation, but has done it in a slightly different way. Therefore, we have no objection to accepting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for delaying the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs Amendment) Bill until this morning. When it was introduced last night it was obvious that it did not completely cover the anomaly that was detected by the Opposition. In the meantime, we have had the opportunity of examining this issue a little more closely. Some time ago the Government attempted to impose tax on software, but ran into some problems. Software which was purchased goods could easily be classified, but there was a difficult where a person had been engaged to render personal services to produce a program. Honourable senators will recall that the Opposition parties, with the support of the Australian Democrats, succeeded in having passed an amendment to correct an anomaly-or, perhaps, an unintended consequence-that while the discs and tapes were exempted under this Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill, the modern technology as represented in a cartridge which was plugged into a port at the back of a computer was not. The Opposition sought to correct that position. In so doing we were very conscious of the need-because of the problem of the distinction between the application of equipment for educational purposes and that used for toys-not to open up a Pandora's box in seeking to close an anomaly. To that end, we sought discussions with the Government, firstly through Senator Walsh's office and then through the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Australian Taxation Office. A high level of satisfaction was achieved. If we were able to have more such conferences to resolve matters of mutual interest-to take politics out of these issues, look for the substance and follow the precedents that have been set in relation to these sales tax laws-we would get much more constructive legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, I have to point out that while the revised amendments which are now before the Senate cover about 90 per cent of the anomaly that we sought to overcome, the new words present difficulties for certain firms operating in this area. We have to acknowledge that some firms will be substantially disadvantaged in relation to their competitors in the market, particularly those who use an external computer monitor or television screen. The Government's amendments have had the effect of encouraging manufacturers to produce two separate products: a home electronic device and a separate monitor and/or a television screen. In fact, the technology is really working in the opposite direction to encompass everything in an inbuilt light-emitting diode crystal display screen. However, we have to acknowledge that there has been a lot of difficulty in the short time available in being able to frame appropriate amendments tight enough to distinguish between the educational use and the toy concept. Because of that difficulty we are not prepared to open up an unintended consequence by admitting such things as toys. Therefore, under the circumstances we are quite happy, given the limited time available and the need to get this Bill through, to accede to the request that came from the other House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the twenty-first report of the Committee of Privileges entitled Possible Adverse Treatment of a Witness Before the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion and to give a notice of motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 9 March 1989 the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges: whether there was any adverse treatment of Mr Michael Pope by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) or its officers in consequence of evidence given by him to the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and whether any contempt of the Senate was involved. The Committee, after a substantial number of meetings to discuss the matter, including a public hearing held on 29 November, has found that on balance and in all the circumstances, firstly, there was adverse treatment, although to a minor degree, of Michael Pope-firstly, by Cedric Wyatt, in that he instructed that Mr Pope should make formal request in writing before visiting the head office of the Aboriginal Development Commission and, secondly, by Michael Stewart, in that he extended the instruction to apply to all ADC offices and sent a minute to that effect to all such offices; secondly, the adverse treatment in each case was partially in consequence of Mr Pope having given evidence to a Senate committee; thirdly, therefore, a contempt of the Senate was committed in each case, although not constituting a serious contempt and, fourthly, in the light of Mr Wyatt's and Mr Stewart's apology to the Committee and the Senate, no further action should be taken. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting that is not less than seven days after the day on which this notice is given, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate endorse the findings contained in paragraph 65 of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HAINES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Following discussions with the Whips this morning, I now present the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, from 556 citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the parlous state of uncertainty faced by the Chinese students in Australia in the wake of the bloody repression of pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing and other cities and regions of China; the certain reprisals faced by such students if they were to return to China and the failure till now of the Australian Government and the Department of Immigration & Ethnic Affairs to accept or seriously consider applications from such students for permanent residence.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to forthwith pass a resolution calling upon the Australian Government and the Department of Immigration & Ethnic Affairs to urgently grant permanent residence to all Chinese students currently in Australia who have taken part in pro-democracy demonstrations against their government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I note the Government's preparedness to use trade sanctions against South Africa in an effort to pressure that Government to reform. What is the Government's attitude to trade with Romania, which as we all know has a despotic regime responsible for killing its own people? Is it the case that the Australian Government currently facilitates trade with Romania and offers the assistance of Austrade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill would be aware that the trade embargoes with South Africa are part of an international agreement. Australia certainly has been at the vanguard of those agreements in pressing our points about apartheid. The point Senator Hill makes about Romania, no doubt, could constitute a policy matter for the international community and Australia in particular. The events have occurred only in the last few days and any reaction by the Government will be announced in the future. I will pass on Senator Hill's implied views in his question to the Foreign Minister on his return.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Education Services. I draw the Minister's attention to the Liberal Opposition's plan to abolish the job training program Skillshare. Has the Government made an assessment of the number of Australians helped by Skillshare and the number of people who will benefit next year? Does the Government intend to adopt a policy approach to Skillshare, as proposed by the Opposition? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year approximately 60,000 people will benefit from the Government's Skillshare program. That number is expected to rise somewhat next year. The Government has no intention of adopting the Opposition policy and abolishing this program. The target group of the program is the long term unemployed, particularly disabled workers and older workers in that long term unemployed group. Community contributions make up about 20 per cent of total Skillshare funding. That significant proportion of community contributions is a fairly good vote of confidence in the program by the people who are actually paying the money, other than governments. It is also cost-efficient compared with other training programs such as Jobtrain, costing about $750 per trainee as against about $1,400 for the Jobtrain program.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition, in its so-called Economic Action Plan, claims that it will save $61m from the abolition of Skillshare. At the local level its members and senators go around claiming that local Skillshare projects will be maintained. The Opposition's dishonesty is amazing. My colleague Mr Dawkins has told me that many Opposition senators and members have been lobbying him-both before and after the Opposition adopted its policy-for increased funding. Those Opposition members include, would you believe, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, and the honourable member for Deakin, Mr Beale. I also table the list of members of parliament who are on Skillshare management committees. I am not sure whether the list, which was supplied to me by Mr Duncan's office, is exhaustive but it lists 16 Labor Party members and 11 National Party members who are members of the committees which give advice on this program which the Opposition says it is going to abolish.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to his statement of August last year when he said that if current account deficits continued at $1.7 billion a month for six months in succession, that would have to be `a real crisis'. I concede that, now that we have seasonally adjusted balance of payments figures each month, the Minister's statement at that time should presumably be read in that context. Against that background, I remind the Minister that for the five months from June to October this year the seasonally adjusted balance of payments deficits recorded have been, respectively, $1.9 billion; $1.6 billion, which falls just outside the Minister's $1.7 billion; $2.2 billion; $1.9 billion; and $1.7 billion. Noting that one of those figures is marginally outside his $1.7 billion a month criterion, now that the November balance of payments deficit of $1.8 billion, seasonally adjusted, has been recorded, does the Minister agree that the current balance of payments situation now constitutes a real crisis?

—It ought to be well known here that I have long regarded the current account deficit as the nation's most serious economic problem. Senator Stone has rounded off the seasonally adjusted figure for November. He called it $1.8 billion; that is a rounding of the figure of $1.757 billion. I am not suggesting that anybody should be complacent about that. As a proportion of gross domestic product the Budget forecast-I do not remember the precise figures-predicted a fall from 5.2 per cent of GDP to 5 per cent of GDP. We would all like to see it come in significantly lower than 5 per cent of GDP. However, I do believe that the figures to date, even though they have been high in the early months of this year, are not inconsistent with the Budget forecast outcome which requires an average current account deficit for the next seven months of this financial year of around $1.3 billion. I believe that the outcome to date and the likely figures for the rest of the year are consistent with the Budget estimate but of course it is too high and it cannot be sustained at that level indefinitely.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources been drawn to an allegation by Mr Geoff Sherrington, President of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, that the Federal Government has carried out `deliberate policies of economic sabotage' on the mining industry in the Territory? Can the Minister advise whether or not there is any basis for this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in which Mr Geoff Sherrington, the President of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, was quoted in the Northern Territory News on 4 December as making the statement that Senator Childs has asked me about. The article was under the by-line of Territory journalist Frank Alcorta. Although the words were not in quotation marks, it commenced by saying that Mr Geoff Sherrington has predicted gloomy times for the Territory's mining industry. The question is, essentially, whether this allegation is true. I am not going to engage, as Mr Sherrington so obviously has, in windy rhetoric about this; I will actually go to the figures and, with facts and statistics, demonstrate that his allegation is not true. For example, the latest report of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics shows that in 1988-89, Northern Territory gold production rose by 51 per cent, lead production rose by 54.5 per cent, silver production rose by 39.3 per cent, uranium production fell by 14.2 per cent, and zinc production rose by 35 per cent. The fall in uranium production is due to the slackness in demand in the world uranium market and the low prices that are being paid for uranium.
—How is the review of uranium going?

—Prices have been rapidly falling, as Senator Parer would know. Mineral exploration is an indicator of future mining activity. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), in 1988-89 the value of mineral exploration in the Northern Territory, excluding petroleum, rose by 36.8 per cent to $66.9m, the highest rise in that year in any State or Territory except Senator Tate's home State of Tasmania, in which it rose by 45.2 per cent. The Northern Territory is second behind Tasmania as having the greatest growth in mineral exploration other than petroleum. The ABS statistics also show that in 1987-88, the year for which the latest statistics are available, the value of turnover in the Northern Territory for mining establishments rose by 28.7 per cent to $1,063.9m, the highest increase in any State or Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears from Mr Sherrington's remarks that his objection is essentially to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, which he claims prevents mining development. It goes to the question, I suppose, of whether Mr Sherrington believes that Aboriginals should have land rights and that they should be prescribed in this way. I, and the vast majority of Australians, believe they should, but I do not accept the presumption upon which Mr Sherrington seems to be acting-namely, that the granting of land rights excludes mining. It palpably does not, and anyone who attended the last national conference of the Australian Labor Party will remember that Aboriginal groups lobbied us to extend mining operations in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am conscious that this may well be the last question I ask in the Senate and I would have liked to have asked a slightly sexier question, but if it is good enough for Senator Stone, whose position is much the same as mine, to ask the Minister for Finance a dreary economic question, I guess I can, too. My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer relates to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1989 and, in particular, to subclause 23 (3), which relates essentially to a capital gains tax anti-avoidance measure introduced in the last Budget. For the benefit of the Minister I point out that the apparent effect of the amendment is that, where a group company-namely, the loss company-transfers a capital loss to another group company and the other group company either holds shares in or has made a loan to the loss company, the cost base of the shares or the loans held by the other group company will be proportionately reduced to the extent that the particular shares or loans bear to the total shares of or loans to the loss company multiplied by the transferred capital loss.
—He won't understand a word of this.

—Yes, he does. I gave him fair warning of the question; I gave him half an hour's notice of this question. I suggest to the Minister that it would appear that, therefore, if the loss company pays back the loan to the other group company in full, it may cause a capital gain, and hence a tax on that capital gain, to accrue to that company. Is this interpretation correct? If it is not, why is it not correct? If it is correct, why has the Government introduced such an element into the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) at a time when I would have thought it would be encouraging all Australian businesses to reduce their level of debt?

—Mr President, may I say how pleased I am that, after about 10 years of chasing fairies around the bottom of the garden, Senator Haines is now asking a serious technical question about taxation? About an hour ago she told me that she was going to ask this question and said that she had approached the Treasurer's office yesterday. I said that, if the Treasurer's office had a considered reply, I would make it available. If the Treasurer's office does have a considered reply I have not got it yet. I stayed here instead of returning to my office after the last division. However, if a reply is available at the end of Question Time I will get it then, otherwise I will try to get Senator Haines a reply by correspondence.
—Try to answer it.

—I will do that. To refresh the memories of people in the Senate, an Opposition amendment-supported by the Australian Democrats or perhaps the other way around; I do not remember for certain-to tax legislation earlier this year imposed a retrospective capital gains tax liability.
—Which one was that?

—I think it ought to be noted that the Opposition knowingly forced an amendment on the Government which imposed a retrospective capital gains tax liability. Sorry; I believe that it was a Democrat amendment supported by the Opposition' and Senator Panizza voted for it along with all the rest of the Opposition, to impose a retrospective capital gains tax liability, admittedly on a small number of people, but on people whose actions had done nothing to justify the imposition of that liability on them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. While I acknowledge the Minister's last deviation from his answer to my question, I certainly do not accept that that was the effect of that amendment. In fact, it had the effect of closing off a serious loophole in the Government's own legislation. I ask the Minister certainly to expedite the answer to that question, given that it has particular relevance at the moment in the light of the relationship between Bond Corporation and Bell Resources. I think it is something that the Government ought to be turning its attention to on those grounds, if not on the general grounds.
—Mr President, I do not think I can add anything relevant to what I have already said.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of Mr Nicolai Rusak, the Minister for Sport in the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome him to the Senate and trust that his visit to Australia is a success.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF ALL FORMS OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that this week marks the tenth anniversary of the adoption by the United Nations of the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women? Has the Government any plans to give special emphasis to this anniversary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact contained in the honourable senator's question. The Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women, commonly referred to as CEDAW, is the most important international human rights instrument for women. It was adopted by the General Assembly on 18 December 1979 and was sent for signature on 1 March 1980. Australia signed it on 17 July 1980 and ratified it on 28 July 1983. Obviously, many important tenth anniversaries have been related to this convention over the years. For the anniversary this December I am aware that the National Women's Consultative Council has organised Justice Evatt, Australia's independent expert on the committee, to give talks on the convention in several States.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has taken its obligations under the convention very seriously. We actually ensured that it was ratified soon after we came to office in 1983. We provided the resources to service our obligations under the convention. Australia's initial report to the committee presented in 1988 was commended by the committee as a model report for other countries. In accordance with provisions contained in the convention, this Government has passed major pieces of legislation, including the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Affirmative Action and Equal Employment Opportunity Act 1986.

The Government's national agenda for women provides a strategy for continued Government action aimed at raising the status of women in the context of the convention. The Government is proud of the fact that Justice Evatt is the current chairperson of the committee and some assistance will be provided to her in fulfilling this role, but that is constrained by the need to guarantee her independence. Australia also plans to co-sponsor an information seminar on the convention for South Pacific island states in late 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the fact that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) has threatened to withdraw services from-indeed, in some cases it has already withdrawn services-and reduce other services to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) at the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor site because of an unresolved dispute over financing arrangements between ANSTO and CSIRO that I understand the Minister has been aware of for six months or so. This has been compounded by the Government's reduced funding of CSIRO. What does the Minister intend to do about ANSTO's ultimatum to CSIRO to pay all claimed money or face the withdrawal of essential site services, such as health and safety, medical, telephone maintenance and mail deliveries from 24 December 1989, having already withdrawn some minor services? As this means that in the case of accident or incident within the nuclear reactor complex CSIRO staff will be refused medical or safety services and denied telephone facilities to call for help, will the Minister give an assurance that these services will not be withdrawn and will he take urgent action to correct the situation?

—I do not have any prepared answer on this but I am quite familiar with the situation, certainly in respect of the withdrawal of services by ANSTO. I understand that that matter has been resolved and the services will be supplied. An unresolved dispute has been going on between ANSTO and CSIRO over the presence of CSIRO laboratories on the site; it was suggested at some stage that they be transferred to North Ryde. I sought to have the parties resolve these issues amongst themselves. They were unable to do so and yesterday, as a matter of fact, I determined the manner in which this dispute should be resolved. In essence, I have decided that the CSIRO laboratories should be consolidated on the ANSTO site. I wrote yesterday to the Chairman of ANSTO advising him of that decision and I have also written to the Chairman of CSIRO advising him that, if any moneys owed by CSIRO to ANSTO are still outstanding, they are to be paid. This morning I had a discussion with the Chief Executive of CSIRO and he told me that matter will be attended to quickly. I think there is now an opportunity for CSIRO and ANSTO to collaborate on the site and I think they ought to take that opportunity.
