QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH-EASTERN FORESTS OF NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Government received the interim report of the biological studies committee into flora and fauna values to the south-eastern forests of New South Wales? Has the Minister had an opportunity to consider its recommendations? If so, can the Minister advise honourable senators of the Government's response to these recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the interim report from the Joint Scientific Committee on the South-east Forests headed by Professor Bryant Richards. The report was addressed to me as the Minister for Resources, on behalf of the Commonwealth, and to the Hon. Ian Causley, MP, Minister for Natural Resources in the State of New South Wales. I propose to table the report, and that is consistent with my approach of making available to the public domain all the key documents in the south-east forests argument over the conflict of environment and development.

ANSWER.PARA: The study team was criticised when it was first formed on the basis that it was perhaps biased too far one way and/or that it may have preconceived attitudes as to how it would approach the study. At the time I expressed full confidence in the study team. The product of its investigations thus far demonstrates its scientific objectivity and qualifications in undertaking the task that has been set.

This report essentially does three things: First of all, it interprets the terms of reference of the joint governments-New South Wales and the Commonwealth-at great length. Secondly, it sets down the methodology that the team of scientists proposes to follow in assessing the information available on the south-eastern forests, and which it will discover. Thirdly, it sets down the work program of the study team to the end of June 1990 and the manner in which it is proposed to finalise the recommendations. I think that was an unanticipated by-product of having an interim report. I now invite any organisation, community group or individual to criticise the interpretation of the terms of reference, the methodology, or the work program, as to whether it will assemble the critical mass of information necessary to make these judgments, and to make their criticisms available to the study team, because it would like to know whether there is any scientifically-based argument about its approach, so that when we come to the final outcome we will not debate whether the methodology was appropriate, but the merits of the outcome.

The two principal recommendations of the report are, firstly, that as the study team has been unable to complete and preserve its own scientific integrity of its report it seeks an extension to 30 June and, secondly, that there be no logging in the National Estate forests in the south-east of New South Wales-except the 9 per cent that I have excised for logging-between now and the completion of the report.

I inform the Senate that I understand Minister Ian Causley has agreed to the extension date and has agreed that there be no further logging in the National Estate areas under study until 30 June next year. He has expressed the belief, which I share, that there is sufficient wood resource to maintain the viability of industry at current levels in the south-eastern forests during this period. There are two outstanding matters for me to conclude, which I will do in the first couple of weeks of next year; that is, to settle with New South Wales the cutting cycle for 1990 in the south-eastern forests, and to announce my decision on the application of Harris-Daishowa (Aust) Ltd for an export woodchip licence for 1990. On 29 December last year I announced that I was providing a 17-year export facility which is subject to the environmental considerations. At the beginning of next year I will announce the outcome of that study. I table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen the letter dated 20 November 1989 from the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, to Mr Ben Bremmer, a policy consultant on Senator Button's personal staff, regarding the submission of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to the Australian Science and Technology Council on environmental science? The letter states:

QUESTION.PARA: If you want to give directions about how CSIRO's material is presented, I suggest that you start with me. I don't quite understand what you think is to be gained by lying about the Organisation's capacity. I don't appreciate you throwing your weight around with CSIRO officers. If I thought you had something to contribute that would be another matter.

Does the Minister agree with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business that Mr Bremmer has been lying about the CSIRO? Does he, as Minister, accept responsibility for the actions of his consultants with respect to CSIRO? Finally, what measures is the Minister taking to contain hostilities between his office and that of the Minister for Science?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the McGauran brothers are like Siamese twins, but Siamese dinosaur twins. It is said of the dinosaur that if one sticks a pin in its tail it takes 24 hours for the sensation to reach the brain. Senator McGauran's brother asked almost the same question in the House of Representatives yesterday. It has now been transmitted like a Bill to the Senate. I begin by saying that there is no friction between Mr Jones and myself on these issues.

—I will say it again, Mr President. There is no conflict between myself and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business over funding of CSIRO. We both share a common objective in wanting to see the valuable and intellectual resources within the CSIRO used to the greatest possible benefit of the nation as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the letter from Mr Jones to Mr Bremmer dated 20 November was written after Mr Jones had received advice-I am not quite sure who from, but I suspect somebody associated with his office-and probably had lunch. The advice was that Mr Bremmer had sought to have the CSIRO change its submission on environmental science to the Australian Science and Technology Council. That advice given to Mr Jones-- Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr President, all the interjecting and shouting that is going on is like the Stock Exchange during a share market boom. The moment I said the word `lunch' everybody started to interject about lunch, because that is predominantly the thing on the Opposition's mind at the moment. But Senator McGauran asked me a serious question about the CSIRO. The advice given to Mr Jones was incorrect. Following the publication of details of the CSIRO report in several newspapers, Mr Bremmer contacted the general manager of the CSIRO's Corporate Resources Division to inquire whether the figures cited in the report took into account the substantial increase in funding for environmental research which was made available in the Prime Minister's statement on science and technology and on the environment earlier this year. Mr Bremmer was informed that this additional funding had not been taken into account by the officers who compiled the report, and he advised me of this fact. Honourable senators will recall that I gave an answer to the Senate on this matter on 21 November. I forget who asked the question, but an Opposition senator asked me about funds for environmental research and I gave a detailed answer on that day.

ANSWER.PARA: I make one other point: in regard to submissions prepared by bodies such as the CSIRO to the Australian Science and Technology Council, I think it is important that Ministers see those submissions before they are submitted. I think it is also important that Ministers exercise no influence in attempting to change them. But I think they should be made available to Ministers as a matter of information. Ministers should not seek to have any influence over the contents of reports of independent or statutory authorities of that kind. I would certainly not do that, and nor would my staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's attempt to gloss over the very serious allegation of lying, and the fact that he gave no indication that he had sighted the letter, I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard and ask the Minister for a further and more detailed answer.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Ben Bremmer
Senator Button's Office
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Bremmer,
Last month I approved the CSIRO submission to ASTEC's review on environmental research and sent a copy to your office. You have been sitting on it since then.

If you want to give directions about how CSIRO's material is presented, I suggest that you start with me. I don't quite understand what you think is to be gained by lying about the Organisation's capacity. I don't appreciate you throwing your weight around with CSIRO officers. If I thought you had something to contribute that would be another matter.

cc: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter has been circulated all over the building during the last 24 hours; it might as well be incorporated in Hansard. I have nothing to add to what I said in my original answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. In mid-1988 the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority recommended the establishment of a national witness protection program. Has the Government done anything about that and, if so, what?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for his question, as it is acknowledged he left his sickbed in order to perform his duties in the chamber. He has raised a most important matter. Protection of witnesses in all the Australian jurisdictions is an extremely essential part of the fight against criminal activity in our society, particularly against drug trafficking. It would be well known that between the street dealers and the entrepreneurs and financiers of crime there are often interlaid many different persons and activities in order to obscure who are the real financiers and entrepreneurs of organised crime in our society. It then becomes very important to rely on those from the criminal milieu to act as informers and eventually as witnesses in the trials of these people. It is essential that they be protected against intimidation, harassment and threats of violence and actual violence that might be made against their persons and, of course, those of their families.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only are the criminal informants in need of protection quite often, but quite commonly there are decent, law-abiding citizens who are prepared to undertake the peril to themselves and even create jeopardy for their families in order to provide information that will be useful in a prosecution. In this situation it is important that, as the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority pointed out, we have a nationwide approach which does secure the protection of these people.

A steering committee was set up in response to the Joint Committee report that Senator Cooney has alluded to. It has been having discussions to ensure that all jurisdictions-Federal, State and the Northern Territory-have in place by the end of 1990 uniform legislation, for example, providing very severe penalties against those who disclose information as to the whereabouts of protected witnesses and also to put in place procedures which will facilitate the operation of a national complementary scheme. Obviously, there needs to be provision for a change of identity. This will require very complex document issuing. One thinks of marriage certificates, obviously, as one area that would need to be tackled. Major difficulties also concern social security payments and how one relates to the child support program. The relocation of witnesses and their re-establishment in a different part of Australia is also a matter of quite complex logistics.

The joint Commonwealth-State steering committee has been meeting during 1989 and has reached consensus that there be a cooperative witness protection scheme. Under this cooperative model, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) will offer full witness protection arrangements on a national basis for its own witnesses and to all Commonwealth, State and Territory law enforcement agencies based on formal agreements and on a user pays basis. States not wishing to use AFP witness protection services will continue to provide their own. Agreement was also reached between all jurisdictions on the legislative provisions which will be required, and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel will commence work on drafting the legislation, other priorities permitting. It is then proposed to pass Federal and complementary State legislation contemporaneously.

I have outlined important steps being taken along the way in the battle against criminal activity in our society. We must ensure that there be no intimidation of witnesses so as to frustrate the bringing to justice of those criminals in our society who, in addition to their criminal activity, would, as I say, harass, intimidate and do violence not only to those witnesses and informers I speak of, but even to their families. It is important that we as a society protect these people and I am very pleased that the national Government, the States and the Northern Territory have reached agreement to do just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to reports from the Cooke inquiry which have appeared in the media during the week in which a union solicitor stated that the red light district in Brisbane does a roaring trade every time there is a committee of management meeting of any trade union in Brisbane. A trade union leader confirmed to the inquiry that these services were paid for from union slush funds. Mr Ken Goodhew, a union leader and Vice-President of the squeaky clean Labor Party in Queensland, who participated in the abuse of trade union funds, also admitted he borrowed $52,000 from slush funds-presumably interest free-to buy a Gold Coast unit more than two years ago. As union dues are tax deductable and income from union funds is tax free, what, if any, are the tax implications for the unions concerned and for the individuals, particularly the Vice-President of the State Labor Party, who have received any benefits in cash or kind? Are such benefits subject to fringe benefits tax in the hands of the union or income tax in the hands of the recipient? Will the Minister request the Australian Taxation Office to investigate the informal claims made that union delegates are paid out of slush funds for attendance at union meetings the cash equivalent of pay forgone, thus avoiding tax?

—I suppose I could ask the Treasurer to ask the Tax Office to investigate the matter, but I think it more than likely that the Tax Office will await the outcome of the inquiry before it judges anybody to be guilty as charged. The general answer to the question-and this is subject to confirmation-is that if, indeed, such payments were being made and it could be substantiated, I think the union, as the employer, providing an employer-employee relationship could be established, would be liable to fringe benefits tax. But, as I said, I think we would all be much better advised to await the outcome or the findings of the inquiry.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the request under the Freedom of Information Act from the honourable member for North Sydney for material relating to the Government's costing of the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether his Department has provided the honourable member with documents to satisfy his request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I mentioned that Mr Spender had applied on public interest grounds for the charges appropriate to his freedom of information (FOI) request to be waived. The big spender was seeking a bit of expenditure relief for himself. I also said that the Department of Finance had recommended that I waive charges and that under those circumstances I believed I had no realistic option. Mr Spender will be supplied with the documents in question today-there are about 70 of them in total. With the exception of those that are addressed to me, I have not seen any of them before, and that tells us something about the Opposition's assertions that there has been political interference in the preparation of these documents.

ANSWER.PARA: As Mr Spender's request for waiving the charges on public interest grounds was accepted, I believe that, also on public interest grounds, these should now become completely public documents and not just Mr Spender's documents. Therefore, I table the documents. Attached to them is a brief explanatory memorandum from the Department of Finance which explains the background to the preparation of some of the costings. I also table documents from the public record relating to the period 1980 to 1983 which establish quite conclusively that it has been common practice for governments to cost Opposition policies.

I mentioned to the Senate earlier this week that I had applied under the FOI Act for other documents from the Department of Finance which were relevant to the costing of the then Opposition Labor Party's policies in 1980 and 1983. I said that I will pay the appropriate charge, and I intend to do so. I again invite Mr Spender to follow my excellent example if he feels inclined to do so. When I get those documents I will also make them publicly available, even though I will, of course, be paying for them. The costings for 1988-89 and 1980 to 83 in the documents that I have tabled are-and I certainly have no reason to believe otherwise-as accurate as the Public Service could provide at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: Would the Minister agree that the recent spate of road tragedies involving heavy transport vehicles is a sad indictment of our whole transport system in Australia? Does the Minister agree that the high cost of Australian shipping, because of overmanning, delays and rorts on the waterfronts, has caused more and more goods to be conveyed long distances by road rather than by sea, thus helping to overload our road system? Does the Minister also agree that because the Government is moving so slowly to introduce urgent reforms into the waterfront that companies are beginning to take matters into their own hands? I will give one example: I remind the Minister that the Australian Wheat Board recently loaded a grain ship with two Wheat Board employees rather than four Waterside Workers Federation of Australia labourers, a foreman and supervisor. That was two doing the work that six would otherwise have done-a 300 per cent productivity improvement, the sort of improvement we urgently need on the waterfront to be internationally competitive. How long will the Government delay the thorough reform of shipping and the waterfront while the whole economy suffers and more and more lives are lost on the roads because semitrailers are hauling goods which should go cheaply and safely by sea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope Senator Hamer enjoyed the P and O lunch the other day. It usually prompts these sort of questions.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I do not wish to be unduly sensitive on Christmas Eve, but I remind the Senate that the honourable senator introduced a Bill on coastal shipping a couple of years ago and has shown a consistent interest in this matter. I suggest that the Minister withdraw what, I am sure, was a semi-jocular comment.

—Mr President, I withdraw what I have accused Senator Hamer of in a jocular way about 20 times before. I agree that the events of this morning are a major tragedy. The second question is: Is it a fact that our road system is put under undue pressure because we do not move goods by coastal shipping? I would have to say yes to that. It has always been my long term view that a lot of the goods that are carried by interstate transport could either by carried by train or coastal shipping. Part of the reason why they are not is cowardice on the part of government in lifting all sorts of road taxes. The first time there was a blockade and a strike of trucks, the Fraser Government went crawling and negotiated all sorts of agreements. There is not an even playing field at the moment. It is not simply a question of road versus shipping, it is also road versus rail, as the honourable senator would be aware. This Government has been determined, for a long while, to even out that position.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hamer has again raised waterfront and shipping reform. It is not a question of whether this Government is committed to that-it is. The Opposition says it is committed to it-not that it ever did anything about it, but that is the old story. The Opposition members are great Rambos in Opposition and wimps in government, and that is well recorded throughout their history. The real question Senator Hamer is asking is: Is the pace sufficient? This Government believes the long term plans it has are sufficient and are the logical way to go. The Opposition might take a different view and want to provoke a shipping strike for six months. We have always believed in deregulation and structural reform, phased in in such a way that it does not have dramatic dislocation; and that, I guess, is the difference between us and the Opposition.

The Opposition always talks about these things. On many occasions Senator Button has mentioned how often the Opposition talks about tariff reform. The Opposition talks and talks about tariff reform but never does it and leaves it to us to do. The Opposition talks about shipping or waterfront reform. It never did anything about it; we have got to do it. The Opposition talks about a range of issues, but when we have tried to do the hard things, it has opposed us. It opposed us in the fringe benefits tax, the assets tax and lump sum superannuation. We have done all the hard work on the things now incorporated in the Opposition policy. The Opposition apparently wants to try to win government and say, `Thanks for all the money, fellows; all that carping criticism is now forgotten and we will take the pot of gold'. The Opposition has only bolted on one issue that it has opposed over the years-and that is not gold tax, it has accepted that too-and that is capital gains tax, and for the most spurious reasons.

Coming back to the thrust of Senator Hamer's question, this Government is and has been committed to reform of the waterfront and shipping. But it is not going in with all guns blazing, getting no results-as an Opposition government would-by trampling right across the top. That is the Opposition's policy at the moment. The reality is, if the Opposition ever wins government, the old Rambos will suddenly become wimps, it will do nothing about it and it will dither like the Fraser Government and Liberal governments before did. It will be all talk, and no action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Noting the President's report to the Senate on Government responses outstanding to parliamentary committee reports, tabled just a short while ago, I ask the Minister: What progress has been made in preparing the Government's response to the report on animal experimentation of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare? When does the Minister anticipate that the Government's response will be tabled in the Parliament? Does the Government support the banning of the Draize test and the classical LD50 test, as recommended in the report? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the extent to which Draize and LD50 testing continued to be used in Australia and the numbers of animals which are being used for these forms of experimentation and, given the delay in preparing the Government's response to the report, will the Government name a date on which bans on Draize and LD50 testing will be imposed nationwide to spare further unnecessary suffering of laboratory animals?

—After question five I lost count of the number of questions asked by Senator Jenkins. I can say, to one of her earlier questions, that the Government's response to the report is expected to be tabled in the Senate early in the next sitting period. I will have to take on notice the other subsidiary questions which arise out of the report and the Government's response to that report. They will obviously depend on the Government's response, and I am not advised at this stage how soon the Government will be able to respond to the report. Nonetheless, for the sake of the convenience of the Senate, I will take them on notice and reply as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. In light of the enormous tragedy this morning on the Pacific Highway at Kempsey-a short time ago the death toll stood at 32-and in light of the 127 people who have been killed this year on this road, will the Minister now agree that the Pacific Highway ought to be upgraded to a four-lane divided highway throughout its entire length?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment we do not have available to us the exact circumstances of the cause of that crash. Senator Brownhill has drawn attention to a fairly tragic record in that part of New South Wales and it is obviously something that will have to be looked at very seriously. My first hearing of the news this morning suggested that the crash was on what was regarded as one of the safer sections of that highway, but no doubt investigation will throw that up. Both Commonwealth and State governments have to do a lot more in this area to upgrade highways and reduce the pressure on the highways to make sure these crashes do not occur. I also put in a very strong plug to all State governments to take seriously that offer by the Federal Government of $110m to get uniform road laws and to remove the black spots that are occurring in various parts of the country.
—Why not just make the money available without the tag?

—Senator Bishop asks why we do not just make the money available. Sooner or later we have to get out of this provincial attitude where every State can have its own road laws in total contradiction of those of other States. I still cannot get used to not giving way when turning left in Canberra. In Victoria we give way to anyone when we are turning left. It is quite surprising when we drive up here and we start abusing someone and then suddenly realise that there are different road laws, speed laws and drink laws.
—They are all wrong, except us.

—It is not a question of their being all wrong; all we are asking for is some sort of uniformity. In the case of the accident this morning there may not have been a black spot. But there are many black spots which we have to address. We have to try to get some sort of uniformity. In conclusion-I am sure Senator Brownhill will join me here-I extend our sympathy to all the relatives of those involved in that accident. I am sure that everyone in this Senate feels very deeply about the tragedy that has occurred.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of forecasts contained in the latest Economic Outlook of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) which indicate that Australia's current account deficit will drop to $16.5 billion next year and $15.2 billion in 1991, and make distinctions on the nature of deficits based on the discipline of the policies being pursued by the countries in question? Does the Minister agree with the OECD forecast and with the distinction it makes between `good' and `bad' deficits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I glanced rather perfunctorily, I suppose, at the newspaper report of that OECD report this morning. I have not seen the report itself, but I did pick up from the newspaper the flavour of that report, which Senator Beahan has referred to in his question. I think the OECD has made a very good point that the governments of some countries with chronic or very large current account deficits do not really do very much about them. I believe that the United States of America (US) is a case in point. I see Senator Stone shaking his head. Of course, it is true that the US current account deficit, as a proportion of gross domestic product, is not as high as Australia's current account deficit by quite a large margin. However, it is also true that, over the period of the Reagan Administration and still, the US has recorded enormous absolute current account deficits in contrast to its history. For the whole period from, I believe, 1914 to Ronald Reagan the US was a creditor nation. The Reagan Administration also-and this is not entirely unrelated to the US current account deficit-ran up huge budgetary deficits. The United States still has very large budget deficits. I believe that the expected deficit for the coming year is about $US114 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not go into this in great length, but there are a huge number of constitutional and political constraints on the United States Administration even if it were serious about addressing its Budget deficit problems; not the least of which is the lack of party discipline in both the United States House of Representatives and the Senate. It is not like that in Australia. This Federal Government has massively tightened fiscal policy. For the first time since statistics have been kept, the Commonwealth Government has become a major saver instead of a borrower. I am sure that that sort of fiscal discipline would not have gone unnoticed by the OECD examiners. It is the sort of fiscal discipline that four years ago I would not have believed that any Australian government would have pursued or held to, and I doubt whether anybody else would have believed that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC COOPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT: REPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance, follows the question he has just answered. I note his, one could say, approval of the line which is put in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) report. Does he also agree with the OECD report that the Australian economy will slow dramatically next year and that there will be increases in both inflation and unemployment? Does he agree that, despite a possible fall in interest rates, interest rates will remain high in real terms after that increased inflation is taken into account? Does he agree that in 1990 the balance of payments deficit will still be running at the very high level of $16 billion or about 4 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP)? Does he think, in the light of all those matters which are noted in the same OECD report, that we are anywhere close to tackling what he acknowledged earlier in Question Time as our core problem-the looming international debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I noted all the parts to the question that Senator Chaney asked but the first one was whether I believe the economy will slow next year. The answer to that is yes.
—Dramatically?

—I will come to that, Senator. I think everybody in the Government believes that; it was certainly published in the Budget Papers. I do not know how one would quantify the word `dramatically'; it is unquantifiable, so I am not sure what the OECD means by that.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator then asked whether inflation would go higher. No, I do not believe that inflation will go higher, although the indications are, unfortunately, that it will not fall very much in the foreseeable future. The honourable senator also asked whether unemployment would increase. Consequent upon the slowing down of the economy, there is certainly likely to be some absolute increase in unemployment, unless the participation rate changes. The participation rate is now at an all time record high of about 63.3 per cent.

Finally, the honourable senator asked whether interest rates would remain high in real terms. I will follow the example that I have set for myself for 6 3/4 years and will not speculate about what will happen to interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that I also referred to the forecast of a balance of payments deficit of about $16 billion, or about 4 1/2 per cent of GDP, and the extent to which the general indicators suggest that we are coming to grips with the problem that he acknowledged earlier in Question Time about debt. By way of a supplementary question, as well as asking for a reply to the original question, I ask the Minister whether he has any estimates of what wage movements will be in 1990-91. Given the current indicators and the wage fixing system, is it likely that there will be an overall increase in wages of around 9 per cent? Would that influence the Minister's view on inflation which he says is not likely to improve but which I and the OECD suggest will get worse?

—When I said that inflation was not likely to improve very much in the foreseeable future I was really talking about the next calendar year. Beyond that I think it is too difficult to make any predictions; likewise for the likely level of wages in 1991 or 1992-even more so in that case. As for the current account deficit-I have not read the OECD report, as I said earlier; it may well have some background information-I have not recently read any background information upon which I could make any sort of a reasonable judgment about the current account deficit in the next few calendar years other than that I believe for the foreseeable future-again, that is not much more than another 12 months, probably-it will be down, a judgment apparently with which the OECD concurs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 20 December Senator MacGibbon asked me a question regarding the diesel fuel rebate scheme. I have an answer here which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Customs Service (ACS) aims to process claims which have not been selected for audit within 14 days of receipt. There is a further 7 days for payments to be credited through the Department of Finance General Payment System to claimant accounts. However, in the majority of cases, claimants receive rebate payment within 14 days of receipt of their claim by the ACS.

The processing time for claims selected for audit is generally a further 2 weeks but no greater than 4 to 6 weeks in exceptional cases. All regions are achieving these targets with the exception of New South Wales where delays of up to 6 weeks are being experienced in processing claims not selected of audit. Staff shortages caused by a slow staff selection and recruitment process are the main reasons for this delay. Remedial action has been taken to improve the situation.

The approved establishment for the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme is 102 positions in all regions. This level of staffing has been reviewed in July 1988 by ACS Management and the unions and is considered appropriate. Currently, the actual staffing occupancy is 90, or 88 per cent.
Given the high occupancy rate overall, the ACS does not consider that recruitment and retention of staff is a particular problem for the area processing claims under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Panizza asked me a question on the resumption of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia. Let me follow the example of my leader. I have an answer here which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is not in dispute with Saudi Arabia. We have always recognised that the issues arising from the quarantine rejections of Australian sheep by Saudi Arabia needed to be resolved on a co-operative and objective basis. Proposals advanced to the Saudi Arabian Government to this end will continue to be pursued in conjunction with the resumption of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia.

The temporary ban was imposed by the AMLC pursuant to its independent legislative responsibility to safeguard the commercial interest of the Australian industry. The decision to impose the temporary ban had the support of relevant industry groups and was taken in a situation where orderly commercial conduct of the trade had become impossible. The announcement follows discussions the AMLC Chairman, Mr Austen, had on 15 December with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on Mr Austen's return from meetings in Saudi Arabia. Arrangements for lifting the AMLC's temporary ban were also discussed earlier this week with industry groups.

The new conditions to be imposed on exporters by the AMLC to re-open the trade to Saudi Arabia on a planned and controlled basis will include a provision for an alternative destination should there be a further rejection by Saudi Arabia.
Arrangements for the research program are still being developed but will involve, importantly, scientific examination of the possibility of shipboard contamination or infection of sheep.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Environmental Impact of Development Assistance, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Australia's concern for the environment ought to be global in scope. We have an obligation to ensure that all people have access to as unspoilt a world as possible. This concern also has benefits for us. It is not only environments within Australia that determine our capacity for ecological enjoyment. A number of threats to the environment can have world-wide consequences: ecological damage abroad can have deleterious effects on Australia.

The Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has been considering such threats to the global environment and the possible role played in these threats by the provision of aid to developing countries. The report tabled today is the product of that consideration. The reference was first passed to the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment in February 1987. In September 1987 the inquiry was referred to the Committee of which I am Chairman. Specifically, the Committees were asked to examine the capacity of the Australian International Development Aid Bureau (AIDAB) to:
(a) assess the environmental impact of proposed projects; and
(b) ensure the environmentally sound management of such projects.

The reference also required an examination of the adequacy and effectiveness of Australia's participation in the decision-making process of international banks and multilateral aid agencies of which it is a member in relation to the environmental aspects of development projects.

The inquiry was conceived and pursued in the acknowledgment that it can be a particularly difficult task to provide development assistance that is environmentally sound. The level of this difficulty is appreciated through an understanding of the ways in which environmental damage often accompanies economic growth, the tendency of developed countries to cause damage to the environment in the developing world and the kinds of analytical difficulties that confront the formulation of development projects that deliver humanitarian aid benign to the environment.

The provision of development assistance also runs the risk of deteriorating the culture, and therefore the essential well-being, of recipients. Should this occur in connection with the provision of Australian aid, it would be counterproductive to the humanitarian objective and focus that we have adopted for our international assistance.

In accepting the need to review the provision of Australia's development aid from this perspective, the Committee considered that while Australian aid has valid objectives, it runs the risk of damaging the well-being of the recipients and causing significant environmental damage. In so doing it runs a risk of failing to contribute to the ideal of sustainable global development that was so well articulated in the Brundtland Report.

Somewhat reassuringly the inquiry revealed that Australia has obligated itself to a considerable number of sound commitments concerning aid and the environment. Much less pleasing, however, is the fact that no Australian Government has ever formally set out these obligations comprehensively in a published document. The Committee considers that this should be merely one step along a path towards openness concerning the ways in which Australian development assistance is applied in countries that could suffer significant environmental damage unless adequate care is exercised. The formal acknowledgment of our obligations will assist both Australians and aid recipient countries to assess whether our actions comply with our intentions. This acknowledgment will apply both to Australia's role in the multilateral development agencies and to the range of development activities pursued through AIDAB.

With regard to AIDAB, the Committee was most concerned that AIDAB's environmental responsibilities have not been formalised by way of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. The Committee considers this regrettable given that the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment advised in his second reading speech on amendments to the legislation in April 1986, that such an MOU would be negotiated with AIDAB. The Committee considers that, since the Impact of Proposals Act applies to Australian decision-making, AIDAB's activities are within its scope. The benefit of the MOU is that it will confirm the intentions of AIDAB to comply with the principles of the Act.

Having AIDAB's activities subject to the Impact of Proposals Act entails requirements of environmental assessment and, where appropriate, the preparation of impact statements. While the Committee acknowledges that AIDAB has prepared a guideline booklet for staff use in assessing the environmental aspects of proposed aid projects, there is a clear need for all AIDAB staff to be environmentally sensitive and informed. Further, AIDAB needs to organise an environmental review section, appropriately staffed, within its Appraisals, Evaluation and Sectoral Studies Branch. And the environmental guidelines need to be comprehensively applied.

In part the Committee reached these conclusions about the need for AIDAB to substantially improve its environmental analysis on the basis of a review carried out by AIDAB on 400 bilateral projects current in 1987. The Committee found AIDAB's review to be self-condemning. Of 121 projects having potential environmental significance, AIDAB's figures show that more than forty-five per cent passed through the planning/design phase without the consideration of environmental effects. Those projects amounted to more than $211 million in value. Not surprisingly, of those projects more than thirty per cent in number (and fifty per cent in value), had a `major negative' or `minor negative' environmental impact.

Accordingly, the Committee has concluded that AIDAB needs to improve its environmental assessment activities very substantially, and has recommended a broad program for such improvement. If AIDAB adopts the program, it is most unlikely that its sorry record on environmental matters will persist. It includes elements that I have already noted such as the formalising of the MOU with DASETT, the appointment of adequate staff to conduct environmental assessments and the adherence by AIDAB to policy already announced on aid and the environment. However, the program also includes an annual comprehensive audit of Australian aid activities for their environmental effect.

Turning to the multilateral development agencies, three of these institutions are supported by Australia. They are the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. The Committee found that IFAD uses small amounts of money to help the poorest people in developing countries: it does so by promoting self-sufficiency and through education in agriculture and health. Importantly, IFAD makes loans directly to third world villages rather than to their governments.

Despite the World Bank's endorsement of IFAD. the Australian Government's record in allocating funds to IFAD has been patchy at best. In November 1987 the Government announced that it would honour its commitment of (only) $8.48 million for the second triennium. It indicated, however, that it would not participate in the 1988 replenishment negotiations. Following widespread criticism of this announcement, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, announced last September that Australia would contribute approximately $10 million to the third replenishment of IFAD.

Nevertheless, the Committee considers that the Government should give immediate consideration to increasing Australia's current funding for IFAD. The Committee has also recommended that AIDAB monitor IFAD's activities more closely and report annually to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

With regard to the multilateral development banks, Australian contributions in 1988/89 amounted to $180.3 million-$52.5 million to the Asian Development and $126.8 million to the World Bank. (The balance of $1 million was allocated to IFAD).

The Committee concluded that the programs of the World Bank require careful monitoring by Australian representatives. Effective membership necessitates greater awareness of the Bank's handling of environmental issues and the making known of Australian environmental concerns at working levels in the Bank. This will require that Australian representatives to the World Bank draw on the environmental advice available from DASETT. And, given that the World Bank is more a development agency than a bank, the Committee has recommended that Australian representation on the World Bank Board should pass from Treasury to Foreign Affairs and Trade. Further, Australian nominees for Executive Directors should be AIDAB officers.

It was useful for the Committee's task to have had a recent review of AIDAB tabled by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. That report, tabled in February 1989, was critical of the Asian Development Bank's standards of project appraisal. That Committee concluded that strong representations be made to the management of the Asian Development Bank that Australia requires the highest standards of accountability and disclosure. My Committee has endorsed that recommendation. And, as with the World Bank, we advocate that Australian representation on the Board of the Asian Development Bank should pass from Treasury to Foreign Affairs and Trade and that Australian nominees for Executive Directors should be AIDAB officers.

Two other matters are crucial. The first concerns consultation and liaison between Australian authorities. If Australian concerns about the environmental soundness of development projects in assisted countries are to be satisfied, there must be adequate co-ordination between AIDAB, Treasury and DASETT. The Committee has accordingly recommended that these authorities establish a regular and systematic process of consultation to produce the advice necessary for Executive Directors to effectively represent Australia's position on environment policy.

Second, Australian involvement in the multilateral development agencies must be an accountable involvement. The Committee has thus recommended that the current responsible Department, the Treasury, should include in its annual report to Parliament an outline of Australia's involvement with multilateral development banks including:
Australia's current representation;
Australia's official position on major projects and any formal votes taken;
the projects for which AIDAB, Treasury and DASETT have provided assessments;
any environment-related policy initiatives which have occurred; and
Australia's input to such policy developments.

Following the adoption of the Committee's recommendation that Australian representation on the development banks be passed to Foreign Affairs and Trade, this reporting function would reside with AIDAB through the annual report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Coates) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.02 to 2 p.m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The unnecessary hardship facing many Australians and their families as a result of the Government's broken promises, failed policies and the hope for 1990 offered by the Coalition's Economic Action Plan.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In just 10 days time one of two things will happen: either no Australian child will be living in poverty or Bob Hawke's promise will be exposed as one of the greatest frauds and one of the greatest lies ever to have been perpetuated against the people of Australia. If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not to be proven a liar and a fraud, every single day for the next 10 days at least 3,000 children under the age of 15 in Sydney alone, and up to 44,000 young Australians around the whole of this nation, will have been lifted out of poverty. Christmas 1989 will be a miserable one for increasing thousands of ordinary Australians and their families. The clear, direct and personal responsibility for this will lie at the feet of the Prime Minister. They will not be luxuriating at taxpayers' expense at Kirribilli House, waited upon and pampered, watching the yachts of their rich mates sail by and ordering the Royal Australian Navy out of Sydney Harbour because it spoils the Christmas view.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter or public importance draws attention to the plight of increasing thousands of Australians who are suffering as a result of the policies of the Hawke-Keating Government. It draws attention to the fact that in 1990 there is real hope for them only in the election of a Liberal-National Party government and the implementation of our Economic Action Plan. This Christmas will be miserable for families in poverty. Let me draw the attention of honourable senators to the Sydney Morning Herald of a week ago in which this statement was made:

On Monday there were 65 beds left in refuges for homeless children in Sydney. By yesterday afternoon the pressure was on and there were only 35 left. By nightfall there were even fewer. The women's refuges are all full. The crisis centres are groaning.
Despite the promising rhetoric from the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke . . . poverty in NSW is definitely on the menu this Christmas.
According to welfare agencies, this year has seen the emergence of ``the new destitute''-those who for the first time are having to accept charity to get through the yuletide season.

The general manager (communications) of the Sydney City Mission, Ken Harrison, said: ``The number we're helping has doubled this year. We are currently helping over 3,000 families . . . with food and clothing.''
``High interest rates and the high cost of accommodation are breaking people in the middle range. It's creating a new poor who are stretched to breaking point.

The Federal Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, said yesterday he was concerned that an inquiry which he reconvened in Canberra last week had shown there had been little improvement in the number of beds for homeless youth in NSW since his report . . . was released in February.

In terms of social deprivation among those young people the record that the Hawke-Keating Government brings to this country shows that 34 per cent of young homeless girls have tried to kill themselves and that 67 per cent of these children have major drug or alcohol abuse problems. That is the ongoing legacy of the Hawke-Keating Government. Its degree of interest in this matter is shown by the fact that not one Government Minister is prepared to attend the chamber during this debate. We know from the figures that have been produced just what a scandal it is. In his 1984 policy speech the Prime Minister said:
This Government sets the welfare of the Australian family as its top priority.

Having devalued and demoted the priority from the top, it is no wonder that the Government has nothing else left. The only hope of those families, those young people, lies in the coalition's action plan; in the real hope of interest rate relief; in the real prospect of assistance for child care; in the real prospect of help for sole parent families; in the real prospect of real jobs created through reform of the industrial relations and wages system; through the promotion of real educational opportunities; and through real reform of the crushing burden of taxation imposed by the highest taxing government known in the peacetime history of Australia-none of which have been delivered to the people of Australia, despite the fact that, again, in 1984 the Prime Minister stated:
We pledge ourselves to bring home ownership once again within the reach of ordinary Australian families.
Let us look at the promises about relief for real home ownership. In April 1985, the interest rate was 12 per cent, and the Prime Minister said:
. . . through the period of this year . . . there will be, I would expect, a lowering of the level of interest rates.
In July 1985, the rate was 12.5 per cent, and the Prime Minister said:
. . . pressures imposed by the discharge of tax obligations and one would hope as those are met, the pressures on interest rates would reduce.
In September 1985, the interest rate was 13 per cent, and Mr Kerin said:
This Budget will bring interest rates down.
In November 1985, it was 13 1/2 per cent, and Senator Button said:
. . . the Government is optimistic that there will be a steady decline in interest rate . . .
In March 1986, it was 15 1/2 per cent, and Mr Hawke said:
Of course, what we are about is to secure a situation in which we will be able to enjoy permanently lower interest rates.
In March 1989, it was 16 per cent, and Mr Hawke said in Perth, in response to a question as to whether interest rates would fall this year:
They'll go down this year.
Asked whether there was any chance that they would rise before they fell, he said:
No, I don't believe so.
In June 1989, the interest rate was 17 per cent, and Mr Hawke said:
There is no reason why interest rates should rise.

So, once again, on issues such as interest rates consistently this Government and the Australian Labor Party have misled, lied and deceived the people of Australia. It is likely that short term interest rates will fall because the Government is running down the economy. Yet under Labor interest rates have been and will remain far too high. Home owners and small businesses are now faced with the prospect of being run over by an eight-tonne truck instead of a 10-tonne truck. Under Labor, any fall in interest rates for home mortgages and small business cannot be significant and sustainable. A significant or sustainable fall in interest rates is not possible under Labor, because it has no policies to fix the fundamental weakness in the economy. Our huge foreign debt continues to mount, and inflation continues to be stuck between 7 and 8 per cent.

The answer will be a new Liberal-National Party administration whose Economic Action Plan will bring down our huge foreign debt and have it under control, and bring down the underlying rate of inflation. From day one in office we will start putting our policies in place so that they bring about a significant and sustainable drop in interest rates during our first term in government. It is not just families and individuals that suffer; small businesses and the individuals that make up the small business sector in this country also suffer. Labor, having pledged after the last war that it was not going to create a class of small capitalists, has certainly gone out of its way to destroy those few small capitalists who have managed to get themselves established.

It is absolutely no wonder that the Labor Party has been so intent on attacking the coalition's plans for the introduction of the speculative gains tax to reduce and replace Labor Party's capital gains tax, because on 14 December the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) admitted that the Opposition's sliding scale tax arrangements would be of benefit to small businesses and farmers. He said that the removal of the capital gains tax would provide a break to small businesses, including farmers. Of course, the Treasurer is and always has been opposed to, and a great opponent of, small business. Under the Keating Treasury, the only small business to do well are eastern suburbs' antique shops and dealers and vendors in empire clocks. Let me remind Mr Keating that, like the other famous collector of clocks in history, Louis XVI, the tumbrels are waiting and the blade of the electoral guillotine is sharp. All we want now is the date on which we send the tumbrels round and an address from Mr Keating so we know where to pick him up, depending on which part of his travelling allowance rort he is into that particular week.

As I said, small business, including retailers, will be particular beneficiaries of the Economic Action Plan which the coalition will put in place. Let us look at retail sales this year. Coles Myer Ltd reports that its retail sales are 4 per cent lower in real terms than they were last year, and the retail sales of David Jones (Aust.) Pty Ltd are down between 5 and 6 per cent in real terms. The Retail Traders Association of Victoria says that, statewide, a 3 per cent decline is likely in the real value of the sales of its members. Labor's capital gains tax places imposts on superannuation policy holders, small shareholders and small businesses around Australia and is a substitute death duty. It has the potential to hit the value of the family home. All those things will be eliminated after the election of a coalition government and the putting in place of our Economic Action Plan.

Another area in which small businesses have been particularly hurt and damaged is the Australian tourist industry. It is suffering as a result of the Prime Minister's declaration of war on the pilots, because what started as a dispute between the pilots and their employers has become very much the Prime Minister's own personalised dispute-his dispute, his exacerbation of the dispute, his decision to prevent the companies getting together with their employees to sort it out, his decision to bale out only his mates, his friends, his cronies.
Opposition senators-What dispute?

TALK.START.PARA: —And to respond, as my colleagues are reminding me, to the dispute that is not, the dispute which has been terminated, the dispute which is no longer with us, because we all know how easily anybody can fly to anywhere they want to go at any time because the dispute has been settled. The coalition parties have never supported the pilots' outrageous demands in this dispute. We have consistently supported the position of the small businessman, the tourist industry, the tourist operators, particularly those who are disadvantaged in places such as the Northern Territory, north Queensland and Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, in terms of the particularities of families, it will not just be that they have to curtail their Christmas arrangements, that their food is costing them more, that their accommodation is costing them more, that they are unable to afford the sorts of goods which they have been able to afford in the past. Many will have made the decision to buy goods on credit, and their day of reckoning will come some time in January or February-and their day of reckoning has a great deal to do with the policies this Government has put in place. For example, for those who might have shopped using their credit cards, the interest rate on the Commonwealth bankcard is about to go up to 24.6. In 1984 it was 18 per cent. On the Commonwealth Mastercard, the rate was 18 per cent in 1984 and it is now 23 per cent. On the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd Visacard, the rate was 18 per cent, and it is now 23.5 per cent. On housing mortgages, the rate was 12.5 per cent and it is now 17 per cent and more. On the small overdrafts, the rate was 13 3/4 to 14 per cent and it is now 20 3/4 to 22.75 per cent. That is the legacy of this Government. Once again, it is all very well for no Minister to attend and for Senator Schacht to come in here and grin all over his face. He is not particularly affected by these sort of things; he is well secured and has a secure existence. He is not the sort of person who bothers to go around the streets in cities like Sydney to observe what is going on in terms of the homelessness, drug abuse, and the fact that kids are left on the streets in Sydney with nothing to sell but their bodies. He is not concerned about that sort of thing, because nobody on his side has demonstrated the slightest degree of interest or the slightest degree of concern in these particular areas.

The Hawke-Keating Christmas presents to Australians and their families for 1989 are as follows: for increasing numbers of families, the prospect of no home and no hope; for increasing numbers of young Australians, no presents, no prospects; for increasing numbers of small businesses, no sales and no sympathy; and for the forgotten people around Australia, no recognition and no relief. Only with the adoption of the policies which have been put forward in the coalition parties' Economic Action Plan will there be any hope, any prospect for families, individuals, young people, small businesses, those seeking reward through their own effort, or people seeking a decent standard of living in this country, to prosper and to be looked after. The Hawke Labor Government is out of ideas. It writes around to its Ministers asking for ideas to be put in the Prime Minister's suggestion box. The suggestions that we have seen so far-we have been supplied with a fair number of copies of those letters to the Prime Minister-demonstrate just how far this Government is out of ideas, out of vision, out of initiative, out of steam, out of energy, out of hope and out of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table them.

—If Senator Faulkner invites me to table them he should look to the House of Representatives where Mr Peacock yesterday tabled the letter from Mr Kerin to the Prime Minister with his suggestion. And what a pathetic suggestion it was. The only thing he could think of was a strategy to put in place to bore it right up the collective noses of Graham Richardson and his mates in the conservation movement. That was his suggestion. It had nothing to do with improving the welfare of the people of Australia, just a great deal to do with trying to prove that he was more macho than Graham Richardson when it came to the power play within Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990s are Australia's decade of opportunity. They give us the opportunity to improve and to free up our economy by meaningful reforms in the industrial relations and wages systems. They give us the opportunity to safeguard our environment in a fashion which is genuine and committed, not in the fashion which is a cynical vote buying exercise, the only coin which is actually understood by members of the Australian Labor Party-and, by gee, they are pretty good at understanding coin in a fair number of ways. The 1990s give us the opportunity to develop our talents and our education system. They can be a decade of opportunity to really attack the issues of poverty, homelessness, drug abuse and social deprivation. They can provide an opportunity to do something about restoring our real international position-not sending our foreign Minister off on a publicly paid Christmas holiday in Europe at a very pleasant time of the year, attempting presumably to straighten out the east Europeans and then give everybody else the benefit of his advice on the way home.

But in order to take advantage of that decade of opportunity which is now available to us-the opportunity of economic reform, of environment protection, of educational progress, of a real assault upon the deprivation that exists in our society, of a restoration of our international position, of a restoration of the position of families, individuals and small businesses in Australia-it will require the election of a coalition government. It is the promise of 1990 and the decades ahead that there will be a coalition government to steer the destiny and opportunities of this country through the last decade of the twentieth century on the basis of our Economic Action Plan, that real leadership will be provided and a determination to tackle the fundamental problems and to get on with the job in the interest of all of the people of Australia, and not simply our sectional mates. We look forward to taking advantage of that decade of opportunity and providing the leadership which will ensure that in the twenty-first century the Australian nation is once again a decent nation which can be proud of its position in the world, and which can be proud of the building blocks of the individuals and families so sadly and so badly neglected by the tawdry administration of this Labor Hawke-Keating Government, now in its last dying and decaying days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the Opposition does not take this motion seriously or it would not have asked Senator Puplick to move it. We have all known for a very long time that he is an economic illiterate, and he confirmed it absolutely today. He made it absolutely clear today that he knows nothing about economic policy, because there was not one iota of substance whatsoever in his contribution. I did a crossword puzzle this morning which asked for the meaning of the word `thespian'. Of course, it means `actor'. That is exactly what we had today-quite a competent act by a person who could as easily have been quoting Shakespeare, except that he would have understood Shakespeare better.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick really made no contribution whatsoever; he was entirely negative. The saddest thing was that he was pretending to offer hope. Pretending to offer hope when in fact he offers none is a very cruel hoax. But I do not think Senator Puplick or most of his colleagues are cruel people. I think they just do not understand the implications of the things they are saying because they do not know anything about the lives of ordinary Australians, because they have never seen one except through a very long telescope. They do not understand that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We have tolerated the debate proceeding without a Minister being present in the chamber to this point, but I think it is complete contempt of the Senate and I call your attention to the state of the House. (Quorum formed)

—The contribution that I have already made was worth the crowd that was attracted, and I appreciate it. The problem is that Senator Puplick and the others who will be speaking on behalf of the Opposition, if the debate lasts that long, find it very hard to understand that ordinary Australian families will not be offered hope if they lose their jobs. Members of the Opposition do not understand the significance of employment because it is not an issue that operates on their horizon. It was very clear during the last time the Opposition was in government that it did not understand the importance of employment, because it created enormous levels of unemployment. We could talk about the economic consequences of it in terms of the blow-out in the deficit, the loss of tax revenue and the significant increase in expenditure, but I am not interested in talking about it in those terms today. I have done that before. It is still important but the fact is that the policies which the Opposition prescribes are heartless in the extreme and will create loss of jobs and Australian families will suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition continually fails to understand this matter. It cites figures that indicate that average weekly earnings for people in employment may not have risen as much as inflation, but household disposable income has increased because people have been in jobs. The most important transformation has been of those households that have gone from no job to one or those that have gone from one to two or to one and a half. It has made a fundamental transformation of those households. It has changed their lives significantly and substantially. We on this side of the House have dealt with large numbers of individual constituents-in my previous occupation I dealt with people who came in for assistance-who have been able to get jobs which have been created because of the successful economic policy of the Government.

The Opposition also does not understand the consequences for ordinary Australians of its industrial relations policy. It tries to follow the Thatcher strategy which has led to the division of Britain into two countries-the north and the south. Members of the Opposition would not understand because none of them who ever went there would travel north of London. They travel to the nice, comfortable parts, not where the real people live and where the consequences of the policies that Dr Hewson espouses, which have been put into practice by Mrs Thatcher, can be seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —You speak for yourself.
—I have just been there. I have just been to Sheffield. I have seen the consequences.
—You said that we do not go there.

—Absolutely, I know that members of the Opposition do not. I have been there and I have seen it. The decline in compassion by the Government of that country would be reflected here and is shown in the Opposition's attitude towards the long-term unemployed. To say that people who are unemployed for nine months should lose the benefit, even if it is no fault of theirs, if they happen to live in a town where a government's economic policy has destroyed the industry in which they have lived-55-year-old people who have been living for 35 years in places like Wollongong which the previous Government, the Fraser Government, destroyed--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on both sides of the chamber and I ask that Senator McMullan be heard without interruption.

—I appreciate your support, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I did not mind the interjections. They were a very useful indication of the attitude of the Opposition and I hope they are all faithfully recorded. Its attitude to the long-term unemployed is also reflected in its view about Jobstart and Skillshare. Every Skillshare program in Australia is under threat. I know that Senator Watson tries to pretend otherwise but we all know it is true. We can read the policies. Maybe we should not believe those policies any more than the promises made in the Whips meeting this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the question of up-front tertiary fees. The Opposition does not understand that that is a barrier to entry by ordinary Australians. It is true that university education has been a question of the poor subsidising the rich and we had to do something about it, but to introduce up-front tertiary fees, as proposed by the Opposition, provides a barrier to entry by ordinary Australians. Ordinary Australian families will not believe they are better off if their children cannot go on to tertiary education.

The Opposition does not understand the consequence of the proposed $100m cut in expenditure on Aboriginal affairs. Some parts of the proposal can be argued. I do not agree with any of what the Opposition is proposing, but I understand why it can say that it will abolish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission because, on the face of it, that is an administrative change. I do not agree with it, but we can say it is a legitimate difference of opinion about administrative policy. We can even say that about the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I do not agree with what the Opposition is proposing, but we can say that it is a legitimate, different view about administration. If we accept its figures, $20m would be saved, but the other $80m cut will have significant adverse consequences for Australians in greatest need. It is a credit to the Senate, to the Parliament and to the Government that we have just passed legislation that will allow assistance to be provided to Australians in greatest need in the Northern Territory through excisions that have been made possible by the recent amendments to the land rights legislation. But if we cut $100m from the funding to that Department, assistance to those people cannot possibly be forthcoming.

The Opposition also does not understand the consequences of its proposal to cut $100m from the overseas aid budget. Much could be said about that, but I just want to say one thing: it fails to understand in its phoney concern about the environment-a concern that Senator Puplick pretends to have everywhere but here in the Senate where he never speaks about it-that if one cuts the aid budget one reinforces that inevitable link between poverty and environmental degradation that is evident to every informed observer of the international scene. The desertification in Africa and the destruction of rainforests in other countries are an inevitable and inexorable outcome of poverty in those countries. The proposal to cut $100m from overseas aid-if one pretends that it is not an act of social and international cruelty-shows that the Opposition does not understand the consequences of what it is doing.

We know that the Opposition does understand the consequences of what it is doing in one area but it hopes the voters will not understand. That relates to the changes to the capital gains tax. We had an interesting debate about that recently. Senator Chaney got upset because I said that it was a reflection of the priorities of the Liberal Party and the National Party that they proposed to give back $450m to the wealthiest in our community and take it away from the poorest in our community. It remains exactly the same today. It is a statement of the Opposition's priorities, and there are many other elements of that indication of priorities that can be outlined.

The Opposition understands the consequences of its policy with regard to wages policy. It would abolish the wages policy that has brought fair wage increases across the board in Australia and which still enables changes that facilitate improved efficiency and shop floor reform, in favour of what is called the free market system, otherwise called the pilot system of industrial relations. It would have led to an enormous blow-out in wages for the few and the powerful and no wage increases for those in the weakest positions. Plentiful opportunities for the strong and devil take the hindmost is the wages policy of the Opposition. It would lead to further division in our society, a blow-out of wages in areas where we cannot afford it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which wages policy is that? Which one?

—It is true that the Opposition has several wage policies. I regret to say there is one I think it will enforce, because Senator Stone actually drives the bus. Mr Peacock is only there on the front like one of those things that used to be on the bows of sailing ships for decoration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is deliberately trying to mislead the Australian people about micro-economic reform. Every independent commentator says that Australia is leading the world in micro-economic reform and that the micro-economic reform program in Australia is greater than it has ever been. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade made that clear. The book from which I quoted the last time we had this debate, by Keating and Dixon, makes it clear. It was made very clear in an article yesterday in the Age by Kenneth Davidson who very effectively criticised the phoney micro-economic reform exhortations of the Opposition as those which will not lead to effective change. It is quite evident that all those informed analysts will make it clear to the voters what the Liberals know but do not wish to understand.

I said previously that the capital gains tax versus cuts argument that we had before said something interesting about the priorities of the Opposition. I will quote from a very interesting advertisement about the Thatcher Government that appeared in newspapers during the last British election:

The Conservative manifesto does not say anything about reducing unemployment; it does not say anything about improving the health service; it does not say anything about investing in education; it does not say anything about building more houses . . .
That could apply equally to the Economic Action Plan, and so could the conclusion. It says:
. . . but it says a lot about the Conservatives.

That is absolutely right. The Opposition says nothing about the issues that affect the lives of Australians in greatest need. It wants to give $450m to people who are already generating significant income through capital gain and who ought to pay tax on that gain, just as everybody who generates income in any other way does. It wants to give back that money to those people and take it away from the people in greatest need.

In the remaining minutes of my contribution I have to say that the saddest thing about the Opposition contribution is that it ignored all the positives. I regret to say that about Senator Puplick because it may be his last chance to speak in the Senate, which is a great pity because he makes a greater contribution than the person who ousted him from No. 1 on the ticket.
