The Liberal Party organisation is incapable of coping with that situation, so we have to put up with that unfortunate outcome. The opposition pretends that nothing good is happening in Australia. It is a propensity that people have when they have not been in opposition quite long enough but have been in Parliament for a long time. They need a bit more experience in opposition, and the people of Australia will give it to them.

The Opposition has failed to mention the benefits to ordinary Australian families of Medicare. The Government is not surprised because the Opposition does not want to talk about health policy. A wonderful exposition of the failure to outline the nature of the Opposition health policy has been a recurrent feature of the last 12 months of public debate in Australia-it is always just around the corner. It is just like the recovery in the fortunes of the Bond Corporation-it is just coming around the corner, if we only wait a little longer. I think the Opposition health policy is about as viable as the Bond Corporation at the moment.

The Opposition has failed to say anything about school retention rates because when it was in power the rates used to be in the low 30s and now they are rising through the 50s to the 60s, and continuing to rise. Ordinary Australian families know that their kids have a better chance of a career if they stay at school and go on to tertiary education. The Opposition has also failed to mention the family assistance supplement which builds on a useful initiative of Senator Chaney when he was Minister. I do not criticise that initiative-it only went half way, but it was a good start. I acknowledge that. It has been substantially improved by Mr Howe and is the best family assistance package that Australia has ever had. It has been indexed for the first time, as are family allowances.

The Opposition failed to mention anything about jobs. It tried to pretend that the jobs that have been created were not real jobs. Senator Puplick probably does not know, because he is an economic illiterate, but most members on the Liberal Party front bench would know, because at least they have probably read something about economics, that 90 per cent of the jobs created during the term of the Hawke Government have been in the private sector, whereas in the Fraser period it was 45 per cent-twice the percentage. We want none of that phoney rubbish about real jobs. This Government has created more jobs at a higher rate then any other member country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, and they have been real jobs.

The Opposition failed to mention the home and community care scheme that is saying to old people, `You don't have to go into institutionalised care. That which we've all known you've always wanted is now possible: you can receive quality assistance in your own home.' That is in the interests of society because it is cheaper, it is what the people want and it lends them dignity. The Opposition failed to say anything about retirement incomes at all. We used to hear a lot about the concern the Opposition had for old people when it thought it had a vote winner on the assets test. The Opposition now wants to keep the assets test because it is fair, just and directs the income to the people in need. It has given up the decision to get rid of that.

We have heard nothing more about the aged because, for the first time ever, the pension is 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and we have had a doubling of the superannuation coverage. We have had one of the great equity distributions in Australian history. In the past only the very wealthy and people in government employment had superannuation. It has now been fundamentally transformed. Australian families know that their welfare is substantially enhanced because the breadwinner or breadwinners in that family have one or two superannuation schemes. This means that in retirement their income will be substantially enhanced and they will have that dignity to which they are entitled. The Opposition also failed to mention the question of the implications to ordinary Australian families of the proposed changes in the taxation scheme.

I do not pretend that there has been no pain to ordinary Australian people with higher interest rates. The Australian people demand that that pain should be for some reason, that there should be an outcome in terms of improved economic performance and restructuring of the Australian economy. The statistics increasingly show, as Mr Elliott and the Australian Chamber of Commerce have correctly said, that the preconditions for economic growth, a sustained fall in interest rates, and a reformed economy into the 1990s have been established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I think is interesting about the film industry in Australia and overseas is that somehow or other film makers manage to make films that capture various parts of the ongoing human experience. Senator Puplick's contribution this afternoon reminded me of that famous scene in the current film When Harry meets Sally. There is a lot of great acting.
—I think I know the scene you mean.

—The honourable senator says that he thinks he knows the scene I mean. The film to which I wish to refer after five weeks in this place is not When Harry meets Sally but rather the film called, Sex, Lies and Videotape. There is very little of the first in this place, and Senator Collins managed to get a bit of the last, but probably the middle bit is overwhelming after five weeks in this place. The debate this afternoon is probably as good as any to illustrate that particular exercise. I think politicians are very happy to wander around and blame the community for its cynicism in politics, when most of it is engendered by politicians themselves. What they do is what has been done here this afternoon; that is, they claim-this is in an election context-that if elected to office the sun will shine brighter, everybody will be happy, all our problems will disappear and we will all live happily ever after. Nobody in the real world believes that and everybody in this place knows that that cannot happen. However, in the true spirit of the film Sex, Lies and Videotape, we are quite happy to pursue that particular course, but we should not then blame the public for being cynical about politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: The theme of the debate this afternoon is that the Government does not care at all about families. If anybody in the Opposition was asked outside this chamber whether he believed that, he would say no. Nobody in his right mind would believe that any elected government would not care about families. The Government says that the Opposition does not care about families. If any Government member were asked that question outside this chamber he would say no, he did not believe that either. Those lies are able to pass as truth in this chamber. That is part of the passing facade, as it were, of politics in this country.

The facts of the matter are that any government of any political persuasion in this country attempts to introduce policies that it believes will benefit families. Whether it does or not is then a matter of fact. Whether another set of policies would actually improve the matter is theoretical and will always remain so, because at any one time only one set of policies can be applied to the economy and, hence, we know what happens. We suggest that with other policies in place things will get better or deteriorate. After five weeks here why do we insist-I would like to characterise it as lies, but I suppose we are not allowed to-on making gross overstatements of what is going on?

Under the Labor Administration many families have had it very hard. The Government has broken many of the promises it has made to the electorate time and again, election after election. Quite frankly, that is no different from what the Fraser Government did, and it will be absolutely no different from what a Peacock Government would do if it were elected to office at the next election. In office the Government will suggest that in the light of current events some of those policies are no longer applicable and something else will have to happen. Those are the circumstances with which we are faced.

I was given hope by the fact that in my home State of Queensland at the last election the Liberal Party and the National Party ran a mud-slinging campaign, a sloganeering campaign, and a campaign of lies. It was an old-style campaign. For once, the Labor Party ran a campaign-I say for once as this is the first time I have ever seen it run such a campaign-which actually stuck to policies and discussed nothing other than policies. In fact, the present Premier of Queensland insisted that every one of his candidates should not even respond to the mud that was being thrown. As I travelled around the electorate during that election period I heard more and more people saying, `At last somebody is actually talking about what we want to hear. We are sick to death of the mud-slinging in this political operation', and they voted accordingly. This has not been commented on in the press but I believe that it is an indication of what went on during that Queensland election.

I was very proud of the people of Queensland. For the first time they said very clearly and very definitely to politicians, `Stop making the types of promises you know you cannot keep. Stop suggesting that the world will look better and the sun will shine when you get into government, because it will not. Let us hear the truth. We are quite able to take the truth. We want to know what it is and we want to know whether your policies will make it marginally better'. If any people in politics actually suggest that they will ever do anything more, in terms of one set of policies rather than another, they are lying. On most occasions, any government in office has only one decision to make; it does not have a choice. It would like to have a choice. I am quite sure that, when Senator Chaney was in government, he would have loved on many occasions to have had a choice rather than do what he was compelled to do. But in government those choices are not there. I am not talking about legislation, as this chamber always has a couple of choices on legislation. I am talking about the day-to-day administration where there are not too many choices.

Quite frankly, if one looks at what the Government has done to date, one sees a whole host of areas where major improvements could have been made which would have significantly benefited ordinary families. Probably one of those areas which would have had the most beneficial effect would have been for the Government to avoid deregulating the banks. There is absolutely no reason why we could not have run, as we have done in the past, separate housing interest rates and commercial interest rates if that is what we wanted. There are benefits and there are disadvantages in running two rates. If we had wanted to do that and if those benefits and those disadvantages had been explained to the community, we could have made a choice. We did not have that choice and families have suffered significantly since then.

Turning to the Opposition's policies, it is interesting that it wants to look essentially at families. I certainly applaud that. That is a nice change. The fundamental structure of our society should be given far more support than has been given by the policies of all administrations. When I look through a whole range of policies I have to ask: What will happen to the families of Aboriginals if we take away $100m? What will happen to the families of unemployed people after nine months if we take away $1,500m? On that latter point I wish to quote from an article by Greg Sheridan. I think most people would agree that he has never been classified as being any further to the left than Ghengis Khan. In this article he says:
After nine months your dole will be stopped unless you qualify for a special benefit.
To qualify for the special benefit you will be interviewed by welfare bureaucrats.
Yet to qualify for the dole now you need regular interviews with bureaucrats.
Where is the change?
Many of the long-term unemployed are in bad shape.

If these interviews are to involve intensive counselling, much less any rehabilitation or retraining, they will involve still more bureaucrats, an increase in the welfare state, and will save no money.
If the policy does not involve such extensive counselling I would say it would survive about three or four weeks of implementation.

I think that is a fair summary. I think that is precisely what would happen, because the policy is unworkable unless we change a lot of other expectations within our society. That can be done. There are plenty of models of societies that we could emulate; the United States is one. We could be quite happy to have beggars on our streets. We could expend vast sums of money turning our houses into fortresses and even larger sums of money on building prisons-the growth industry in the United States. We could do all those things. They are choices that are open to us as a society. Quite frankly, my view is that most people believe that the type of society we have is the one which they prefer.

Unemployment must always be acknowledged as a cost to the community. We cannot choose that it not be a cost-it will always be a cost-but we can choose how we deal with that cost. We can pay for it by having an increased prison population, an increase in crime and a lack of security or we can pay for it by giving people a small amount of money to be able to feed themselves, clothe themselves and house themselves. I suggest that the latter option benefits not only those people but also us. A society which cares for people in need is a much more attractive society for everybody. We might not have as high a standard of living, but we would certainly have a better quality of life.

One of the interesting facts about many religions is that they often managed to get right-even if they did not manage to get a lot of other things right-that it is preferable to help others in need, not to dump on them when they are in need. Translating that into an Australianism, one does not kick somebody when he is down. That is illustrative of who we are as a society. I worry that the promotion of so many policies which depend on greed as their motivation will undermine who we are as a community and will change us into a mini-United States, a mini-Britain, or a mini something else. We will not be an Australian society.

I wonder about the families of recently arrived migrants and the proposed cuts in that area. I wonder about the families of students and the cuts that are being proposed that will affect them. I wonder about the families of the sick and the disabled because of the projected cuts in those areas. They are all families more in need than others, yet the proposal is that those cuts will somehow or other benefit others. How will that be translated? How will the money move across? It will move across in a number of interesting ways but, most definitely, if we look at the policies which have been identified in a National Party document, those families which benefit will exclusively be in the upper income bracket. I do not think that gives us a better society. So let us lower the expectations of what politicians can do. Let us be a little more truthful. But I think we should also say that, at the end of the day, a society which is caring is a far better society in which to live than a society based on greed and avarice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the initiative of the Opposition, the Senate is spending its last hours before Christmas considering the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The unnecessary hardship facing many Australians and their families as a result of the Governments broken promises, failed policies and the hope for 1990 offered by the Coalition's Economic Action Plan.

We brought this forward because we think that there is a great deal of concern in the community about the pressures that people are under. We believe that most Australians think it appropriate that the Senate spend some little time considering the issues of the pressures on Australian families.

I was quite taken by a couple of Senator Macklin's comments. Senator McMullan's speech-he was the first Labor senator to speak-struck me as typical of Labor's contribution to these debates during this session. Senator McMullan did not once acknowledge that there are Australian families in difficulty. At no point in his speech did he advert to the real pressures on Australian families and to the fact that there is massive disaffection in Labor's heartland. I agree with Senator Macklin that there is a lot of disaffection with politicians generally. I do not deny that. But I would have thought that an honourable senator with the experience of Senator McMullan, who has great experience in the Labor Party organisation and in campaigning, would be familiar with the fact that it is in Labor's own heartland that there is the most disaffection. That disaffection relates to the genuine hardship which many people are suffering under the Labor Government. It is not hard to explain that hardship.

Often enough in debate in this place I have quoted the fact that whilst it is true that there has been an expansion in the number of jobs under the accord, average earnings have declined and award wages have declined in real terms. When one combines the wage situation, the tax situation and the interest rate situation it is not surprising that a substantial number of Australian families are desperate. Senator Macklin said that we all exaggerate. He was trying to avoid the Standing Orders provision which precludes one saying that another honourable senator has lied. Let me put what I want to put in this debate in the flattest--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Is there a standing order under which I can correct Senator Chaney? He has said things about me which are untrue.
—No.
—Senator Chaney just said that I did not refer to certain things to which I did refer.
—Order! There is no such standing order.

—Senator McMullan is an experienced enough honourable senator to know that that was a specious point of order. The simple fact is that there is a close relationship between the plight of Australian families and the problems of poverty which are causing such concern to the welfare agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: The welfare authorities have been reporting to the people of Australia that we have problems in Australia of the new poor. After nearly seven years of the Labor Government the Reverend John Livingstone, of the Anglican Church's welfare division, was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 December as saying:
. . . there are many more families in need of welfare that the charities will never see.
``A lot of them find it hard to approach welfare agencies,'' he said. ``There is a lot of pride involved.''
Notwithstanding that, Mr Livingstone goes on to say:
. . . about half Careforce's Christmas clients this year have never received welfare before.
``High interest rates and the high cost of accommodation are breaking people in the middle range. It's creating a new poor who are stretched to breaking point.
``Even people on what used to be reasonable wages are having to choose between paying their gas or their electricity bill this Christmas.''

That is part of the reality of Australia. Some attention from Senator McMullan to what the Government thinks is the cause of that hardship and what could be done about it might have been welcomed by his constituency. The Opposition is saying that the explanation for what is going on is clear. It relates to the fundamental economic matters which were raised by Senator McMullan in the debate. It relates to our economic failure to be a sufficiently competitive country, to be a sufficiently productive country. In a recent study the Sydney City Mission, another welfare agency, estimated that up to 30,000 Australian children, including 9,000 aged from 12 to 15, remain homeless and that the number of children in poverty is double that of 10 years ago. As I said before, that is a simple function of declining real wages under Labor, hugely expanded interest rates and, of course, a tax burden which is still very heavy.

I think Senator Puplick in his contribution talked about some comparative interest rates. Let me do the same. The interest rate on Commonwealth Bankcard in 1984 was 18 per cent; it is now 23 per cent. It is to be 24.6 per cent next year. Interest on Mastercard from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia has risen from 18 per cent to 23 per cent. Housing mortgages have risen from 12.5 per cent to 17 per cent and small overdrafts from 14 per cent up to 22.75 per cent.

Mr Deputy President, I am sure you have a lot of contact in your electorate of Queensland. I am sure that you would be familiar with the reality that there are very many Australian families in very real financial difficulty, notwithstanding the expansion of employment, notwithstanding the statistics about household disposable income, which is what Senator Button chooses to talk about. But when one looks at what the University of New South Wales has analysed and found within the last few weeks, one finds that there is no escaping the simple reality that families with children have been hardest hit during the period of the Labor Government.

The study by the University of New South Wales estimates that on average the increases in house prices and interest rates have led to families with post-1986 mortgages-that is 70 per cent of those with mortgages-paying out an additional $48 per week in repayments. Mr Acting Deputy President, a succession of statistics of that sort can be produced to explain the reality which, if you have ever been in your electorate, you would have personally experienced as I have personally experienced. I refer to the fact that many families are finding themselves the new poor, and many families which find themselves directed to the attention of welfare agencies, who, in the past, would have been proud to proclaim their permanent independence. The relationship between the caring for the independent middle-income earners of Australia and the relief of poverty is very clear. It has become far clearer under Labor because of the toppling of many of those middle-income people into poverty and into having to beg.

It is in that context that what the Opposition is saying becomes significant. Senator Macklin suggested that any politician who comes in and promises that we can completely revolutionise things is lying. In a broad sense I would accept that. There is no way of suddenly clicking one's fingers, passing a law and suddenly solving all of the nation's problems. Let me remind the Senate that what the Opposition has done-and I do not believe that any Opposition in history has ever done this-is identify not merely the winners under its programs but also its losers. It identified the truth and accepted the truth that if one is to provide instantly additional benefits to large sectors of society, then there has to be a transfer from one area to another. The Opposition makes no secret of that. It has set out in the Economic Action Plan the fact that it is prepared to reduce government expenditure by $2.7 billion because it wishes to deliver $2 billion of that as tax relief to the families which have borne the brunt of Labor's economic mismanagement and something under half a billion dollars in the reduction of capital gains tax and its substitution with a speculative gains tax, which, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating)--Senator Cook-You're giving it to the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick up the half-interjection from Senator Cook, who has come into the chamber. In fact, in recent weeks his own Treasurer has admitted that the repeal of the capital gains tax and its substitution with a speculative gains tax will benefit the small business and the farming community, which accounts for 700,000 people in Australia. Let me add to that: there are 4 million people in superannuation funds and a million Australians who own shares who will benefit by the repeal of the tax. It is absolutely absurd to suggest that this is a benefit for the rich.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the main body of relief which is being offered. Under Labor-and the Institute of Family Studies bears this out, as the other welfare reports bear it out and as the University of New South Wales bears it out-the burden has unfairly been focused on families with children. For that reason we are offering direct, immediate tax relief for middle income Australians to the tune of $2 billion. That tax relief comes in the form of tax rebates for all children; an entirely novel-for Australia-tax rebate for people with child-care expenses, that is, the vast majority of families which now require two incomes to survive and, therefore, incur child-care expenses in the process; and additional liberalisation of the dependent spouse rebate. That amounts to $2 billion directly into the pockets of Australians with children.

What is the priority? The point made by Senator McMullan is that we are demonstrating our priorities. The truth is that to get that $2 billion we have to reduce the generosity and scope of some other government programs, and we make no apology for being honest about that. We can save close to over $1 billion on social security in ways which are not harsh and which are socially positive. The bulk of that money comes from reducing the unemployment benefit from one which can be taken by Australians on a permanent basis without limitation of time to one which is in line with other countries which provide unemployment insurance or benefit on a time limited basis. I think there is widespread public acceptance that it is socially and economically sensible to make that change.

Senator McMullan raised the question of Aboriginal affairs. I simply say to Senator McMullan that, whether or not he believes it, I believe there would be very few people who have direct experience of Aboriginal advancement programs who would not admit that there has been considerable waste and maladministration. A reduction of about 10 per cent is proposed in this area, which equals the increase in expenditure this year. The Opposition believes that that can be done in a way which will still enable the effective delivery of services to the Aboriginals for whom Senator McMullan expressed concern-and I express my own concern for them. We believe that this is an area in which there could be greater efficacy and efficiency of administration. We have reduced payments to the States and make no apology for that because the States have enormous capacities to reduce their costs in ways such as contracting out.

In this debate we have identified two simple propositions. The first is that the group in Australia which has been most put upon by this Government-that is, the group which is most disadvantaged-is families with children. That is not a politician's statement. The work which has been done by the University of New South Wales following that done by the Institute of Family Studies shows that that is clearly so. If Government senators do not have enough contact with their electorates to know that it is true they are not doing their jobs. The second simple proposition that we put forward is that it is a matter of social justice to give relief to those people. That relief must cost and we have identified where the cost will come from.

In the minute that remains for me to contribute to this debate, I will focus on what Senator McMullan referred to as the major economic underlying matters. The truth of the matter is that we can increase the welfare of the Australian people only if we make Australia a more productive country. Again, the Economic Action Plan sets out in detail proposals which will make Australia a more productive society. Whether it is in accelerating the rate of labour market reform; whether it is in accelerating the rate of reform of the waterfront and coastal shipping; whether it is in contracting out government services to get efficiency for the taxpayers' dollar and a better deal for consumers, there is no shortage of detail in the Opposition's proposals for that more productive character to be put into Australia. The national Parliament should focus on the fact that this country needs to be both fairer and more productive, and the Opposition has a detailed program to ensure that it is both. I welcome the brief opportunity this afternoon to address some of those issues. I hope that we will hear from the remaining Labour speaker in this debate an admission of the causes of the disaffection with his party which is so obvious-including in the State of New South Wales-and which was so accurately summed up by the Labor Council of New South Wales which said that this Government certainly has not brought home the bacon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by assuring Senator Chaney that he will be hearing no such admission from me, but I will certainly speak about some relevant matters concerning the State of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that I should begin this contribution by congratulating Senator Puplick for proposing this matter of public importance. It seemed to be some form of a self-valedictory; probably Senator Puplick believes that his speech on this matter of public importance may well be his last contribution in the Senate as an influential Liberal frontbencher. He knows there is every chance that in the forthcoming election he will lose his seat as he is number three on the coalition Senate ticket in New South Wales, and he knows there is every chance that an election will be called before the Senate sits again on 20 February. I can understand why Senator Puplick is so worried about his impending defeat-crashing to defeat along with Mr Peacock and the rest of the Liberals-so I forgive him for this last-ditch stand on the final day of sitting of the Senate for this year. Other Government senators should also forgive Senator Puplick because--

TALK.START.PARA: —I forgive him.

—Thank you. After all, most of us at this time of year are imbued with the Christmas spirit. We have been sitting for five weeks and it is understandable if, after five weeks, Senator Puplick's judgment has been a little affected by the fact that he has been away from home for so long.

SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised that he and the Opposition want any examination of the so-called Economic Action Plan of the Liberal Party of Australia. We have heard a little about what is supposed to be the impact on families of the Economic Action Plan and Government policies. I had not intended to talk about that at great length but, as Senator Chaney has challenged me to do so, it is only appropriate that I oblige. We should recognise that the Economic Action Plan has a very simple economic prescription: take as much as possible from the needy groups in the community to provide what is, in effect, a substantial tax cut to the wealthy through the abolition of the capital gains tax. The Economic Action Plan purports to strengthen the family in Australia-it claims that the family is the cornerstone of the plan-and that is the big lie of Australian politics, because the Liberal Party's definition of family is unbelievably narrow.

I am happy to associate myself with the remarks that Senator Macklin made about the definition of the family, because the Liberal Party defines the family by political expediency alone. The Liberal Party's definition of the family arises from political research in marginal seats; the only families that it cares about are those that reside in marginal seats. There is not a skerrick of concern in the Liberal Party for disadvantaged families-for Aboriginal families, sole parents, families on low incomes, the unemployed or ethnic and aged Australians. The Opposition defines families as those groups whose votes it needs to win the election.

The Economic Action Plan is nothing more than a cynical vote-buying exercise as some sort of answer to the Opposition's own problems. The Economic Action Plan is not designed to deal with the fundamental challenges of modern Australia and the crucial direction of government economic policy. The Liberals have fallen into the trap of mindless negativism, an example of which was Senator Puplick's speech-simplistic criticism of the Government. The Economic Action Plan is nothing more than a blatant and straightforward attempt to bribe the Australian electorate.

But the Opposition cannot get its propaganda right. Take interest rates, for example. The Liberals' so-called best chance to fluke an election win is on the issue of interest rates. They have been effectively bombed, sabotaged, on that by their own Federal Party President, John Elliott. He has blown interest rates right out of the water as an election issue. I was very pleased to pick up the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday of this week and read an article entitled `Libs upset as Elliott speaks out of turn again'. The article states:

The Federal president of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, angered his federal parliamentary colleagues yet again yesterday, this time by predicting interest rates would fall by as much as 5 per cent next year.
Mr Elliott also said he would like to see the Australian dollar fall to as low as 68 US cents.
Recently there have been many conflicting statements on interest rates by Liberal-National Party spokesmen. I will mention a few examples. On 27 November Mr Peacock said:
We've said it'll take us through the first term of government to lower interest rates. I mean, I'd love to say to people we can get them down in the first week or two we come in, but you can't.
On the same day Senator Stone said:
This Government has put us in a situation where undoubtedly interest rates will stay high for some time.
On 7 December John Howard, the deposed Liberal Leader, said:
I don't think that anyone in the Opposition is running around saying that we can ever go back to the halcyon days of very low interest rates until we get on top of our trade and debt problems.
Mr Peacock, this time on 14 December, said:
When the market sees that we are putting [our] policies in place, inflation and interest rates will come down . . . Over the three-year period there will be massive reductions.
And then on Tuesday of this week, when he was asked when interest rates will fall, John Elliott said:
About five weeks before an election . . . They'll probably come down 1, 2, 3-in my view they could come down as much as 4 or 5 per cent.

So there is very little consistency in what the Liberal Party is saying. In the Christmas spirit I would like to ask Senator Puplick and Senator Chaney to table their Christmas message to John Elliott. I would imagine it would be something like `We want your money for the election campaign, but we certainly don't want your opinions'.

But in this debate, given that it is Christmas and we are about to wind up and have a holiday period, I think we ought to place on record what a disastrous and pathetic year the Federal Opposition has had. What about the contemptible tactics that the Liberal Party used to get rid of John Howard-the Howard sacking? Of course, John Howard was a very unpopular leader-though not as unpopular as Mr Peacock-but he was a decent enough and intelligent man. What about the machiavellian and slimy tactics of the Liberal Party? Senator Puplick was one of the gang of Four Corners that was responsible for the demise of John Howard. Senator Chaney was in it up to his neck as were Mr Wilson Tuckey and Mr John Moore. We all know what they were on about. What has been the ultimate result for the Liberal Party of that change of leadership? The result has been that it has elected as leader the most unpopular political leader of a major Australian political party in our history. That has been its achievement this year.

I have already mentioned the daily contradictions between Senator Stone, Mr Elliott and Mr Peacock in their remarks on interest rates. What about their failure in elections held this year? We receive a wry smile from Senator Chaney whose Party lost the Western Australian election. It was a failure. This year his Party lost the Tasmanian election-another failure. This year his Party lost the South Australian election-another failure. In Queensland his Party came third. The National Party lost the Queensland election. I say to Senator Chaney that there is only one thing better than the Liberal Party coming second in an election, and that is when it comes third as it did in Queensland. The Liberal Party has failed miserably in all its electoral tests in 1989.

What about Andrew Peacock's complete lack of understanding of his own Party's industrial and wages policies? What about his complete lack of capacity and courage to face the Australian press? He will not even have a news conference. Finally, of course, as the good news to end the year for the Liberal Party, a news poll shows that it is even further behind at the end of 1989 than it was at the beginning of the year. It has not had much of a year. It is hardly surprising that it comes in and wastes the last few hours of this sitting of the Senate to whinge about its own performance and Australian politics over the previous 12 months.

When we look at the Liberal Party's disastrous year we should not forget environment policy. Senator Puplick, the proposer of this matter of public importance, has, I believe, the worst job of any politician in the Western world. That job is, of course, to be the Liberal and National Party spokesperson on the environment. He is the person who has to sell the Opposition's neanderthal environment policies to the Australian people. The Australian people form a sophisticated and very aware electorate. Senator Puplick is the person who has to justify why the Liberals would have dammed the Franklin River. He is the person who has to justify its policy of logging rainforests, mining in Kakadu, protecting only some national parks in Australia from mining, and so on. Because it is Christmas, I am sensitive to Senator Puplick's difficult task. In the Australian newspaper, when he spoke about the monumental difficulties he faced in convincing the Opposition that it needed a better environment policy, he said:

I accept that it's my neck that's on the line if the whole thing falls in a heap. If I can't convince my colleagues to go in a particular direction or to embrace some different policies, that would be a mark of substantial personal failure as a politician. I don't think I'd be of much use to the Liberal Party.

Quite so. Frankly, I think that Senator Puplick has failed to convince his own colleagues and his own Party, and he should seriously consider resigning his position as shadow Minister for the environment. A proposal of a matter of public importance about broken promises is the greatest hypocrisy imaginable from Senator Puplick, a New South Wales Liberal senator. Nick Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, has broken 150 promises since he came into Government, which is an absolutely outrageous sell-out of the New South Wales electorate. A statement by George Bernard Shaw sums it up. He said that we are all liars to people we do not care for. This is certainly the Liberal Party's attitude, Mr Greiner's attitude, to broken promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the discussion has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-fourth report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

It is customary to say a few words at the end of a session. I just want to make a few points. This year the Senate has sat later or closer to Christmas than it has ever sat in its history. We sat for 25 weeks, which is the greatest number of weeks that the Senate has sat in recent years, and almost half as long again as the House of Representatives this year. In 1989 we sat for 500 hours, of which approximately 170 hours were devoted to debating Government legislation, and we considered 200 Bills. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation took 40 hours for consideration; my colleague Senator Tate, and probably Senator Peter Baume largely on the other side, should be congratulated for their patience and receive commiserations in respect of the handling of that Bill. We will be utilising new procedures next year to facilitate the consideration of legislation. I hope all senators will give these procedures every chance to succeed. Anything which improves the effectiveness of the chamber is worthy of support.

I would like to thank you, Mr President, for your success in continuing to manage smoothly the operations and proceedings of the Senate this year, and I would like to thank the Deputy President and the temporary chairmen of committees for their control, humour and tact, all of which qualities you, Mr President, displayed as well, in the face of sometimes quite unruly debate. I also thank the Whips and Deputy Whips of all parties without whose behind-the-scenes negotiations-and, in Senator McKiernan's case, sometimes in-front-of-the-scenes negotiations-this chamber probably would be quite unworkable. I also thank you, Mr Clerk, and the other Clerks and officials of the Senate for the long hours you devote to the smooth functioning of the Senate. It is nice to see Senator Haines taking a vigorous interest in the proceedings of the chamber, perhaps, as she said this morning, for the last time. I would like to thank all other officers of the Parliament, including Hansard staff, the staff of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department, who have maintained their usual high standards of service to senators and members of the House of Representatives. I would personally like to thank the Manager of Government Business, Senator Robert Ray, for the smooth way in which he has run the business of the Senate. Sometimes he has been fired up a little, particularly by minor parties--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Not the Australian Democrats. I do not regard them as a minor party. Senator Robert Ray has done a particularly good job. Craddock Morton, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer, has been a great help, I believe, to all senators, particularly Ministers, and has paid great attention to the Government program in the interests of the Opposition, the Democrats and the Independent senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to wish all senators and staff associated with the Senate a very happy Christmas. I particularly hope honourable senators from the Opposition have a very happy Christmas because they are going to have a lousy new year. I wish all Opposition senators luck when they go to that Opposition conference on how to be a Minister and I commend to the Opposition the immortal words of Peter Shack: `The real barriers to progress are to be found in yourselves, and once you rid yourselves of prejudices, blind spots, ignorance and really set some goals, then you can achieve'. So I hope Opposition senators get a little way along that track at their conference in January.

TALK.START.PARA: —He who laughs last laughs loudest.
—Yes, I know. I wish all senators a very good Christmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition senators I would like to join with the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) in all but his concluding remarks and to thank the many people in this building who have provided services for us during this year. I also thank you, Mr President. The task of the President is not an easy one. We have asked you to be the President of all the Senate, and I think you have done a great deal of work towards that end. I particularly congratulate you on your efforts with respect to the Senate budget, which I think is of long term significance to this place, and I thank you for your efforts in that. I thank the Clerks who, I think, without fear or favour give us their advice, and I acknowledge it and its high quality.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank everybody from Hansard through to the Library, the catering staff, the attendants-the chamber attendants in particular, who come rushing about in their endlessly courteous way-the security people who keep us safe, not in our beds but in our offices, and the car drivers who drive most honourable senators around. I would like to make mention of the gardeners who are starting to add their touches to this building in a way which is proving to be very attractive. We will have not been able to get a goatherd to look after the goats that Senator Button would like to have wandering about on his garden, but I am sure he will find the offices of the Opposition a perfectly satisfactory place, although it is a rather stony courtyard on which to graze sheep or goats.

As far as the Senate itself is concerned, I just acknowledge the work which has been done by a number of people, including Senator Robert Ray and, on our side, Senator Hamer, concerning Senate procedures. As regards the long term operation of this Parliament, the work that has been done this year has been most significant, and I express the hope that the procedures which we have put in place for next year will prove as successful as I believe they could be. I do not think there is any doubt that but for the indefatigable efforts of Senator Hamer on our side we would not have seen the formation of a corporate view on a matter which involved essentially a free vote, and I very sincerely thank him for devoting so much time and attention to consulting so closely with all of his colleagues. I think that Senator Robert Ray's similar interest in seeing some progress has meant that we have actually got the potential for another substantial leap in the Senate's activities.

It is quite a long time since the Senate made a quantum lift in the way it operated. The period of the early 1970s was a very constructive and imaginative time. Again, there were notable contributions from both sides of politics, with the late Senator Murphy on the Labor side and a series of people on our side who were party to the standing committee and Estimates committee procedures being established. I personally express the hope that the procedures that we have put in place for the more careful consideration of legislation will prove to be very valuable for good government in Australia and for reducing transgressions on individual liberty. The only point that I make-and I raise it for long term consideration, because I think it is foolish to pretend that we can function as a completely objective house of review in what is a party political chamber-is whether we might adopt in government a rather more sensible view towards changes to legislation than we have in the past. Governments of all political persuasions have regarded the letter of the legislation that they bring into the Parliament as something that should not be interfered with by Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no Ministers in the Senate now, I suppose.

—No Ministers in the Senate is probably a good idea, too, but I will leave that for others to debate. Even in jest, I do not embrace that fearful proposition, largely because I want to get out of the building alive.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing mentioned by Senator Button was the long periods of sittings, and again I express the view it is inevitable that, if the Senate is to live up to the changes that it is testing next year, longer sittings for the Senate will occur. Compared to the sittings of parliaments in other countries, our length of sitting is not great. If senators continue to wish to add functions then I would simply suggest that the Senate will continue to add to the period of sitting under which it operates.

I would also like to express my great personal gratitude to Senator Peter Baume. I formally represent the Opposition in Aboriginal affairs in this chamber. I was aware of the enormous task of dealing with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation. Having a previous Minister with the ongoing interest in Aboriginal affairs that Senator Baume has was, I think, a splendid thing not just for the Opposition but for the Aboriginal community. The Government accepted over 100 amendments after 40 hours of debate. I believe that whilst we opposed the ATSIC legislation it certainly left this chamber in a much better form than it entered the chamber. I simply thank Senator Peter Baume and the whole group of senators-I will not name them all because the last time I did I left one or two out-who gave a lot of attention to that matter. They gave Senator Baume their support and demonstrated an enormous interest in that area of policy over the last 12 months.

Everybody is sick to death of being here. I think they are all desperate for Christmas and I wish everybody a very happy and restful Christmas. For 1990, I wish us success and I hope that Senator Button will enjoy his fresh period in Opposition rather more than I have enjoyed the one I am just concluding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I would like to endorse Senator Button's comments, including the last couple of sentences, and to add my thanks to the people who make the Senate operate, inasmuch as it does operate at all. They include people such as the attendants who have already been mentioned. I would point out to Senator Chaney that there is indeed a qualified goatherd among the attendants in this place. He may care to make his acquaintance some time.
—The one who looks after the Democrats?

—No, I do not know about that at all actually. I think he probably finds something far more appealing in the Opposition. I refer also to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) journalists who decide what volume, I suspect, they are going to tune various speakers up to and judiciously wind down those who are being more or less obnoxious and who attract the attention of listeners-however few there are-to the identities of people who are speaking, their political affiliation and the States from which they come. I am sure those three or four listeners around Australia who are trying to put the baby to sleep or drown out the noise of the tractor find that most useful.
—You can't get it on the tractor.

—That is the problem. The reason they do tune in to parliamentary broadcasts is that they are generally too far away on their tractors out on their farms to pick up commercial radio. Those in the fortunate position of still being able to get the ABC use it to put the baby to sleep, to drown out the noise of their tractor and so on. I would also like to add my thanks to the Clerks. I came here first in 1978 completely alone--
—It seems like 30 years!

—That is right; it does seem like 30 years. I relied very much on the assistance of the Clerks and, in particular, Anne Lynch, who was a great support for me. When we arrived here in 1981 holding the balance of power in the Senate for the first time, and frightening the living daylights out of the rest of the political parties represented here, we got an enormous amount of help and advice from people such as Harry Evans who, on more than one occasion, helped us to foil the odd bit of skulduggery that was going on. He was quite aware of the fact that we were untutored and untried and he did his best to at least even up the balance a little on our side.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, I would like to thank my colleagues, particularly my deputy leader, Michael Macklin, and the Whip, Paul McLean. I think it is not known-or perhaps if it is known it is not appreciated-just what sort of load my Democrat colleagues carry. We make a habit of dealing with every piece of legislation. When there are only seven of us, or in the past when there were only five or six, that is not an insignificant load.

The journalists who periodically and in very small numbers cover the Senate from the press gallery also deserve our thanks, inasmuch as they are ever able to follow anything that ever happens in this place. A journalist described the Senate to me a week or so ago as the `B-grade chamber'. I suspect sometimes it turns into a horror movie but more often than not it does a far better job than most journalists and most members of the public are aware. The contribution on the part of all senators to the democratic process is a considerable achievement. Senator Chaney said that one has to take into account party politics. Certainly one does. One has to discount a certain amount of rhetoric and vicious comment from time to time. Nonetheless, the Senate does operate to put a brake on any sort of dictatorship that could occur if both Houses were held by the same political party-it would simply be a two-House version of Queensland and I do not think anybody ever wants to see that happen. I wish everybody here a joyous Christmas and a very happy New Year. Should an election befall us before we meet again, could I say that I hope everybody gets what they deserve.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will be very brief, necessarily in fact, but in any case intentionally so. I want to thank you for your courtesy to me personally during my brief time here and also for the manner in which you have presided over the deliberations of this chamber. I want to thank the staff of the Senate and also the attendants who look after the needs of senators with such good humour and understanding. I want to thank my National Party colleagues for their considerable assistance and support to me during the course of the past 2 3/4 years. Also my thanks go to my Liberal Party coalition colleagues with whom I have found a very happy relationship.
—Hear, hear!

—Particularly some of the Western Australian members. I want to be quite clear about expressing my appreciation to the senators on the Government side of the chamber who, with relatively few exceptions I think, have accorded me courtesies in this place which-I make this point-are not, as far as I can judge, courtesies which are normal in the other place. I say that against the background of someone who does not expect to be returning to this chamber and who is aspiring-if that is the right word-to go to the other chamber. I must say that if, as I hope and expect, I succeed in that aspiration I believe that I will be a better member of the House of Representatives for having been first a senator. I want to say that very sincerely and not without some little emotion. Although I think I am in the process of bidding this place goodbye I shall not forget it, nor shall I forget the lessons I learnt here.

—Yesterday I could have given a notice of motion to wish all senators and staff and everybody in this place the best for Christmas and the New Year and sought to have that declared formal today. That would have prevented me taking up the time of the Senate now, but my principles are such that I am sure many honourable senators would agree with me that far too many notices of motion have been declared formal and passed without debate. I take this opportunity of wishing every good wish to everyone for Christmas and the New Year. I noted that Senator Button said that the Manager of Government Business had been fired up by minor parties. Apparently he said that did not refer to the Australian Democrats. I do not know to whom it did refer; I do not think that I have given him much trouble. If I wanted to I suppose I could. As to the new procedures, all I can say is that time will tell. Nobody can tell just at the moment but only time will tell whether they will save time or add to the time of the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With regard to an article in Australian Fisheries on 7 July 1989, headed `AQIS warns no drugs on export fish' concerning the use of drugs in such operations as hatching, tagging, packing, stripping and transportation which may result in residues of the drugs being left in fish tissue which might represent a potential hazard to consumers, can the Minister indicate (a) what drugs are involved; (b) what harmful effects would result from customers eating fish containing residues of those drugs; (c) what control measures are currently in force to safeguard (i) domestic, and (ii) overseas consumers from being subjected to fish containing drug residues; and (d) what has been the response from the 6 State Health Departments to approaches from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for information on control measures, standards and possible legislation to prevent fish tainted by chemicals finding their way onto the export market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Tricaine methane sulphonate (MS 222 Sandoz), 2-methyl quinolone (quinaldine), 2-phenoxyethanol, methyl pentynol; benzocaine, etomidate, chlorotone, chlorobutanol, 2-phenylpropanol.

(b) Because such drugs are not tested on humans, it cannot be said what harmful effects would necessarily result. Whether any harmful effects might result to customers would, in any event, depend upon the dose received.

(c) (i) The National Health & Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) food standards which form the basis for State and Territory food regulations do not allow for the use of such drugs. Consequently, their presence in fish for human consumption could be regarded as adulteration, with the drug residues being seen as non-permitted additives; (ii) The presence of such drugs has not been approved by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service under the provisions of the Export Control (Fish) Orders.
(d) Replies received are summarised as follows:

Health Department, Victoria: These drugs have not been approved for use within the fish industry by the Health Department, Victoria. Victoria has adopted the Commonwealth Food Standards Code 1987, and would require an appropriate amendment of the Code to permit such practice.

Department of Health Services, Tasmania: None of the drugs are registered, but a veterinary officer could use one on his/her own initiative. Benzocaine is used in trout hatcheries prior to stripping brood stock or taking blood samples at least 12 months before the fish is consumed. It is not used for transport.

Queensland Department of Health: The standards included in the NH&MRC Food Standards Code 1987 are law in Queensland and any residues not provided for in that Code would be illegal if the product is offered for sale.

South Australian Health Commission: South Australia has adopted the NH&MRC Food Standards Code. Food for human consumption may only contain residues from substances used in food production up to the limit set by Standard A 14 for Maximum Residue Limits (MRL). Where no MRL has been set for a substance its presence is not permitted.
Health Department of Western Australia: There is no provision for the use of such substances within the current Western Australian Health Food Standards Regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice, on 31 October 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: By way of preamble, I point out that in March 1987 the public health committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recommended that `studies of human exposure arising from such uses'-termite control by organochlorine pesticides giving rise to air concentrations inside homes-`should be undertaken for further assessment'. Has the Department of Community Services and Health appointed officers to collect and collate information becoming available on this matter? If so, when will monitoring and collating of information be completed? Does the Government intend to set exposure standards for organochlorine pesticides for air inside homes? Is the NHMRC requiring further studies from registrants of chlordane, heptachlor, aldrin and dieldrin? Specifically, is it requiring inhalation toxicity data? Finally, is there any interim report and, if so, will the Minister make it available?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
At its 104th Session in November 1987, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) issued a statement on chlorinated organic pesticides, the relevant portion of which is as follows:

``The Council recommended that the use of these pesticides in the indoor living areas of domestic dwellings and habitable buildings, outdoor living areas (such as children's play areas, verandahs or patios), and in home gardens where food is produced, should be prohibited by State and Territory registration authorities.

The Council also recommended that the continued use of these pesticides in the subfloor space and other uses in and around habitable buildings be restricted to application by licensed pest control operators in accordance with State/Territory legislation. Studies of human exposure arising from such uses should be undertaken for further assessment.

The Council recognised that misuse of these materials by pest control personnel could present a potential hazard to themselves and to occupiers of treated dwellings, and further recommended that a code of practice be developed and an appropriate training program be implemented uniformly by the States and Territories.
The Council directed that these recommendations be drawn to the attention of State and Territory departments of health and agriculture.''
The NHMRC reference did recommend that studies of human exposure (not solely air concentrations) arising from permitted controlled use of these chemicals as termiticides be carried out.

The Department of Community Services and Health has not appointed officers to collect and collate information on this matter. When information becomes available, it will be collated for evaluation by the NHMRC in the usual manner.
The matter of possible exposure standards is for the NHMRC to consider in the light of the outcome of the studies now in progress and of any other relevant information.
Some further studies have been requested from the registrants. Additional inhalational toxicity data are not being required.
An interim report on one study has been provided to the Council. As the interim report was provided on a confidential basis, I am unable to make it available to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a recent ruling by the Australian Taxation Office in Queensland and indeed in other States, where income earned by the funds of pre-paid funeral businesses will be taxed at 49 cents in the dollar, plus Medicare benefit levy, plus provisional tax with the 12 per cent inflationary factor, thereby making the funds inadequate to meet the costs of the funeral.

(2) Will Section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 be amended to specifically include a funeral benefit business registered under Part III and Part IV of the Funeral Benefit Business Act 1982 (Queensland) and other similar acts in other States to obtain exemption for such funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that there has not been any recent change in the taxation treatment of funeral benefit businesses. The income derived from a funeral benefit investment is generally taxable. The exception to this is the funeral benefit business of registered friendly societies, non-profit medical benefit funds, trade union and employer associations and religious institutions.

The Commissioner has further advised that it is not correct to assume that recent advice provided to one funeral benefit business in Queensland as to the taxation status of its investment income implies that all funeral benefit businesses are treated in the same way.

To a large extent the conditions in the funeral benefit contract as agreed between the parties determine the taxation consequences. One possible outcome may be that each funeral benefit business client is taxable on his or her share of fund income. Another result may be that all the income of the trust is subject to the highest individual marginal rate of tax plus the Medicare levy. There is no State or Commonwealth legislation which specifically precludes contracts under which contributors would be taxed at their normal marginal tax rates.

The structure of the funeral benefit business fund and the amount of investment income it derives will determine whether provisional tax is payable. In any case, liability to provisional tax does not increase the total amount of tax to which a taxpayer is subjected. A provisional taxpayer's final tax liability in respect of any year is based on his or her actual income for that year (as with all other taxpayers) and the provisional tax paid during the year is offset against this tax liability.

(2) No; funeral benefit businesses are operated with the intent of making a profit and therefore, in terms of both policy and taxation principle, should be subject to taxation accordingly. Moreover, the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that provision of a tax exemption would create tax avoidance opportunities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What public opinion and/or market surveys have been commissioned by the Department or agencies for which the Department is responsible since 1982.

(2) (a) What was the cost of each survey; (b) who was awarded the contracts; and (c) were competitive tenders called for each survey; if so, who were the tenderers involved and what were their respective tender prices; if not, why were competitive tenders not called.

(3) (a) What was the sample size for each survey; and (b) what are the details and characteristics of those sampled (e.g. were group discussions held); if so (i) how many group discussions were held, (ii) how many people participated in these group discussions and (iii) who were the participants.

(4) (a) Will the Minister provide copies of the actual questionnaires used in the field; and (b) were any questions asked which were not in these questionnaires; if so, why and what were these questions.
(5) Will the Minister provide copies of the reports which contained the results of these surveys; if not will the Minister provide other access to these reports; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister provide copies of the computer printouts of the results of the surveys; if not, will the Minister provide other access to these printouts; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only major public opinion/or market survey commissioned by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs since 1982 was that conducted by Australian National Opinion Polls in 1984-85.
The Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Limited and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies have advised that they have not commissioned any opinion surveys since 1982.

(2) (a) The survey cost $59,000; (b) Australian National Opinion Polls (ANOP); (c) Yes. Submissions were invited from major poll organisations. Those who submitted proposals and their prices were: Inview $66,500, Roy Morgan $84,808, ANOP $59,000 and Yann, Campbell, Hoare and Wheeler $44,850.

(3) (a) The sample size for the national survey was 2000; (b) Those sampled were adults, including rural and provincial town dwellers, residents of North Queensland and north-west Western Australia and farming and mining communities; (i) Group discussions were held in two waves. Wave one included 17 group discussions and 28 opinion leader interviews. Wave two included 10 further group discussions and 16 opinion leader interviews; (ii) The Department does not have details on group discussion. The results are detailed in the ANOP report to the Department; (iii) The participants were adults of both sexes, drawn from a range of social class groupings and aged 20-55 years.

(4) (a) The Department of Aboriginal Affairs does not possess copies of the questionnaires used in the field. However, the questions are detailed in the ANOP report which was published in January 1985, a copy of which will be made available to the honourable senator.
(5) This report includes the results of the survey.
(6) The Department does not possess computer printouts of the survey. However, detailed tabular printouts from the survey are included in the report being provided to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 30 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was approval granted in 1986 for Australian interests to import 2 Carvair aircraft from New Zealand for the Tasmanian freight run.
(2) Was that approval subsequently reversed; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 17 February 1986, the then Minister for Aviation, the Honourable Peter Morris MP, wrote to Mr J. L. W. Ellis, of Mornington Peninsula Aerodrome, Moorooduc, Victoria, indicating that he agreed in principle to his Department approving the importation by Mr Ellis of 2 ATL 98 Carvair aircraft, for operations in domestic freight services, subject to the execution of formal undertakings with the Department on the use and disposal of the aircraft.

Consultations between the then Department of Aviation and Mr Ellis and his legal representatives continued during 1986 regarding the identification of those parties that were to import, operate and have control over the above aircraft, and the obtaining of suitable undertakings from these parties. The Department forwarded to Mr Ellis's legal representatives draft undertakings, setting out the Commonwealth's requirements in this matter.
In a letter of 11 November 1986 to the Department, Mr Ellis indicated that his proposal to use Carvair aircraft had lapsed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government consider the availability of technologically-oriented management training as highly desirable, if not essential, to the revitalisation of the Australian manufacturing export industry; if so, does the new innovative engineering course now being offered by the ANU fit into this category.

(2) Is there an agreement between the ANU and the Department of Employment, Education and Training providing for restrictions on both funding and access to the new course; if so, what are the main reasons for such restrictions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) There is no formal agreement between the Australian National University and the Department of Employment, Education and Training on this matter. There have been negotiations between the Australian National University, the Canberra College of Advanced Education, the Australian Defence Force Academy, the ACT Institute of TAFE, and the Institution of Engineers, Australia, concerning the formation of a single School of Engineering for the ACT aimed at ensuring cooperation in the provision of engineering education in the ACT. The negotiations have addressed issues concerning respective institutional roles, access to programs and the nature and size of programs. In these circumstances the ANU and CCAE would include proposals for student enrolments into the single engineering school in their educational profiles and the usual procedures for negotiating funding would apply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 23 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is there no field allowance equivalent for Australian service personnel serving in the field in an overseas location as part of the Defence Cooperation Programme (DCP).

(2) Will the Minister explain why the situation exists which allows servicemen serving under the DCP mapping the Papua New Guinea/Irian Jaya border, who are accommodated at a base camp, to receive Temporary Accommodation Allowance (TAA) and servicemen of the same group who are accommodated in the field, in far worse conditions, to receive no allowance at all.
(3) Will the Minister also explain why servicemen in the abovementioned locality of PNG receive no post allowance, yet servicemen in Port Moresby, Lae, Wewak or Mendi do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian servicemen in PNG as part of DCP are eligible for the payment of Travelling Allowance. Travelling Allowance cannot be paid in conjunction with Field Allowance.

(2) Temporary Accommodation Allowance is a within Australia allowance and is not payable overseas. Servicemen serving under DCP at a base camp and in the field are eligible for the payment of Travelling Allowance. There was no authority appointed to approve payment of Travelling Allowance to servicemen who are part of DCP. The Department of Industrial Relations has amended the legislation for Travelling Allowance (including the appointment of a new approving authority) which enables payment of the Allowance.

(3) The Department of Industrial Relations has amended the legislation which now allows the payment of post allowance to members serving in locations in PNG outside of Port Moresby, Lae, Wewak and Mendi.
