QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Under the Aurora Australis contract, how much will be paid and what is the breakdown of the amount, in the financial year 1990-91 assuming that the ship performs a full Antarctic season and is laid up for the rest of the financial year, and using actual figures available, or current estimates for the variables in the contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Total costs under the charter for hire, crewing and science instrumentation system for the 1990-91 financial year are estimated to be $11,058,662. A breakdown of this amount and information on the variables on which it is based are as follows:

Vessel hire fee is escalated at a rate of 4% per annum under the charter, providing the average increase in the CPI for the six capital cities does not exceed 7 1/2% for the twelve months ending 30 June immediately preceding the Antarctic season: 4% has been used for this calculation ...
Crewing is based on the current estimated cost ($1,521,900) plus an estimated escalation of 7 1/2% per annum ...
The cost of the scientific instrumentation system is fixed for the duration of the charter ...

If the vessel is not chartered for some other purpose during the off-season, then a lay up cost will also be incurred. The Commonwealth is not, however, liable for any lay up costs until the vessel has been chartered for a full Antarctic season.

Assuming that no alternative use is found for the vessel in the off-season the cost is calculated to be $164,151, which represents that part of the year between the completion of the 1990-91 season and 30 June 1991.

In addition to the above costs there are a number of items and contingencies which cannot be accurately calculated at this time, eg victualling (which depends on the numbers of expeditioners carried each day), radio telephone and satellite telephone calls, ice pilots (if required) and bounty on scientific equipment (if less than estimated).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Under the Aurora Australis contract, how much will be paid and what is the breakdown of the amount, in the financial years 1988-89 and 1989-90, assuming that the ship performs a part Antarctic season in 1989-90 and is laid up for the rest of the financial year, and using actual figures available, or current estimates, for the variables in the contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There was no cost to the Commonwealth for hire of the Aurora Australis in 1988-89. The Commonwealth made a payment of $460,000 for additional scientific equipment which becomes the property of the Commonwealth and is not subject to the hire charge for the remainder of the scientific instrumentation system.

When preparing its estimates for 1989-90 the Antarctic Division had estimated the costs under the charter for hire, crewing and the science instrumentation system for the 1989-90 financial year at $6,719,872 subject to the vessel being delivered in time to allow a 114 day charter to be completed prior to 30 April 1990. Advice has now been received that the vessel will not be available until the period 1 February to 15 February 1990. Accordingly a reduced program will be undertaken resulting in lower costs.
A breakdown of the amount of $6,719,872 and details of the variables on which it is based are as follows:

Vessel hire fee is escalated at a rate of 4% per annum under the charter, providing the average increase in the CPI for the six capital cities does not exceed 7 1/2% for the twelve months ending 30 June immediately preceding the Antarctic season: 4% has been used for this calculation ...
Crewing is based on the current estimated cost ($1,521,900) plus an estimated escalation of 7 1/2% per annum ...
The cost of the scientific instrumentation system is fixed for the duration of the charter ...
The Commonwealth is not liable for any lay up costs until the vessel has been chartered for a full Antarctic season the first of which is now scheduled to be 1990-91.

In addition to the above costs there are a number of items and contingencies which cannot be accurately calculated at this time, eg victualling (which depends on the numbers of expeditioners carried each day), radio telephone and satellite telephone calls, ice pilots (if required) and bounty on scientific equipment (if less than estimated).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that the advice of the Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee is normally taken into account by the CGS in relation to the appointment and promotion of Senior Army Reserve Officers, in what circumstances in relation to such appointments and promotions would the taking of that committee's advice into account not be applicable.
(2) Have any such circumstances occurred in the past 2 years, what were they and how did they justify not seeking or taking into account such advice.

(3) In view of the fact that Colonel Tait (ARA) was told in mid-September 1988 by Major General Keldie, Commander, 2 Div, that he was to be appointed Commander, 5 Brigade in succession to Brigadier Bryce Fraser (ARes) and Brigadier Fraser was formally advised by Major General Keldie of this on 2 December 1989, and informally on 2 previous occasions, was this change of command discussed at the A&P Committee meeting held on 27 September 1988; if so, what advice was tendered to the CGS; if not, why not, and in particular, what circumstances, if any existed which made it inappropriate or undesirable to consider and tender advice to the CGS on such an important and unusual change of command.

(4) In relation to the similar replacement of an ARes Brigadier with an ARA Colonel in the command of 4 Brigade in Victoria, was this very important change of command considered at the A&P meeting of 27 September 1988; if not, why not.

(5) If, as has been advised by the Minister previously, the A&P Committee did as a matter of course deliberate on these changes of command in the 4th and 5th Brigades, why were these deliberations on these very important and unusual changes not recorded in the minutes of that Committee.

(6) In view of the fact that the A&P Committee has considered that probability of Reserve formations and units being commanded by Regular Officers when on a case-by-case basis a pool of suitable Reserve Officers is not available, would an ARes Officer below retiring age who was available and who had proved himself previously in a similar command be precluded from appointment to such a command.

(7) Since Colonel Tait (ARA) was advised by Commander 2 Division, Major General Keldie, in mid-September 1988 that he was to assume command of 5 Brigade, when was that decision taken by the CGS and how and by whom was it communicated to Major General Keldie, and with what instructions as to its further communication to Colonel Tait and Brigadier Fraser.

(8) If the CGS made the decision to replace Brigadier Bryce Fraser (ARes) as Commander of 5 Brigade after advice from Land Commander Major General Smethurst, Assistance Chief of the General Staff for the Army Reserve, Major General Fay; and Commander of 2nd Division Major General Keldie and Command of 3rd Division Major General Nunn, did the advice of all 4 of these officers favour the decision made by the CGS, if not, which Officer advised against the decision.

(9) In view of the fact that the policy of the Government and the Army is to give preference to qualified, suitable and available ARes Officers over Regular Officers for Senior Reserve Appointments, why does an ARes Officer's age (presuming the relevant Officer to be below retiring age) or the fact that he has previously commanded, render him not suitable for senior command or appointment.
(10) Is age and previous command to be taken as overriding the clear policy of preference of Reserve Officers for ARes Command and Appointments.
(11) Is it policy that ARes Brigade Commanders command for only two-and-a-half years.
(12) What is the basis of this policy, and is it considered sufficiently important to justify the over-riding of the policy that ARes Commands should be held by ARes officers.
(13) Is there a similar two-and-a-half year term policy in relation to the Command of 2nd and 3rd Divisions, or the position of Assistant Chief of the General Staff (ARes), if not, why not.

(14) Were there any reasons other than that he had commanded for two-and-a-half years why Brigadier Bryce Fraser (ARes) was replaced in December 1988 by Colonel Tait (ARA) in the command of 5th Brigade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Advice may be given out of session or informally. There is, of course, no legal requirement for the Chief of the General Staff to follow such advice as he is a duly authorized delegate of the Governor-General.

(2) The Chief of General Staff has acted without formal advice from the Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee on several occasions in the last two years. Such action has been necessary because of the specialist nature of an appointment or because the Committee could not be formally convened in time for a decision. When the latter occurs, advice is sought from relevant commanders.

(3) The proposed change of command of 4 and 5 Brigades was approved by the Chief of the General Staff on 16 August 1988. His decision was supported by out of session advice from the six members of the Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee directly concerned with the appointments. Out of session advice was sought because the Army Reserve Appointment and Promotion Advisory Committee scheduled to consider such appointments was delayed until 27 September 1988 when these appointments were noted.

(5) The command of 4 and 5 Brigades did not form part of a specific agenda item. Comments related either to the performance of officers then in command or as part of the overview presented by the Commanders 2 and 3 Division in relation to the manning in their regions.

(7) The decision to appoint ARA officers to command 4 and 5 Brigades was made by the Chief of the General Staff on 16 August 1988 and formally promulgated by the Military Secretary on 15 September 1988. In accordance with normal procedure it was communicated to Major General Keldie through the chain of command by telephone in the first instance and Major General Keldie was requested to advise both officers.
(8) Yes. As detailed in (3) above, the decision by Chief of the General Staff was supported by the advice tendered.

(9) Officers who had previously commanded brigades were considered. Given that they were not considered suitable for further advancement, however, it was considered to be in the best interests of the Army to appoint other officers.
(11) No. It is however, by practice about the maximum as only one officer in NSW in the past 15 years has commanded a brigade or similar formation for more than two-and-a-half years.

(12) It is not policy that an Army Reserve Brigade Commander should serve for only two-and-a-half years. Each case, is reviewed annually, and a decision taken of the relative merits of the situation. Factors considered include the overall performance of the brigade, the brigade commander's potential for further advancement and the need for him to serve in another appointment for either his own development or to meet the needs of the Service.

(13) It is usual for Reserve Divisional Commanders and the Assistant Chief of the General Staff Army Reserve to complete a minimum of two and a maximum of four years in the appointments. Although, in law, the appointments, as with brigade commander, are for an unspecified period, initial appointments are made for two years and reviewed annually by the Chief of the General Staff.
(14) It was considered that a change in command would benefit the brigade and Brigadier Fraser was made aware of this by the Commander 2 Division in December 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 28 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What companies have expressed an interest in the Woomera rocket range, and if they are subsidiaries, what are their parent companies.
(2) How many of these are non-Australian companies, and which countries are they from.
(3) Which companies attended the industry briefing on the project at Technology Park, Adelaide on 25 July 1989.
(4) What activities are envisaged by companies using the Woomera range.
(5) Do any of these activities involve firings or tests that have an impact area or range outside of the Woomera site: if so, what activities are envisaged.
(6) If the local Aboriginal community at Oak Valley continues to object to proposals for the Woomera range, will the Commonwealth overrule them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An invitation to register interest in the commercial operation of the Woomera Instrumented Range was released on 18 March 1989. By the closing date for Registration of Interest (12 May 1989), thirteen organisations had responded. Details are provided at Table 1 shown below.
(2) The country of origin of non-Australian companies is also shown on Table 1.

(3) The purpose of the industry briefing on the project held at Technology Park, Adelaide on 25 July 1989 was to issue a Request for Proposals to those organisations which had Registered Interest. These companies attended the briefing accompanied by a number of advisors and associates. A list of those who attended is provided at Table 2 shown below.

By the closing date for the Request for Proposals (29 September 1989), two responses were received. These came from Australian Flight Test Services Pty Ltd, an Australian company which had originally Registered Interest, and the Woomera Range Development Group Pty Ltd. This latter group is composed of Aero Space Technologies of Australia 45%, Ansett Technologies 40%, and the Government of South Australia 15%; the first two companies having originally Registered Interest.

Both responses are tentative in nature and dependent on the outcome of feasibility studies. These are required both to establish the range of activities which might be undertaken and the commercial viability of the proposals.

(4) It is envisaged that activities undertaken by a commercial company acting as Range Operator for the Woomera Range will be subject to an agreement negotiated with the operator by the Commonwealth. Details of facilities and services which the Department of Defence requires or may need, constraints on the operators activities, and Commonwealth control of the Range Operator, are set out in the document `REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS FOR THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THE WOOMERA INSTRUMENTED RANGE AND ASSOCIATED FACILITIES AS A COMMERCIAL UNDERTAKING-25 July 1989'. Because of the size of the document it is impracticable to reproduce it in this answer. Consequently, I have forwarded a copy of the document direct to Senator Vallentine.
(5) It is not envisaged that any of the proposed activities involving firings or tests will take place outside the Woomera Prohibited Area.

(6) The position of the Government on the use of the Woomera Prohibited Area has been conveyed to the Aboriginal community at Oak Valley, the Maralinga Tjarutja, by the Minister of Defence, Mr Beazley, on 24 August 1987 and confirmed by the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, on 14 September 1987. The area has been gazetted as a place for the testing of war material in the interests of the safety and defence of Australia. As such, it constitutes part of an important Defence asset. Its very considerable area is an essential feature for the provision of both adequate safety and adequate security.

Relations between the Department of Defence and the Woomera Prohibited Area community of pastoralists, landholders and aboriginal peoples have been conducted over the past 40 years on a ``good neighbour'' basis. The Maralinga Tjarutja have been offered a Memorandum of Understanding to formalise the means by which their justified concerns can be expressed and taken into account in the planning process.
Consultations are continuing with the aboriginal communities impacted by this commercialisation initiative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With respect to the latest Telecom bonds prospectus and application forms, why has the Commonwealth Government suddenly decided not to guarantee their own monopolistic situation;
(2) Why has there been no notification of the change in the wording in the prospectus;
(3) What is the reason behind this change.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Government's power to guarantee the repayment of borrowings by Telecom was removed when the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989 came into effect on 1 July 1989.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When does the Government expect to waive the $35 fee for processing Australian citizenship applications lodged by pensioners.
(2) What would be the cost to Government of implementing this measure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I do understand and have some sympathy for the position of pensioners for whom the payment of the citizenship processing fee may cause some hardship. The citizenship fee received some attention from Members and Senators during the Year of Citizenship campaign. Some concessions in respect of the citizenship fee were introduced during the campaign. While I do not favour abolition of the fee for age pensioners, I am examining the possibility of a reduced fee. I have asked my Department to examine this matter in the context of the 1990-91 round of new policy proposals.

(2) My Department does not have a figure for the number of people applying for Australian citizenship who are in receipt of an Australian age pension. However, an estimated 4.4% of applicants for the grant of Australian citizenship are of pensionable age and meet the residential requirement of an Australian age pension. Using this figure, I estimate the revenue foregone, if waiver for age pensioners were to be introduced, would amount to approximately $132,000 in the financial year 1990-91. This estimate is based on an expected 86,000 applications being received during the financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 7 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What resources are being spent or planned to be spent on research into botulism in cattle?
(2) What funds and resources have been allocated to research into the manufacture of bivalent vaccine, to reduce the high breakdown rate being experienced?
(3) Is the manufacture and preparation of the bivalent vaccine on target to supply graziers in 1990 with sufficient quantity and at the required time (used Jan/March to Aug/Sep)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A joint James Cook University/Queensland Department of Primary Industries proposal to develop a diagnostic test has been submitted to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation for funding in 1990. If funding is approved, Queensland DPI will commit two to three man years to the project for each of the next 3 years.
Arthur Webster Pty Ltd has had an in-house research project on botulism vaccine for several years. This research will be on-going.
The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) has funded some R&D which is nearly completed.
(2) CSL is directing some research resource toward development of a reliable bivalent vaccine, although they have been unable to manufacture or market a bivalent vaccine for several years.
Arthur Webster Pty Ltd has been funding its own research which is continuing in an attempt to make supplies of bivalent vaccine more consistently available.
(3) A joint Cattlemen's Union/Queensland Department of Primary Industries action committee has been implemented to forward order supplies and monitor likely demand.

CSL will definitely not have a bivalent vaccine available by Jan/March 1990 and quite probably not by Aug/Sept. CSL prefer to ensure availability of potent monovalent vaccines rather than risk scarce antigen in commercial size batches of bivalent product. CSL feels emphasis on the bivalent product may be counterproductive.

Arthur Webster Pty Ltd will re-release bivalent vaccine once they are confident that potency variation has been eliminated. Meanwhile they are continuing to manufacture monovalent type C & D vaccines which will be available for the 1990 season.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reservations to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia, on 18 December 1972, sign the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(2) Did Australia, on 13 November 1980, deposit an instrument of ratification of the Covenant, with declarations and reservations.
(3) Did Australia, on 6 November 1984, withdraw the declarations and some of the reservations.
(4) What are the terms of the remaining reservations.
(5) When did the Government last give consideration to withdrawing these reservations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Australia's instrument of ratification, with reservations and declarations, was deposited 13 August 1980, three months after the deposit of the instrument, pursuant to Article 49.2.

``In relation to paragraph 2 (a) the principle of segregation is accepted as an objective to be achieved progressively. In relation to paragraph 2 (b) and 3 (second sentence) the obligation to segregate is accepted only to the extent that such segregation is considered by the responsible authorities to be beneficial to the juveniles or adults concerned''.

``Australia makes the reservation that the provision of compensation for miscarriage of justice in the circumstances contemplated in paragraph 6 of article 14 may be by administrative procedures rather than pursuant to specific legal provision''.

``Australia interprets the rights provided for by article 12, 21 and 22 as consistent with article 20; accordingly, the Commonwealth and the constituent States, having legislated with respect to the subject matter of the article in matters of practical concern in the interest of public order (ordre public), the right is reserved not to introduce any further legislative provision on these matters''.

``Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the constitutent States. The implementation of the treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities having regard to their respective constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise''.
(5) The matter has not been considered formally by the Standing Committee of Attorney-Generals since 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since human rights protection is for everyone, should not individuals be able to take legal action to prevent the abuse of human rights.
(2) Will the Minister ask the Attorney-General to advise as to:

(a) whether current customs regulations are beyond the constitutional power of the Government to the extent that they conflict with: (i) the Human Rights Act, (ii) the UN Charter Act, (iii) the Genocide Act, (iv) the criminal law of Australia (complicitly and conspiracy in homicide, assault, terrorism, etc.), and/or (v) the common laws of the global community on international human rights standards;
(b) the effective remedies' (plural) available to all Australians if international human rights instruments, as ratified by Australia, are violated by the Australian Government or industry;

(c) whether a court action for negligence could be brought against the Departments of Defence and Foreign Affairs and Trade by citizens alleging a duty of care (as set out in these international human rights standards), a breach of that duty (the loopholes in the current defence export regulations) and consequent personal injury (including economic loss involved in such a courtroom `rescue' action);
(d) whether special legislation is required to empower judges to act on apparent human rights abuses once they are brought to the court's attention; and

(e) whether the Attorney-General will provide a special fund for the establishment of Public Interest Advocacy centres in each State with a brief to be `Human Rights Defenders' (see the Draft Declaration presented by the Working Group, which Australia has chaired for several years, to the 45th Session of the UN Commission on Human Rights, March 1989).

(3) Will the Minister move to immediately draft and promulgate new regulations which close the loopholes in the existing export regulations that allow breaches of human rights in other countries to occur through the export of Australian military equipment and services.

(4) Will the Minister recommend that the Department of Defence establish a Human Rights Section, as the Departments of both the Attorney-General and Foreign Affairs and Trade already have such Human Rights Sections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Certainly I believe that it should be the goal of every national system of law to allow individuals to take legal action in respect of breaches of their human rights. Under international law which is essentially the law between states, legal remedies available to individuals are limited. One mechanism exists under the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Government is currently giving consideration to becoming a Party to the Protocol.
(2) This question should be addressed to the Attorney-General.

(3) Please refer to my answer to the question by Senator Dunn on 29 November on military equipment sales and to my answer on 2 March to you on defence exports in which I outlined the constraints, including human rights considerations, applying to the export of defence equipment from Australia. Also, please refer to the answers to questions on notice numbers 1351 (Hansard of 12 November 1986), 1281 and 1282 (in Hansard of 30 November 1989) in which the Minister representing the Minister for Defence provided similar information on defence export controls, as well as the News Release of 14 June 1988 by the Minister for Defence. The Government is not aware of any loopholes in the current regulations, but should any become apparent and require amendment of the regulations, then this would be a responsibility of the Minister for Defence.
(4) This question should be addressed to the Minister for Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 12 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists (RACR) have found compelling evidence from overseas studies, that a national breast cancer screening program could reduce mortality by up to 30 per cent.
(2) Is it a fact that the RACR have urged the Federal Government to implement a national screening program.

(3) As the Minister responsible for the Status of Women, is the Minister prepared to urge the Government to introduce a national screening program and/or introduce a Medicare rebate for such procedures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the College's statement to that effect.

(3) The proposal for a national screening program is one in which the Government, in co-operation with State and Territory Governments, is already actively interested. It was vital to the interests of Australian women that overseas approaches to mammography screening be evaluated and pilot testing be undertaken in Australia before a national screening program is introduced. Women must be able to be confident that any such program would be relevant to their needs and capable of producing high quality results with minimum levels of interpretation error.

Accordingly, a three year evaluation supported by all Australian Health Ministers was established in 1987. This is now almost complete. I will soon be discussing the preliminary findings with the Minister for Community Services and Health.

I know the Minister and the Government are very conscious, as I am, of the special health needs of women. We are particularly concerned to reduce the number of avoidable deaths resulting from undetected breast cancer.

The Medicare Benefits Schedule already provides benefits for mammography services where the patient is referred by a doctor for a mammogram and there is reason to suspect malignancy because of the patient's or her family's history or because there are symptoms or indications of malignancy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Proportion of Women in Medical Specialities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 12 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the April 1988 report of the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce specifically refer to: (a) the need to increase the proportion of women in medical specialities; and (b) the under-representation of women who make up just 60 of the 3800 surgical fellows of the Royal Australian College of Surgeons.

(2) Is it a fact that the report found that, if greater numbers of female graduates are to be attracted into specialist careers, there is a need to align more closely the requirements of training with the family and other personal commitments of female graduates.
(3) Does this not contrast with the Government's newly-created Vocational Register for General Practitioners which clearly discriminates against women.
(4) What action has the Minister taken to address the matters raised by the Committee; if no action has been taken, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The Vocational Register for General Practitioners does not discriminate against women. Allegations that it does were investigated by the all party Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance which examined the proposals for vocational registration for general practitioners. In its unanimous report the Committee pointed out that the vocational training program for general practice, the Family Medicine Program, has extremely flexible arrangements to accommodate the needs of part-time trainees and women doctors returning to the workforce. Further, the provision in the eligibility criteria for vocational registration, that two sessions per week in general practice for the five year qualifying period is acceptable, ensures that doctors working in part-time practice are not disadvantaged.

The Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce (Doherty Report), to which the question refers, recognises that vocational training for general practitioners is highly desirable and that continuing medical education is essential to high quality medical care. These elements are the basis of vocational registration for general practitioners which is voluntary.

(4) In October 1988, the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Conference (AHMAC) established a Working Party to review and make recommendations on implementation of the Doherty Report. It presented its final report to AHMAC in October 1989.
Resulting from the Working Party's deliberations, AHMAC has, among other things:
established a Medical Workforce Data Review Committee to monitor the medical workforce;
directed the Working Party on the Doherty Report to review the training of specialists; and
referred the relevant Doherty Report recommendations to the Committee of Presidents of Medical Colleges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 12 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it correct that recent surveys by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories estimate that 25 per cent of household income goes on sport and recreation expenditure.

(2) Given that upwards of 40 per cent of household income is needed for home loan repayments, is it correct to assume that, based on the survey findings, only 35 per cent of household income would be left for all other expenses including food, clothes, transport, electricity, phone, insurance, rates, etc.
(3) Does the Minister agree that it is unlikely that 35 per cent of household income would be sufficient to do all of the above.
(4) Are the findings correct.
(5) How many surveys were undertaken and at what cost.
(6) Can the Minister provide details of the surveys and their findings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. A recent economic research study conducted by my Department, based on expenditure data from the 1984 Household Expenditure Survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, estimated that in that year, between 15.8 and 18.9 per cent of household expenditure was spent on sport and recreation related goods and services. The study adopted a broad definition of sport and recreation and identified a proportion of expenditure on a range of items, including clothing and footwear, transport, etc. as related to the sport and recreation sector. This allocation, however, was not exclusive and expenditure on these terms could, therefore, be counted in other categories of expenditure as well.
(4) The study used accepted economic methodology to develop its findings. It was, however, a one-off research project in a new field of study and as was made clear should be regarded as indicative.

(5) The study was undertaken as an in-house research project. It employed two officers on an almost full-time basis for 3 months. Additional costs, totalled $1200 for the printing of 200 copies of a Departmental research paper entitled, The Economic Impact of Sport and Recreation-Household Expenditure: Technical Paper No. 1. This is one in a series of studies intended to measure the economic dimensions of sport and recreational activities in Australia.
(6) The findings of the research paper are publicly available from Commonwealth Government Bookshops in The Economic Impact of Sport and Recreation-Household Expenditure: Technical Paper No. 1.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to a report in the Australian of 12 December 1989 that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) negotiated an agreement with the United States Internal Revenue Services to exchange information on the affairs of taxpayers represented in both countries, how many agreements with other countries have been, or are being, negotiated, and with which countries.
(2) In the interests of taxpayers' rights and accountability to Parliament, can the Minister say why the existence of such an agreement has not been made public by the ATO previously.
(3) Is there any possibility of a breach of the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 resulting from the exchange of information on taxpayers by unauthorised persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has entered into comprehensive income tax agreements with the majority of our trading partners. These income tax agreements are based on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Developments (OECD) 1977 Model Double Taxation convention. Australia's comprehensive agreements have as their primary objectives the avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion.

Currently, Australia has twenty-four (24) comprehensive income tax agreements in force with two (2) further treaties, with China and Sri Lanka, signed but yet to enter into force. A further five (5) treaties are in the process of negotiation.
All these agreements have articles providing for exchange of information.

The arrangement reported in the Australian of 12 December 1989 is a working arrangement between The United States Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for the conduct of simultaneous examinations. The conduct of simultaneous examinations is authorised under Article 25 of the present Australia/United States Income Tax Convention which entered into force on 31 October 1983.
Simultaneous examinations were also permitted under the previous income tax convention with the United States of America, which the 1983 convention replaced, although none had been undertaken.

The working arrangement merely formalises the ground rules for the two administrations when conducting simultaneous examinations. A simultaneous examination is an audit of a taxpayer conducted by each country and occurring at the same time. It is not a joint audit in that there is no interchange of personnel. Discussions are held to plan the strategy of the audit and the relevant functions to be undertaken by the respective parties.

To achieve more efficiency in the exchange of information and to deal more effectively with cases of tax avoidance or tax evasion, the competent authorities of each convention partner decided to establish a working arrangement to conduct simultaneous examinations of selected taxpayers, or groups of taxpayers, carrying on activities in both the United States and Australia.

The simultaneous examination of selected taxpayers is conducted under the exchange of information article of the Australia/United States Income Tax Convention and in accordance with the provisions of the arrangement.

The disclosure of information exchanged under the simultaneous examination arrangement is subject to the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Convention and, in Australia's case, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The working arrangement with the IRS is the only formal agreement of this nature that the ATO has made. It is not considered necessary to conclude such an agreement in order to conduct a simultaneous examination.
Indeed, a simultaneous examination is currently being conducted with the New Zealand Inland Revenue Department under Article 20 of the Australia/New Zealand Double Tax Agreement.

(2) The provisions of all of Australia's double tax treaties were made public through the legislative process at the time each agreement was incorporated into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953. The formalised working arrangement with the IRS does not affect taxpayers' rights as the arrangement does not extend the obligations and rights in relation to exchange information beyond those provided for in the Convention.

(3) When information is exchanged in accordance with the provisions of the various agreements there can be no breach of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. All exchanges of information are made by the competent authority, who is a very senior officer in the National Office of the ATO, or by officers authorised to act on his behalf.

All exchange of information articles in Australia's agreements contain a secrecy provision which requires any information exchanged to be treated as secret and not to be disclosed to any persons other than those concerned with the assessment or collection of, the enforcement or prosecution in respect of, or the determination of appeals in relation to, the taxes to which the agreement applies.
A copy of the working arrangement with the United States Internal Revenue Service is attached.
THE UNITED STATES INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE
FOR THE CONDUCT OF SIMULTANEOUS EXAMINATIONS
UNDER THE TERMS OF THE EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION PROVISIONS OF
THE CONVENTION FOR THE AVOIDANCE OF DOUBLE TAXATION AND THE
PREVENTION OF FISCAL EVASION WITH RESPECT TO TAXES ON INCOME

To achieve more efficiency in the exchange of information and to more effectively deal with cases of tax avoidance or tax evasion, the competent authorities have decided to establish a working arrangement to conduct simultaneous examinations of selected taxpayers, or groups of taxpayers, carrying on activities in both the United States and Australia.

The simultaneous examination of selected taxpayers shall be conducted under the exchange of information articles of the United States-Australia Income Tax Convention and in accordance with the provisions of this arrangement. The disclosure of information exchanged under this simultaneous examination arrangement is subject to the provisions of the Income Tax Convention.

(1) Develop guidelines for the exchange of information which will be used by both countries in their examination of selected taxpayers with emphasis on arrangements where tax haven countries are used.
(2) Exchange information on apparent patterns or techniques of tax avoidance that significantly affect the tax administration of each country.
(3) Determine a taxpayer's correct income tax liability where costs are shared, or charged, and profits are allocated between taxpayers resident in different taxing jurisdictions.
(4) Develop techniques and formulas for evaluating transfer pricing practices between related taxpayers.
(5) Develop guidelines for evaluating tax haven transactions resulting from multiprocessing, transfer pricing, research and development, rents and royalties, and market changes in currency.
(6) Identify payments generally referred to as ``under-the-table'' payments, i.e. kickbacks, bribes, and ``illegal'' payments.
The following selection procedures will apply in the following sequence:
(1) Taxpayers will be independently identified for simultaneous examination by tax administration officials of each country.
(2) Each country will inform the other of its choice of potential cases using the selection criteria described below.

(3) Each country will determine whether it wishes to participate in a particular simultaneous examination. Neither country, however, is obliged to cooperate in all examinations proposed by the other country.

(4) If a competent authority accepts a counterpart's proposal to conduct a simultaneous examination, that competent authority will confirm, in writing, the selection of the case and will indicate a designated representative who will have functional responsibility for directing the examination. After receiving the confirmation, the proposing competent authority also will indicate, in writing, a designated representative. In those cases where there is agreement to conduct a simultaneous examination, the competent authority of each country will formally request the competent authority to exchange specific information and, if appropriate will spontaneously provide information to the competent authority pursuant to the Income Tax Convention.

(5) The designated representatives of the competent authorities will designate areas and periods to be examined in the particular case selected, the timetable for the examination and approaches to be taken. They will initiate formal written requests for exchange of specific information and, where appropriate, spontaneous exchanges of information through the competent authorities.
(6) The information which may be requested and provided under this arrangement must be obtainable under the Income Tax Convention and the respective taxation laws of the two countries.

Any case selected for simultaneous examination will involve a taxpayer(s) with activities in both countries. The factors considered in determining whether a case is selected will primarily be, but will not be limited to:
(1) Indication of substantial noncompliance of tax laws in both countries;

(3) Activities involving tax haven (for this purpose, a tax haven is a country or jurisdiction that has a zero or low tax rate, or that allows an escape from taxes on economic gains which should be taxed in Australia or the United States).

Examinations will be conducted separately within the framework of national law and practice solely by tax administration officials of each country in a way which maximizes the advantages obtainable for treaty exchanges of information. No interchange of personnel will be made between the countries.

Before the start of the examination, the tax administration personnel in charge of the case will consider with their counterparts from the other country, the audit plans of each country, possible issues to be developed, and target dates. Designated representatives may, if they consider it appropriate, initiate the exchange of formal examination plans through the competent authorities.

This procedure requires cooperation of personnel located in each country who will simultaneously but independently examine the taxpayer(s) within its jurisdiction. The primary responsibility for coordinating the examination and exchanges of information on a selected taxpayer will rest with the country where the level of noncompliance with the tax laws and tax haven activity appears to be greater. All exchanges of information must be made within the terms of the Income Tax Convention.
If either country concludes that a simultaneous examination is no longer beneficial, it may withdraw by notifying the other country of its withdrawal.
An examination will be concluded after coordination and consultation between the two countries, in accordance with the existing procedures of each country.
(1) This arrangement may be modified at any time by agreement between the competent authorities.
This arrangement is hereby agreed to on this the 2nd day of November, 1989

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that many Immigration Department cables to Australian embassies are not answered.
(2) Does the Minister agree that such requests for information on application should be answered.
(3) What procedure does the Government require of Australian Embassies to follow when responding to departmental request on the status of an application.
(4) Will the Minister give an assurance that such requests will be responded to in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that Australian missions overseas are extremely busy and have many competing calls on the time of their staff. My Department informs me that overseas missions are generally efficient in responding promptly to cabled enquiries from Australian offices. It does happen, though, that in isolated incidents responses to routine progress enquiries on individual cases can be delayed by pressure of work. Follow up requests deflect staff away from the more productive work of finalising cases. The time taken to respond to a cable seeking the present position of a case, can take longer than to action the matter to finality. Where this occurs, I understand that a busy post might not always be able to despatch a prompt answer to each request for information on the progress of a case through the processing cycle. The main avenue for conveying such information is between the post and the applicant.
(2) Yes, in line with the Government's expectations outlined in (3) below.

(3) The Government expects overseas missions to provide a substantive answer to Departmental requests for information on the status of an individual visa application by an appropriate channel of communication and within an appropriate time-frame, depending upon the circumstances of the case in question and the caseload and workload pressures on the mission concerned.

(4) I can assure the honourable senator that all overseas missions will be reminded of the Government's expectations in (3) above. I would also ask Senators and Members interested in immigration cases from their constituencies to exercise restraint in making routine progress enquiries of my Department's offices in Australia and overseas; the time and cable traffic generated by such enquiries consume resources best devoted to finalising visa applications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government received any offers to purchase any of the 11 RAAF Chinook helicopters that were withdrawn from service on 1 July 1989.
(2) Who made these offers and what were the terms of each offer.
(3) Is it correct that Boeing US has offered to purchase all 11 C-model aircraft, up-date them to the latest D-model and then sell them back to the Army.
(4) Has the Department of Defence accepted any offer or are they likely to accept any of those offered to date.
(5) Is it correct that the Army wrote to the Minister asking that some of the Chinooks be retained by the Army.
(6) Has the Minister given any consideration to this proposal; if so, what decisions have been made or are in place for implementation.
(7) What effect is the selling of the Chinooks likely to have on: (a) defence capability; and (b) morale.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) At this stage expressions of interest only have been received. It is premature to speculate on what firm conditions and prices might eventuate.
(3) An expression of interest along these lines has been received.
(4) No offers have been accepted at this time and it is premature to speculate on whether they may be.
(5) No. The possibility of retaining a limited number of upgraded Chinooks was raised orally with the Minister by the CGS.
(6) The Minister has agreed not to approve disposal of the Chinook fleet pending further advice on the cost of retaining four upgraded Chinooks.

(7) (a) The ADF has determined that the essential roles of the Chinooks can be performed more efficiently by other equipment, especially the new Black Hawk helicopters. Chinooks could perform some other support tasks more efficiently than Black Hawks.

(b) It is not possible to assess the effect on morale of selling the Chinooks. It is a function of Service leadership to explain such decisions to subordinates. Effective leadership and sound personnel management practices provide the mechanism for countering any adverse effects of morale.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 20 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What agreements have been reached in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to amend Australian laws to accommodate the legal problems facing transsexuals.
(2) To what extent have those agreements been implemented by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.
(3) Are there any other problems in relation to this matter on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and not yet resolved; if so, give details.
(4) Which States have taken action on their own initiative to address any of these problems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There have been no agreements reached in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to amend Australian laws to give recognition to the change of status of transsexuals. This issue was on the agenda of the Standing Committee between 1979 and December 1985. The item was removed from the agenda when members of the Standing Committee agreed that uniform legislation could not be achieved and that those States and Territories which were interested in changing their laws should take action unilaterally. The Commonwealth made it clear that there would be no amendment of the Marriage Act 1961 to allow transsexuals to marry in their adopted sex.
(2) There were no agreements to implement.
(3) There is no item in relation to this matter on the agenda of the Standing Committee.
(4) The only State which has taken legislative action in relation to this matter is South Australia, which has enacted the Sexual Reassignment Act 1988.
Some administrative action has been taken by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories to address some of the problems of transsexuals.

The Commonwealth has been able to assist transsexuals in a practical way since 1985 when the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade commenced issuing passports which show the adopted name and sex of a transsexual. That action is taken to avoid unnecessary embarrassment and possible harassment when travelling.

I am unaware of the full range of steps taken by the States and Territories. However, in relation to the issue of documents related to birth I am advised that some States and Territories have taken action to assist transsexuals to avoid inconvenience. There is, however, no consistent practice.

All States and Territories, with the exception of South Australia, show the sex of birth on a birth certificate. In the case of South Australia, a person whose sexual reassignment has been recognised can obtain a birth certificate which indicates his or her original name and sex together with a notation of the adopted name and sex or, alternatively, obtain a birth certificate indicating the person's adopted name and sex without reference to the details originally registered.

With extracts of entry of birth the practices are more varied. I am advised that the position is as follows. Victoria, Tasmania and Queensland each issue an extract which shows the adopted name and the biological sex, rather than the adopted sex, of a person. South Australia will, in line with the provisions of its Sexual Reassignment Act, issue an extract of entry indicating the adopted name and sex. I am advised that in New South Wales, the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia, the sex of a person is not shown on an extract of entry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: When monthly balance of payments figures are released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is it possible to itemise the value of imports used for that particular period which will be used to restructure Australian industry; if so, will the Government consider making such figures publicly available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: With a view to assisting in analyses of the composition of Australian imports, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in its published monthly balance of payments statistics, itemises, among other principal commodity groupings, the value of imports of machinery. Published quarterly figures provide details of most imports in terms of three broad categories: consumption goods, capital goods, and other goods. Consideration is being given to providing a similar dissection in the monthly publication.

With few exceptions, importers would not be sufficiently aware of the end use to which particular commodities would be applied to enable them to provide information which would permit the Bureau to itemise the value of imports to be used for the purpose of restructuring Australian industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given that the Minister has recently awarded the maintenance of the C-130 Hercules fleet to New Zealand, what would happen to the maintenance of the aircraft in the situation where New Zealand did not agree with Australia's involvement in a conflict or situation involving the C-130's and where New Zealand was required to repair and maintain them, as was the case during the Vietnam War when the Swiss refused to provide parts for the Pilatus Porter aircraft and the Swedes refused to provide ammunition for the Karl-Gustav anti-tank rocket due to their neutral stance during the war.
(2) With the transfer of Hercules maintenance technical capability to New Zealand, are we not in effect removing our own technical capability leaving ourselves with no alternatives for the future.
(3) Is this considered of lesser importance than the Closer Economic Relationship agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Full account was taken of strategic considerations during evaluation of tenders. There is a close common purpose in defence industry matters between Australia and New Zealand which has been strengthened by the ANZAC Ship Project. Notwithstanding that the scenario which you describe is extremely unlikely, about one third of Hercules major servicings will continue to be performed by the RAAF in Australia thereby providing a capacity for surge should the need arise.

(2) Hercules major servicings have previously been carried out in Australian industry and given the level of technology and infrastructure requirements for servicing, it would not be difficult to transfer this work from Air New Zealand to any one of a number of Australian companies should the need arise.
(3) Given my responses to the previous two questions, the relative importance of the Closer Economic Relationship is irrelevant to the issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority or organisation for which the Minister is responsible, employed consultants since July 1986; if so, (a) who has been employed and for what purpose; (b) what working plan was given to them; (c) what was the cost of their services; (d) when did their services commence and finish; and (e) was any fee in excess of the initial quote paid to the consultant; if so, what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The information to answer parts (a), (c) and (d) of Senator Newman's question as to who has been employed and for what purpose, the cost of services and when the services commenced and finished is contained in appendices A and B for 1987-88 and 1988-89 respectively.

The detailed records required to answer parts (a), (c) and (d) of Senator Newman's question relating to FY 1986/87 are not held in a central location within the Department of Defence due to devolution and revised arrangements for authorising consultancies from 1985 onward. To obtain the information for FY 1986/87 would be time consuming and resource intensive and I am not prepared to undertake this task.

(3) In relation to part (b) of the question, Defence Reference Book 3-Engagement of External Consultants provides instructions on the information to be provided to consultants and specifies that briefing papers and background notes provided to potential consultants when proposals are invited should normally include:
(a) terms of reference for the assignment;
(b) the main objectives-any overriding or limiting considerations of general policy should be mentioned and problems to be solved should be identified and described;
(c) specific matters to be encompassed (or not encompassed) or specific fields to be studied (or not studied);
(d) the specific tasks to sponsor wishes the consultant to undertake in logical and/or time sequence;
(e) the various skill inputs which the consultant will be expected to provide;
(g) a draft timetable of major events;
(h) the sponsor's requirements in relation to the broad content, the format and the number of copies of the final report required;

(i) any role to be played by the consultant in implementing approved changes (it would be made very clear that in projects which are likely to involve a later implementation phase, selection to carry out the project does not imply any commitment to engage the prospective consultant to carry out subsequent action);
(j) a requirement that the consultant disclose any association with other organisations or persons that could lead to a potential conflict of interest in performing the proposed assignment;
(k) any necessary background information needed to assist the consultants in preparing their proposal;
(l) the day-to-day management arrangements, accommodation and other facilities;
(m) the criteria which will be applied in the selection of the successful consultant;
(n) the form in which the consultants should submit their proposals;
(o) the deadline for submission of proposals; and
(p) a copy of the proposed contract document.

Contracts with consultants outline the terms and conditions of the agreement. Where the agreement is simple and straightforward general conditions of contract are used with documents such as purchase orders. With complex consultancies covering major projects, a specific agreement including all the terms of the consultancy is drawn up.

(4) Concerning part (e) of the question, for short term consultancies the charges and fees on which a contract is based are taken as firm for the period of the contract. For longer term engagements (over 12 months) the inclusion of a price variation clause may be justified but would reimburse the consultant only for verifiable cost increases, approved salary movements, increases in air fares, etc during the period of the engagement. Other reasons for varying fees include an approved change in scope of a consultancy or an extension of time. Additional fees would not be paid to a consultant because of failure on the part of the consultant to cost the proposal accurately or for additional work claimed to have been undertaken for which proper authorisation was not obtained in advance. Given these conditions, fees in excess of the accepted quote would be unlikely to be incurred. In view of the large number of contracts entered into during the time span nominated, I am not prepared to undertake a detailed examination of each individual agreement to determine if there are cases of payment of fees in excess of the consultants quote.
[Due to the amount of material contained in the appendices, they are not published in Hansard. Copies are available from the Senate Table Office.]

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Ministerial councils, or similar forums, for the meeting of State, Federal and other Ministers exist.
(2) What are their names and general objectives.
(3) How many times per year does the council(s)/forum(s) meet.
(4) What is the membership (including officials) of each council/forum and who chairs the meetings.
(5) Is the council(s)/forum(s) served by a Secretariat; if so, what is its composition, who is responsible for financing it, and what does it cost.
(6) What meetings of the council(s)/forum(s) were held for the last 3 financial years and how many persons attended the meetings, including officials and private ministerial staff.
(7) What were the costs of each of these meetings to the Commonwealth including travel, entertainment or dinners/lunches, accommodation etc.
(8) Where were the meetings held and what was the venue.
(9) Are the records of the meetings available to the public; if so, where can they be obtained; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two. The Premiers' Conference and the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC).

(2) Premiers' Conference: to determine Commonwealth financial assistance for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory (from 1989) and to discuss other matters proposed by the Commonwealth and/or the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Conferences can also be convened, as required, to discuss particular issues.
Economic Planning Advisory Council: The Council's objectives are:

(a) to provide a broadly based source and channel of information on economic matters to assist the Commonwealth Government in making decisions relating to economic policy and to assist State Governments, local government bodies, other bodies and individuals in making decisions that are related to the economic policy of the Commonwealth Government;
(b) to provide a forum for the participation of the community in the development and formulation of the economic policy of the Commonwealth Government; and
(c) to facilitate the development and consideration by the Commonwealth Government of medium and longer term economic assessments and policy requirements.
(3) A standard (ie. with the emphasis primarily on financial assistance) Premiers' Conference is held annually.
The Economic Planning Advisory Council meets about five times a year.

(4) Membership of a standard Premiers' Conference is as follows: Prime Minister (chairperson), the Treasurer, Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the Northern Territory and the ACT, and Commonwealth State and Territory Ministers as appropriate.
Under the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983, membership of the Council is to consist of:
A Minister chosen by the Prime Minister
Three members nominated by the State Governments
One member nominated by the Council of Local Government Associations
Three members nominated by business interests
One member nominated by rural industry
Five members nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions
One member nominated by welfare organisations
One member nominated by consumer organisations and community organisations
One member nominated by the professions
One member nominated by small business
The Hon R. J. L. Hawke AC MP
The Hon P. J. Keating MP
Ms Louise Sylvan (Consumer and community groups)
One ACTU representative position is currently vacant.
The Prime Minister chairs EPAC meetings.
(5) Secretariat support for the Premiers' Conference is provided by officers from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet as part of their normal duties.

The Economic Planning Advisory Council is served by a Secretariat. The Office of the economic Planning Advisory Council has a staff of 22 all of whom are employed under the Public Service Act. The office is funded through the annual Appropriation Acts. For 1989-90 the estimated expenditure for the Office is $1,711,000
Premiers' Conference, 18 May 1989, 14 Ministers, 115 officials and Ministerial staff.
Special Premiers' Conference on Housing, 3 March 1989, 17 Ministers, 85 officials and ministerial staff.
Premiers' Conference, 12 May 1988, 14 Ministers, 128 officials and Ministerial staff.

6 November 1987, 16 members and 10 officials and Ministerial staff.
19 February 1988, 18 members and 13 officials and Ministerial staff.
22 April 1988, 18 members, 1 guest and 14 officials and Ministerial staff.
24 June 1988, 19 members, 1 guest and 16 officials and Ministerial staff.
9 September 1988, 19 members, 4 guests and 18 officials and Ministerial staff.
18 November 1988, 18 members, 2 guests and 24 officials and Ministerial staff.
17 February 1989, 18 members, 3 guests and 21 officials and Ministerial staff.
21 April 1989, 17 members, 4 guests and 20 officials and Ministerial staff.
23 June 1989, 16 members, 2 guests and 20 officials and Ministerial staff.
Full lists of attendees at Council meetings are included in the summary records of the meetings which are available from EPAC.

(7) Premiers Conference: The cost of these meetings to the Commonwealth was as follows: $12,052 (18 May 1989); $10,739 (3 March 1989); $20,622 (12 May 1988); $3,032 (22 December 1987); and $18,313 (25 May 1987). These costs include hospitality and travel.

Individual meeting costs met by the Office of EPAC cannot be readily ascertained as Council costs are accumulated over the whole financial year and not split separately. These include airfares, travel allowances and car hire for members and invited guests.
In 1986-87, the five Council meetings held cost a total of $17,033, an average of $3,406 per meeting.
In 1987-88, the four Council meetings held cost a total of $20,378, an average of $5,094 per meeting.
In 1988-89, the five Council meetings held cost a total of $33,156, an average of $6,631 per meeting.
Hospitality costs, met by Ceremonial and Hospitality Branch of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, were:

Economic Planning Advisory Council meetings in the last three financial years were held in the Cabinet Room, Parliament House, Canberra with the exception of a special meeting held in Sydney at the State Office Block (October 1986) and another meeting (February 1988), also in Sydney, held at the Cabinet Office.

(9) Premiers' Conference 1987, 1988 and 1989: The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet can provide copies of the Hansard transcript of the public part of the Conferences. Copies of the press release by the Treasurer on the outcome of each of the Premiers' Conference and Loan Council meetings are publicly available. Official Minutes record the outcome of in-confidence discussion of the various agenda items. Release of the official Minutes would require the approval of the States and participating Territories.

Special Premiers' Conference on Housing: A press release available from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet provides an agreed summary of the outcome of the conference. Release of the official Minutes would require the approval of the States and the Northern Territory.
Meeting with Premiers on Gun Control: The outcome of the meeting is contained in a press release available from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Official Minutes were not kept.

Economic Planning Advisory Council: Summary records of each Council meeting are widely distributed via a mailing list that includes libraries, academic institutions, government agencies and community groups. Any member of the public can request a copy of a Council meeting summary record if they so desire.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 20 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Federal Police (AFP) be totally or partially withdrawn from airport service; if so:
(a) what policing service will be responsible for federal crime at airports;
(b) what service will replace the AFP and where will it stand in the pecking order of airport security services;
(c) what guarantee does the Government provide that the standard of services to be provided will be as good as, or better than those currently available;
(d) what funding will be provided to other bodies required to take over the provision of the services; and
(e) what other undertakings are there.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Protective Service (APS) is to progressively take over the counter terrorist first response function performed by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) at airports.

(a) State police already have the power to enforce Commonwealth laws at airports under the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970, and most States have already agreed to do so. It is expected that all States will enter into similar arrangements in the near future. The AFP will continue to provide the `Portswatch' function at airports as part of its role in Federal criminal investigation.

(b) As indicated earlier in my reply, the APS will take over counter-terrorist first response functions at airports. The APS is an appropriately trained force which is already experienced in security guarding at Parliament House and selected embassies, consulates and Defence establishments. The use of the APS represents an upgrading of security at airports. It will result in increased personnel at existing airports and an extension of counter-terrorist security protection to cover a further 14 designated airports around Australia.
(c) The new arrangements will result in upgraded counter-terrorist services. The Commonwealth is providing more staff at more airports to achieve this aim.

(d) The cost of the counter terrorist first response function will continue to be met from the Budget. $2.2m in 1989-90 and $14.8m per annum have been provided to take account of the transfer of the counter terrorist first response function from the AFP to the APS at 23 designated airports. Appropriate offsets will be identified as a result of the transfer.
An allocation of $5.1m has been made to the APS for establishment costs and working capital.

(e) The Australian Protective Services Act 1987 has been amended to provide necessary additional powers for the APS to carry out counter terrorist first response functions at designated security airports from 1 January 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

(7) Were any facilities of the RAAF's VIP squadron used to transport any guests to and/or from Canberra for the function; if so, who were these guests, what was the cost of their use of this facility and who paid it.

(8) Were any Commonwealth cars used to ferry any of the Prime Minister's party guests, including members of the Government and/or their spouses to and/or from Canberra airport; if so, who were these guests, what was the cost and who paid it.

(9) Were any Commonwealth cars used in any other city to transport any party guests, including Government members and/or their spouses, to and/or from their homes to any airport; if so, who were they, what was the cost and who paid it.
(10) Were Commonwealth cars used in any capacity in connection with the function; if so, what was the cost and who paid it.
(11) Were any of the Prime Minister's personal staff, or domestic staff at The Lodge, used to prepare for or assist with the birthday function.
(12) Were extra staff employed at any time in connection with the function; if so, what was the cost and who paid it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (14) The function referred to was private.
