TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 September 1989, Senator Macklin asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice concerning national saving. The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The major advantage claimed for the proposal of the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies' (AAPBS) to introduce an interest withholding tax on interest income (in lieu of subjecting that income to normal personal taxation arrangements) is that it would bring to tax interest income not declared by taxpayers in their tax returns. The Government believes a more appropriate and equitable way of achieving this objective is through the Tax File Number System. Under the Tax File Number System, from 1 July 1991, a taxpayer may choose to quote his or her Tax File Number in relation to his or her:
interest-bearing accounts or deposits with a bank, building society or credit union;
loans to bodies corporate or government bodies such as investments with finance companies and bonds; and
shares in public companies, units in unit trusts or investments through solicitors' trust accounts.

Tax file numbers will be included in income reports provided by investment bodies to the ATO. Tax file numbers will facilitate more efficient and accurate matching between these income reports and details in taxpayers' income tax returns.

From 1 July 1991, if an investor chooses not to quote his or her tax file number, tax will be deducted from interest or investment income at the highest marginal rate of personal taxation plus the Medicare levy. The investor will still be required to include the total amount of interest and other investment income payments in his or her tax return. On assessment, the investor will be allowed a credit for any tax deducted by an investment body at source.
An interest withholding tax along the lines suggested would have significant disadvantages:

it would provide a substantial tax break for persons on high marginal tax rates, whilst pena-lising those low income earners whose incomes fall below the tax threshold. The latter group would include many age pensioners whose total income would be less than their effective tax threshold;

relative to the Tax File Number System, a 15 per cent withholding tax would have a substantial cost to revenue. Tax collected from income earners below the tax free threshold would not compensate for the loss in tax revenue from income earners with marginal tax rates above 15 per cent; and

contrary to a claimed advantage, it would be unlikely to produce any net increase in national savings, its main effect probably being to encou-rage a switch in private savings from non-concessionally taxed vehicles into savings accounts and to bring about a decline in public sector saving represented by the revenue cost of the proposal.

I would also like to expand on one aspect of Senator Button's initial comments in reply to the honourable senator's question. It was stated that partnerships were included in the National Accounts figure of $17 billion but not in the income tax statistics figure of $8 billion. The Australian Tax Office has advised that the National Accounts 1986-87 Household Income sector interest income item of $17.3 billion includes all interest, royalties and land rent income other than interest, royalties and land rent income earned by the corporate sector. The National Accounts measure is derived from income flows and survey results whereas the $8.7 billion estimate published in the Taxation Statistics represents approximately 97% of interest income returned by individuals who lodge tax returns (approximately 3% of returns, late returns etc., are processed outside the period covered by the Taxation Statistics).
To obtain a comparable figure to that presented in the National Accounts, it is necessary to adjust the Taxation Statistics as follows:
Add: Interest receipts of Partnerships and Trusts ...
Add: Interest receipts of non Taxable Individuals etc.-Pensioners, children, exempt institutions ...
On this basis, there is only a very small discrepancy between the National Accounts data and the Taxation Statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, without notice, on 30 October 1989:

The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The proportion of the approximately $1.5 billion accounted for by the cost of drugs is 61%, and the proportion accounted for by remuneration for pharmacists is 39%. The Department of Community Services and Health does not have a requirement to collect figures for remuneration taken up by pharmacists' overheads. That matter is considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal in its deliberations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice, on 24 November 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to an article on page 3 of the Australian of 20 November headed `Cancer test ``unreliable'' '. Does this refer to a statement by Dr Graham Giles of the Victorian Anti-Cancer Council claiming that lifestyle-related `do-it-yourself' cancer test kits currently sold in pharmacies might produce unnecessary anxiety or undue optimism? Will the Government investigate the validity of Dr Giles's claim, and if it is justified, take action to prevent pharmacists from offering the kits for sale.
The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 24 November 1989, Senator Jones asked a question concerning do-it-yourself cancer test kits. It referred to concerns expressed by Dr Graham Giles of the Victorian Anti-Cancer Council that the use of such kits might produce unnecessary anxiety or undue optimism. Senator Jones concluded his question by asking `will the Government investigate the validity of Dr Giles's claim and, if it is justified, take action to prevent pharmacists from offering the kits for sale'. I agreed to further investigate this aspect.

I am now able to advise that the validity of Dr Giles's claim has been readily accepted. However, concerns about these tests relate to the way in which people might interpret the results rather than any inherent fault in the test kits themselves. It is not considered that the circumstances warrant a complete prohibition on the sale of these products by pharmacists, although as indicated in my earlier response, action has been taken to limit their being advertised to the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Calvert asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, without notice, on 29 November 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister please confirm that tenders for the supply of electronic equipment to be used in association with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme closed on 20 November, exactly the same date as the deadline for comments by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, which clearly indicates the farcical nature of the so-called consultation process. Is it true, as reported in the Canberra Times of 23 November, that the equipment being sought will include a magnetic card reader? Accordingly, can we assume that this plan by the Health Insurance Commission, supported by this Government, will result in personal medical information relating to members of the community being stored in a central computer in the Commission's office?
Further to my answer of 29 November 1989, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The Commission has put out a request for tenders for equipment that might be used in the processing strategy proposal that it has put to the Pharmacy Guild. The tender document makes it clear that acceptance of any tender is subject to ministerial approval of the proposal. The Commission's strategy proposal makes no provision for changes to the requirements for patient identification beyond that already required to be included on the prescription form. It does, however, recognise as a long-term objective the need to rationalise the seven different cards which currently operate under the program. The request for tender seeks information as to the extent to which the equipment may be able to be adapted to accommodate a magnetic card reader. This is simply a matter of keeping options open for the future. As there has been some delay in the Guild considering the Commission's proposals, the Commission has decided to discontinue consideration of the tenders.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 November 1989 (Hansard, page 3551), Senator Powell asked me a question without notice concerning the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children. She asked:

QUESTION.PARA: What approach is the Government taking to the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children that a national research centre be established initially supported financially by the Government and for consideration by the Australian Education Council in October this year. Does the Government believe that increased research, professional and curriculum development in this area of education would be in Australia's economic interest and is particularly important for talented children in disadvantaged groups. Has the Government received a report on this specific matter from the Australian Education Council and if not, when does it expect to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A Working Party to consider the establishment of a foundation for gifted and talented children was established by the Australian Education Council (AEC) following the September 1987 AEC meeting. The Working Party also considered the findings of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children. The Working Party's report to the AEC was considered at the October 1989 AEC meeting. At that meeting Ministers agreed that the findings of the Senate Select Committee should be dealt with at a State and Territory level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December 1989 (Hansard, page 3994), Senator Messner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security a question without notice concerning superannuation. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Yes, for employees who receive some employer support for superannuation. Employees who receive no employer support (including no award superannuation) will be able to claim a tax deduction for the first $3000 of contributions plus 75 per cent of the excess over $3000 in the year, provided the total deduction funds benefits within the reasonable benefit limits for the individual concerned.

(b) Yes. However, it should be noted that, in the 1989-90 Budget Speech, the Treasurer only raised the possibility of the gradual introduction of a further 3 per cent award for occupational superannuation forming part of the wage system for next financial year.

(c) Were there to be any further increases in award superannuation or coverage of award superannuation, the tapering of the deduction for the personal superannuation contributions of supported employees will not make these employees worse off in tax terms as regards superannuation contributions. Employer contributions, paid directly to the superannuation fund, are part of an employee's remuneration on which no personal income tax is paid by the employee. In this light, they are equivalent to deductible contributions made by the employee. Therefore, any reduction in the size of the deduction allowed for the employee's personal superannuation contributions, occurring as a result of an increase in employer contributions in excess of 4 per cent of wage or salary, must be precisely equal to the increase in employer contributions in excess of 4 per cent.

It should not be overlooked that the existing 3 per cent award for occupational superannuation has, for the first time, provided the average worker with greatly increased access to superannuation-traditionally the preserve of highly paid professionals and public sector employees. The average worker can now more readily benefit from the tax concessions provided to superannuation to provide a better and more secure income in retirement.
